micro: Ulcerated wound of second toe, with associated skin and soft tissue inflammation, abscess formation, and soft tissue necrosis.
Distal bone underlying the wound exhibits histologic findings compatible with acute bacterial osteomyelitis, with associated osseous necrosis.
Separately received proximal bone with acute osteomyelitis and osseous necrosis.

Histologic sections of this right forearm mass demonstrate a bland myxoid lesion arising within skeletal muscle. No cytologic atypia, mitotic activity, or necrosis is identified. The lesion is well-marginated, surrounded by a fibrous pseudocapsule. Focally, tumor is present at the inked margin, but no evidence of tumoral transsection is noted.

(4 H+E): Sections show a lobular proliferation of capillaries lined by cytologically bland endothelial cells surrounded by an epithelial collarette, with surface keratinizing squamous epithelium, ulceration and fibrinopurulent exudate. The lobules are separated by bands of loose and edematous connective tissue. Immunohistochemical stains for ERG, CD31, and CD34 show diffuse expression in the endothelial cells. Stains for GLUT1, D2-40, PROX1, and STAT6 show no expression.

(4 H&E): Sections show a large foreign body type granuloma characterized by palisading histiocyte and many giant cells containing polarizable foreign body. In the background there are sheets of benign spindle cells, within a fibrous stroma. There are areas of non-ossified and woven bone. No areas of acute inflammation or malignancy are identified. Multiple levels are examined.
(1 H&E) Sections show a cystic structure without an epithelial lining with a fibrovascular soft tissue wall without inflammation

Immunohistochemical (IHC) studies were performed on this specimen. The neoplastic cells are positive for nuclear expression of both HMGA2 protein and MDM2 protein. These findings support the diagnosis of ALT. On our gross examination of this specimen, the mass measured 17.3 cm in greatest dimension; however, the shape of fatty tumors such as this tumor often become significantly distorted once the specimen is removed. Therefore, correlation with pre-operative imaging studies is recommended from a more accurate assessment.

Immunohistochemical (IHC) studies were performed on this specimen. The cells are positive for nuclear expression of HMGA2 protein and negative for the expression of MDM2 protein. These findings support the diagnosis of lipoma.
CD163 highlights a few scattered histiocytes within the tissue.

(2 H&E) Sections show islands of viable woven and reactive bony trabeculae surrounded by a moderately cellular fibrohistiocytic stroma with a storiform pattern, and occasional intermixed osteoclast-like giant cells as well as hemosiderin deposition. A few foamy macrophages are noted.

Sections show viable bone with reactive changes, including fibrosis and mixed acute and chronic inflammation involving the bony trabeculae. A focal neutrophilic infiltrate is present adjacent to a bone fragment. No cytologic atypia is identified.
Sections demonstrate viable bone with reactive and regenerative changes. No cytologic atypia is identified.
Sections show a lesion containing sheets of "ghost cells', with occasional areas of basaloid cells, surrounded by fibrous tissue and mild chronic inflammation. The lesion is well circumscribed.

(5 H&E, 1 GLUT-1) Sections reveal a soft tissue lesion composed predominantly of mature adipose tissue arranged in a lobular architecture defined by delicate fibrous septa. Interspersed throughout the adipose are clusters of vessels of varying caliber, including thin- and thick-walled vascular channels with irregularly shaped lumina, some with intraluminal red blood cells. The walls of many vessels show irregular muscular thickening. The vascular component is heterogeneous, with a mixture of venous-type channels and larger muscular arteries. Foci of fibroconnective tissue are present. A Glut-1 immunostain is negative in th endothelial cells of lesional vessels excluding infantile hemangioma.  No cytologic atypia, mitotic activity, or malignant features are identified.

Sections show portions of foreskin partially involved by a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate at the dermal-epithelial junction, associated with focal hyalinized fibrosis and areas of epithelial erosion.
(focal) High grade intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN)

Invasive squamous cell carcinoma, moderately differentiated, arising from metaplastic squamous mucosa and extending through muscularis propria into pericystic soft tissue and into left seminal vesicle; surgical margins negative for tumor (see microscopic description)
Clear cell renal cell carcinoma with extensive rhabdoid and sarcomatoid features and remarkable necrosis; WHO/ISUP nuclear grade 4 out of 4

Since Banff 1997(2) a biopsy has been considered adequate if it contains at least 10 or more glomeruli and at least 2 arteries; the threshold for a “minimal sample” is 7 glomeruli and 1 artery. It is also recommended that at least 2 separate cores containing cortex be obtained or that there be 2 separate areas of cortex in the same core.(3)

Light microscopy: Multiple sections are alternately stained with H&E, trichrome, PAS and silver stains. Up to 6 glomeruli are seen per section without global sclerosis. One glomerulus displays focal segmental sclerosis. On H&E and PAS stains, the remaining glomeruli show focal mild mesangial hypercellularity and increased matrix. No endocapillary proliferation or extracapillary proliferation and crescents are observed.  On silver stains, no obvious subepithelial spikes or significant glomerular basement membrane reduplications are seen. ~20% of interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy is detected by trichrome stained section. Rare arteries show moderate intimal fibrous thickening.

Immunofluorescence: Sections of renal cortex containing 3 glomeruli are evaluated for IgG, IgA, IgM, C3, c1q, fibrinogen and albumin. The glomeruli show granular peripheral capillary and mesangial deposition of IgA (2+) and IgG (1+).  The glomeruli are negative for the other reactants. The tubules and vessels are negative for all reactants.

Electron microscopy: 16 electron micrographs of one representative glomeruli and adjacent interstitium are examined. Some electron dense deposits are identified mainly in subendothelial and mesangial patterns. And subepithelial membranous deposits are less frequently observed but present within several capillary loops. The podocyte foot-processes show focally effacement. Definitive tubuloreticular bodies are not identified. No deposits are detected within the tubular basement membranes. Subendothelial electron dense deposits are seen in a small vessel.

On silver stains, no obvious subepithelial spikes or significant glomerular basement membrane reduplications are seen. ~***% of interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy is detected by trichrome stained section.

Light microscopy: Multiple sections are alternately stained with H&E, trichrome, PAS and silver stains. Up to 35 glomeruli are seen per section. No global sclerosis is noted. On H&E and PAS stains, 18 glomeruli show mesangial proliferation, in which, 10 glomeruli display endocapillary hypercellularity as well; cellular or cellulofibrous crescents are identified in 4 glomeruli.  Fibroid necrosis and karyorrhexis are seen in a few glomeruli. On silver stains, no subepithelial spikes or reduplications are seen. The tubules lie back-to-back without significant interstitial fibrosis or tubular atrophy. Rare patchy interstitial inflammatory cell infiltration is noted. A few small vessels show mild intimal fibrous thickening.

Immunofluorescence: Sections of renal cortex containing 3 glomeruli are evaluated for IgG, IgA, IgM, C3, C1q, fibrinogen and albumin. The glomeruli, tubules and vessels are negative for all reactants.
Immunohistochemical stain of C4d was performed on block A1 and shows focal perimesangial granular deposition (non-specific pattern)

Electron microscopy: 12 electron micrographs of two representative glomeruli and adjacent interstitium are examined.  A small cellular crescent with associated mesangial and endocapillary proliferation is noted in toluidine blue stained slides. Some immunocomplex type electron dense deposits are identified within the mesangial area. The thickness of glomerular basement membrane is within normal limits without reduplication identified. The podocyte foot-processes show focal sloughing and effacement.

The morphological findings and immunocomplex type electron-dense deposits identified in the electron microscopic study, in conjunction with the patient's past medical history (IgA vasculitis on skin biopsy), support the diagnosis of immune complex-mediated necrotizing and crescentic glomerulonephritis. Although IgA nephropathy is suspected, a definitive diagnosis cannot be established due to the negative results of immunofluorescence, including repeated tests for IgA, C3, and Fibrinogen. The possibility of false-negative immunofluorescence results cannot be completely excluded. Clinical correlation is recommended.

Crescentic and exudative glomerulonephritis, mostly consistent with postinfectious glomerulonephritis
-Mild arteriosclerosis
-Mild interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy

Light microscopy: Multiple sections are alternately stained with H&E, trichrome, PAS and silver stains. Up to 20 glomeruli are seen per section. One global sclerosis is noted. On H&E and PAS stains, cellular or cellulofibrous crescents are identified in at least 8 glomeruli. Segmental mesangial proliferation with moderate extracellular matrix expansion are noted in a few glomeruli, and rare endocapillary and extracapillary proliferation is noted. In addition, some glomeruli show neutrophil exudation. On silver stains, no subepithelial spikes or reduplications are seen. Approximate 10% interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy is noted in trichrome stained slides. Rare patchy interstitial inflammatory cell infiltration is noted. The vessels show mild intimal fibrous thickening.

Immunofluorescence: Sections of renal cortex containing 8 glomeruli are evaluated for IgG, IgA, IgM, C3, C1q, fibrinogen and albumin. The glomeruli show granular mesangial deposition of C3 (2+) while negative for the other reactants. The tubules and vessels are negative for all reactants.

Electron microscopy: 12 electron micrographs of one representative glomerulus and adjacent interstitium are examined. Endocapillary proliferation is noted. A few subepithelial "Hump" like deposits are identified. The thickness of glomerular basement membrane is within normal limits. Electron-lucent subendothelial widening with mesangial interposition are noted in rare capillary lumens. The podocyte foot-processes show focal effacement.

(3 H&E) Sections show unremarkable oxyntic-type gastric mucosa overlying a well-circumscribed submucosal nodule composed of benign pancreatic tissue. The nodule demonstrates a lobulated architecture with pancreatic acinar cells, scattered pancreatic islets, and intervening ductal and vascular structures. No cytologic atypia or evidence of malignancy is identified. Overall, the findings are consistent with benign pancreatic heterotopia.

Sections in parts B and C demonstrate partial atrophy of oxyntic glands. This finding can be seen in the setting of atrophic/autoimmune gastritis. Correlation with laboratory testing for anti-parietal cell and anti-intrinsic factor antibodies may be suggested if clinical suspicion is present

The history of *** is noted. The findings in the donor terminal ileum and colon are mild and nonspecific. There are no granulomas, viral cytopathic effect, or infectious microorganisms identified on H&E stain. The differential diagnosis for these findings includes mild acute cellular rejection, therapeutic drug injury (e.g. mycophenolate) and infection. Further clinical correlation and evaluation is recommended.
Immunohistochemistry (IHC) Testing for Mismatch Repair (MMR) Proteins:
IHC Interpretation: No loss of nuclear expression of MMR proteins: low probability of MSIH.
Immunohistochemical stains for mismatch repair (MMR) proteins have been ordered, and the results will be reported as an addendum.

The duodenal biopsy (part A) shows mild intraepithelial lymphocytosis in the setting of preserved crypt and villous architecture. The findings are not specific and raise a differential diagnosis including small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO), medication injury (NSAIDs and olmesartan), peptic injury, celiac disease (if felt to be consistent celiac disease, the findings of this biopsy would be consistent with a Marsh type I lesion), and sensitivity to nongluten proteins, amongst others. Further clinical correlation and evaluation is recommended.

Sections of the terminal ileum show mildly active ileitis characterized by focal intraepithelial neutrophils. Sections from the colon show mildly to moderately active colitis characterized by cryptitis and crypt abscesses. There are no well-developed features of chronic mucosal injury. There are no granulomas, viral cytopathic effect, or infectious Michael organisms identified on H&E stain. There is no dysplasia within these biopsies. The differential diagnosis for these findings includes therapeutic drug injury (e.g. NSAIDs), infection, and early/evolving inflammatory bowel disease. Please correlate with clinical and endoscopic impression.

Slides demonstrate ileal mucosa with infiltrating nests of monotonous neoplastic cells with round to oval nuclei featuring finely granular chromatin. The cells stain positive for synaptophysin, chromogranin, and INSM1. Mitotic figures are not identified. Ki-67 demonstrates a proliferation index of ***%, consistent with grade *** well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumor.

Sections show enterocutaneous tissue with minimal mixed acute and chronic inflammation and reactive changes to include prominent lymphoid follicles within the lamina propria and areas of vascular congestion / hemorrhage. Overall, the findings are consistent with stoma.Reactive changes of the superficial mucosa, consistent with stoma site.

Sections show colonic mucosa with features of of chronicity including mild crypt distortion and prominent inflammatory expansion of the lamina propria by lymphocytes and plasma cells.  Chronic inflammation does not contain lymphoid aggregates/germinal center formation.  No transmural extension of inflammation is seen; the muscularis propria is intact. A focal area shows fibrovascular tissue with many  giant cells forming granulomas surrounded by chronic inflammatory cells. Throughout the specimen, the submucosa and muscularis propria demonstrate appropriate ganglion cells.  There is no evidence of dysplasia, malignancy, or viral cytopathic changes.
[<1 cm or in one location] Intestinal metaplasia (Alcian blue stain), consistent with Barrett esophagus in the appropriate endoscopic setting

The portal tracts contain all expected constituents (portal veins, hepatic arteries, and bile ducts) and are devoid of significant inflammation***. There is *** bile duct injury or ductular reaction.  There is no significant lobular inflammation. There is no significant steatosis or cholestasis. Central veins are unremarkable. Trichrome and reticulin stains show *** fibrosis. PAS and PAS-D stains confirm the above findings; PAS-D stain shows no alpha-1-antitrypsin globules. Iron stain shows *** hemosiderin deposition.

In both parts A and B, show sections of degenerated endometrial tissue and abundant hemorrhage/blood clot and scattered fragments of benign smooth muscle. There is no evidence for definitive retained products of conception. Clinical correlation is recommended.
An immunostain for p16, performed on part B, shows diffuse, block-like staining, supporting the interpretation. Dr. *** has reviewed part B and concurs with the interpretation.

Sections demonstrate squamous mucosa with an intact epithelium and focal spongiosis. Chronic inflammation is focally noted within the epithelium and superficial dermis. The infiltrate is composed of lymphocytes and plasma cells without evidence of eosinophils. There is no evidence of dysplasia or malignancy, and features of lichen sclerosus are not appreciated. Findings are nonspecific and clinical correlation is recommended.
Placental disc with appropriate villous maturation and subchorionic fibrin deposition and focal areas of infarct.
Equivocal C4d staining with increased numbers of macrophages may be interpreted as a nonspecific effect due to the presence of moderate acute cellular allograft rejection.

Electron microscopy:  Ten electron micrographs of one representative sample of cardiac tissue reveal cardiomyocytes and vascular structures surrounded by interstitial spaces filled with masses of fibrillary material consistent in size (~9-10 nm diameter) and appearance with amyloid fibrils. No evidence is found to suggest a lysosomal storage disease.  No infectious agent or inflammatory infiltrate is observed in this limited sampling.

Light Microscopy: The sections show 4 fragments of myocardial tissue with myocytes showing patchy areas with mild cytoplasmic vacuolations, most of them filled with fine lipofuscin granules; there is no evidence of interstitial fibrosis, as confirmed by trichrome staining. The small vessels show no evidence of thickening and iron staining is negative. Special Congo red staining examined under polarized light shows no evidence of amyloid deposits.

Electron microscopy: Seventeen electron micrographs of the sampling of cardiac tissue reveals the cardiomyocytes to display multiple large autophagosomes and sites of focal cytoplasmic degradation. In addition to the expected non-specific lipofuscin-containing lysosomes, lysosomal inclusions bearing distinctive curvilinear structures are identified. The observed ultrastructural findings are associated with hydroxychloroquine toxicity.

CD68 highlights numerous macrophages in association with Quilty effect; a prominent intravascular component is not appreciated. C4d shows focal nonspecific staining, but appears negative in capillary endothelial cells.

Histologic evaluation demonstrates thyroid parenchyma involved by a diffuse mononuclear cell infiltrate composed predominantly of lymphocytes and plasma cells. Numerous well-formed lymphoid follicles with germinal centers are present. This inflammatory process involves the right thyroid lobe, pyramidal lobe, and isthmus. In the appropriate clinical context, these findings are most consistent with Hashimoto thyroiditis, classic form.

Histologic evaluation demonstrates a well-encapsulated tumor composed predominantly of oncocytic cells arranged in a follicular pattern. The neoplastic cells show abundant granular, deeply eosinophilic cytoplasm and prominent nucleoli. The background thyroid parenchyma exhibits preserved follicular architecture with a diffuse mononuclear inflammatory infiltrate composed primarily of lymphocytes, including numerous well-formed lymphoid follicles with germinal centers. In the appropriate clinical context, the findings in the background thyroid parenchyma are most consistent with Hashimoto thyroiditis.

Mucoceles have been described to show variable histologic morphology depending on chronicity of the lesion. In earlier phases, mucus extravasation and lymphatic proliferation is more prominent, while later phases have been described as demonstrating a variable degree of vascular proliferation. This lesion demonstrates a cystic space and copious muciphages, consistent with mucocele, however a prominent lymphovascular component is also present surrounding the pseudocystic space and at the base of the lesion. Overall, these histologic findings are most consistent with a ruptured mucocele and associated lymphangiogenesis.

(1 H&E) Sections show a cystic structure underlying nonkeratinizing stratified squamous epithelium with subjacent congested blood vessels which is filled with abundant muciphages and inflammatory cells. Fragments of seromucinous salivary gland tissue are also present at the periphery of the lesion.
A pentachrome stain supports the diagnosis. No granulomas are seen. AFB and GMS stains are negative for acid-fast bacilli, fungi, and Pneumocystis organisms

BIOPSY STAINS: Iron, PAS, PAS-D, Trichrome, and Reticulin

Comment: The post-reperfusion liver biopsy shows changes consistent with mild reperfusion injury, including mild macrovesicular steatosis (5%), mild focal infiltration of inflammatory cells around portal tracts, and mild cholestasis. Trichrome staining reveals mild pericellular fibrosis. Iron staining does not detect iron deposition, and PAS-D staining does not highlight alpha1-antitrypsin intracytoplasmic globules.

Comment: Examination of the liver explant shows parenchymal nodularity with fibrous bands and septations. These fibrous bands contain a mild inflammatory infiltrate, predominantly composed of lymphocytes. A mild ductular reaction is noted. There is no evidence of steatosis, ballooned hepatocytes, or Mallory-Denk bodies. Prominent cholestasis is present within the regenerative nodules. Prussian blue staining shows no iron deposition, and PAS-D staining is negative for intracytoplasmic globules. The portal veins show foci of vascular calcifications. The findings are consistent with advanced chronic liver disease.

Microscopic examination demonstrates liver parenchyma with well-developed fibrous septation and parenchymal nodularity, consistent with cirrhosis (confirmed by trichrome and reticulin stains). The fibrous septa show ductular reaction and patchy lymphocytic inflammation. The native bile ducts are present and without inflammation. There is no significant interface or lobular inflammation. The septal vasculature is unremarkable. The hepatocytes show about 5% macrovesicular steatosis without ballooning degeneration. The cytoplasm contains no Mallory's hyalin or hyaline globules. Rare cholestasis is present. No sinusoidal dilation or congestion is present. PAS stain shows variable hepatocellular uptake without abnormality. A PASD stain is negative for alpha-1 antitrypsin globules. An iron stain shows foci of 1 plus hepatocellular iron deposition. Benign macroregenerative nodules are present. Additionally, a benign hemangioma (A8), biliary microhamartoma (A10), and biliary type cysts (confirmed with negative d240 and calretinin) are also present. Additional stains performed on sampled nodules show intact reticulin framework, perinodule ductules (CK7), nondiffuse glutamine synthetase, and no nuclear beta catenin. Glypican 3 is noncontributory.

Microscopic examination demonstrates liver parenchyma with adequate sampling of portal and central areas. There is no significant portal, central, or sinusoidal fibrosis (confirmed by trichrome and reticulin stains). There is patchy mild to moderate portal inflammation comprised mostly of lymphocytes. Rare bile ducts show lymphocytic cholangitis; no ductopenia or significant proliferation is present. The portal vasculature is unremarkable. There is foci of mild interface activity, some of which show conspicuous plasma cells. The hepatocytes show rare apoptosis and minimal macrovesicular steatosis (<5%) without balloonging degeneration. The cytoplasm contains no Mallory's hyaline or hyaline globules. There patchy foci of lobular inflammation, some with conspicuous plasma cells. No cholestasis is present. No sinusoidal dilation or congestion is present. The central veins are patent and without fibrosis. PAS stain shows variable hepatocellular uptake without abnormality. A PASD stain is negative for alpha-1 antitrypsin globules. An iron stain is negative.

Microscopic examination demonstrates liver parenchyma with patchy predominantly centrilobular necrosis (about 5% of tissue). There is no definite fibrosis (Trichrome stain is suboptimal/overstained; reticulin stain). There is patchy minimal portal inflammation comprised of lymphocytes. The bile ducts are intact with no inflammation, ductopenia, or proliferation. The portal vasculature is unremarkable. There is no significant interface activity. In addition to centrilobular necrosis, the hepatocytes show scattered apoptosis and focal cholestasis. The cytoplasm contains no hyaline globules. Rare clusters of lobular neutrophils are noted. No steatosis is present. No sinusoidal dilation or congestion is present. The central veins are patent and without inflammation or fibrosis. PAS stain shows variable hepatocellular uptake without abnormality. A PASD stain is negative for alpha-1 antitrypsin globules. An iron stain is negative.

The findings in this biopsy are minimal and nonspecific. The H&E and reticulin stain appears to show a subtle patchy hepatocellular plate atrophy. Although this could raise the possibility of a vascular flow issue, it is overall patchy and very minimal in degree; the clinical significance of this finding is uncertain. Clinical and radiologic correlation is suggested.

Microscopic examination demonstrates multiple cores of liver parenchyma with adequate sampling of portal and central areas. There is minimal periportal and interstitial fibrosis seen (confirmed by reticulin and trichrome stains). There is patchy mild portal inflammation comprised mostly of lymphocytes. No lymphocystic cholangitis, no ductopenia or significant proliferation is seen. The portal vasculature does not demonstrate endotheliitis. There is no significant interface or lobular activity. Hepatocytes show minimal reactive changes, focal cholestasis, and no definite apoptosis. The cytoplasm contains no hyaline globules, significant steatosis, or abnormal glycogen. No sinusoidal dilatation or red blood cell congestion is present. Central veins are patent. PAS stain shows variable hepatocellular uptake without abnormality. A PASD stain is negative for alpha-1 antitrypsin globules. An iron stain shows no significant iron deposition.

Microscopic examination demonstrates one (1) core of liver parenchyma with adequate sampling of portal and central areas. There is portal, periportal, and perisinusoidal fibrosis without bridging (confirmed by trichrome stain). There is patchy mild portal inflammation composed of mostly lymphocytes with rare neutrophils. No portal or periportal granulomas are present. The bile ducts are present and without significant proliferation. The portal vasculature is unremarkable. There is no significant interface activity. The hepatocytes show ballooning degeneration and associated lobular inflammation // no significant steatosis. The cytoplasm contains no hyaline globules or abnormal glycogen. The nuclei show patchy prominent glycogen. No cholestasis is present. No sinusoidal dilation or congestion is present. The central veins are patent. PAS stain shows variable hepatocellular uptake without abnormality. A PASD stain is negative for alpha-1 antitrypsin globules. An iron stain shows 2+ hepatocellular iron deposition // no significant iron deposition // mild reticuloendothelial and rare foci of 1+ hepatocellular iron deposition.

Microscopic examination demonstrates multiple cores of liver parenchyma with adequate sampling of portal and central areas. There is no pathologic fibrosis (confirmed by reticulin and trichrome stains). There is patchy mild portal inflammation comprised mostly of lymphocytes. Rare bile ducts appear injured and show lymphocytic cholangitis; no ductopenia or significant proliferation is seen. The portal vasculature demonstrates endothelialitis. There is no significant interface or lobular activity. Hepatocytes show minimal reactive changes, focal cholestasis, and no definite apoptosis. The cytoplasm contains no hyaline globules, significant steatosis, or abnormal glycogen. No sinusoidal dilatation or red blood cell congestion is present. Central veins are patent. PAS stain shows variable hepatocellular uptake without abnormality. A PASD stain is negative for alpha-1 antitrypsin globules. An iron stain shows no significant iron deposition.
An iron stain shows mild reticuloendothelial and rare foci of 1+ hepatocellular iron deposition.

(3 H&E, 1 Trichrome, 1 PAS, 1 PAS/D, 1 Iron, 1 PanCK): Sections show core liver tissue composed of predominately viable and few injured hepatocytes, with giant cell transformation. The portal tracts contain a bile ductular reaction as evidenced by pancytokeratin and PAS staining. There is abundant hepatocytic and canalicular cholestasis with areas showing bile duct plugs. There is also mild to moderate, primarily chronic portal inflammation.  No PAS diastase resistant accumulations of alpha-1 antitrypsin are seen.  Trichrome staining shows fibrous expansion of the portal areas with some septa formation. Iron stain highlights mild hepatocytic iron accumulation, favored to represent reactive change. Additionally, there are focal areas show mild neutrophilic inflammation with microabscess formation, however, CMV and adenovirus special stains are negative.

EM: Electron microscopic examination reveals distorted hepatic parenchyma with prominent mixed inflammation and accumulation of bile. The accumulated bile does not display the coarse granular appearance associated with PFIC-1. Canalicular bile plugs are observed. Focal cytoplasmic necrosis and lysosomal biliary debris are noted in most hepatocytes. Mitochondria display a normal abundance and distribution, with a degenerative appearance in the most affected hepatocytes. Peroxisomes are observed. Glycogen is present in normal amount. Lipid is absent. No inclusions of the type associated with alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency are observed. No infectious agent is detected. No unusual storage product suggestive of a metabolic storage disease is observed within the Kupffer cells or hepatocytes. The described features of cholestatic injury do not offer a definitive etiology but may be associated with extrahepatic biliary obstruction.

An immunostain for E-cadherin shows retained membranous staining, supporting ductal phenotype. Immunohistochemical studies for ER, PR, HER2, and Ki-67 have been ordered and results will be reported as an addendum. Dr. Post has reviewed this case and concurs with the diagnosis.

Drs. Howe and Gray were notified of the final diagnosis on 5/2/2023 by Dr. Berning.

An immunohistochemical stain for E-cadherin demonstrates loss in the invasive component, supporting lobular phenotype. Immunohistochemical studies for ER, PR, HER2, and Ki-67 have been ordered and results will be reported as an addendum. Dr. *** has reviewed this case and concurs with the diagnosis.

Histologic evaluation of the needle core biopsy demonstrates multiple foci of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), including both comedo-type and solid-type patterns. A portion of the specimen contains free-floating clusters of tumor cells suspended within mucin without an identifiable background of breast parenchyma. Additionally, there is a very small focus (<1 mm) of tumor cells with scant mucin embedded within intact breast parenchyma, meeting criteria for at least microinvasion. The invasive component appears low grade (Nottingham grade 1; tubules 1 + nuclei 1 + mitoses 1 = 3/9). Immunohistochemical stains for myoepithelial markers (p63 and SMMHC) highlight attenuated myoepithelial cells around the in situ component and demonstrate predominantly absent myoepithelial staining around the free-floating tumor clusters within mucin. Taken together, these findings support a diagnosis of DCIS with at least microinvasive carcinoma. Definitive staging and further characterization are best performed on additional biopsy material, excision, and/or radiologic correlation. Further clinical evaluation is recommended.

Microinvasive mammary carcinoma

Sections show a well circumscribed moderately lobulated fibroepithelial lesion composed of ducts and lobules with significant interlobular stromal fibrosis with varying amounts of adipose tissue present. There is usual ductal hyperplasia and apocrine metaplasia within the lesion. The presence of these components are consistent with a benign mammary hamartoma. Dr. Berning has reviewed selected slides and concurs with the diagnosis

Histologic evaluation reveals a large, well-encapsulated, biphasic lesion composed of stromal and epithelial elements. The stroma is relatively cellular and the epithelial component forms open ductal spaces in a predominantly pericanalicular pattern. A subtle, vaguely fascicular growth pattern is noted within the stroma. Taken together, the morphologic features support the diagnosis of a juvenile fibroadenoma.

If there are multiple invasive carcinomas, size, grade, histologic type, and the results of studies for estrogen receptor (ER), progesterone receptor (PR), and HER2 should pertain to the largest invasive carcinoma. If smaller invasive carcinomas differ in any of these features, this information may be included in the "Comments" section.

Alpha synuclein highlights Lewy bodies in all areas of neocortex, hippocampus, amygdala, substantia nigra and Locus coeruleus. There is mild to moderate global arteriolosclerosis as well as loss of perivascular parenchyma at the basal ganglia, with neuritic core plaques identified by Bielschowsky staining.

The substantia nigra and locus coeruleus demonstrate decreased pigmentation in the midbrain and pons. Lewy Bodies are visualized within the midbrain and pons and confirmed with alpha synuclein. The cerebellum demonstrates cerebellar amyloid angiopathy and is confirmed with Beta-amyloid staining. Bielschowsky stain highlights Aβ plaques and neurofibrillary tangles within the amygdala.

Infection: Fetal brain was received partially macerated. The leptomeninges revealed mild-moderate mononuclear inflammation consistent with meningitis. Fragments of immature, developing neocortex are identified revealing a polymicrogyria pattern of disrupted cortical neurons with frequent microcalcifications. The subcortical white matter revealed several scattered microglial nodules and frequent perivascular inflammation. Inflammation is also identified in the immature choroid plexus, ependymal cells, and germinal matrix. There are also scattered areas of focal necrosis and germinal matrix loss. Developing deep grey structures and cerebellum were also identified. No obvious cytomegaly is identified but could potentially be obscured by inflammation. CMV stain highlights several CMV-positive cells.

moderate to severe arteriolosclerosis and are free of amyloid angiopathy. The cerebral cortex shows normal cellularity. The right frontal corpus callosum displays loss of myelin by PLP and LFB/PAS within the lesion with little to no inflammatory cells, supportive of a chronic lesion in the white matter. Minimal to mild macrophages/microglial cells (CD68) are present at the edge of the plaque. The right paraventricular area with corpus callosum also demonstrates loss of myelin, consistent with chronic lesion. The right paraventricular parietal/occipital region shows scattered macrophages/microglial cells but no obvious loss of myelin by PLP and LFB/PAS staining. The right posterior internal capsule shows loss of axons, consistent with focal area of infarct and is supported by CD68 and neurofilament staining. The left occipital lobe demonstrates extensive reactive gliosis (GFAP), subpial gliosis and arteriolosclerosis. In the cerebellum, reactive gliosis is seen around the Purkinje cells and within the granular neurons. The basal ganglia are unremarkable. Sections of the brainstem are unremarkable.

PSP: Sections of the left frontal lobe show focal hemosiderin-laden perivascular polymorphonuclear leukocytes. The remainder of the neocortices are similar and described collectively. These sections include the right superior temporal lobe, right parietal lobe, and right occipital lobe. They display normal neuronal layering without hypoxic/ischemic injury in the neurons with moderate subcortical arteriosclerosis identified globally. No hemorrhage or inflammation is identified. The hippocampus demonstrates appropriate cellularity without ischemic change. The basal ganglia and thalamus do not demonstrate any obvious abnormality by H&E.

Bielschowsky stains highlight scattered extracellular plaques and neurofibrillary tangles in the frontal and parietal lobe as well as diffuse neurofibrillary tangles in the basal ganglia, thalamus, cerebellum, pons, and medulla. Subsequent tau immunostain highlights neurofibrillary tangles and tau positive astrocytes of the basal ganglia, thalamus, and subthalamic nucleus. Tau staining also identified neurofibrillary tangles of the pons, neuropil threads in olivary nuclei, as well as neurons of the dentate nucleus in the
cerebellum. This tau pathology is predominantly 4R tau positive by IHC. 3R tau is negative in all the same regions.

Sections show paracortical hyperplasia, sinus histiocytosis, and dermatopathic changes. There is no histologic, flow cytometric, or immunophenotypic support for lymphomatous involvement.

Additionally, there is a paracortical hyperplasia with prominent epithelioid histiocytes and Langerhan cells, some with intracytoplasmic pigment. The paracortical lymphocytes are small and banal with condensed chromatin. No large atypical cells, Hodgkin Reed-Sternberg (HRS) like cells, or metastatic tumor are identified. Immunohistochemistry (IHC) is performed. CD20 highlights B-lymphocytes predominantly in the follicles. CD3 highlights T-lymphocytes predominantly in the paracortex. CD10 highlights germinal centers. BCL2 is positive in the T-lymphocytes and mantle zone, but appropriately negative in germinal centers. CD1a highlights the increased Langerhan cell population.

The lymph node core biopsy shows multiple areas of coagulative necrosis with surrounding histiocytes and occasional multinucleated giant cells. The remaining lymph node contains mostly small lymphocytes and scattered plasma cells. There is no overt atypical lymphocytes or metastatic tumor noted.

By immunohistochemical staining, CD3 highlights abundant reactive T-cells, CD20 is positive in abundant small reactive B-cells, CK AE1/3 is negative, CD30 highlights rare immunoblasts, and HHV8 is negative. AFB shows scattered mycobacterial microorganisms. GMS and PAS-G are negative for fungal elements.

The biopsy shows expansion of mucosa by abundant mature plasma cells and small clusters of lymphocytes. CD3, CD20 and PAX5 show mixed infiltration of T-cells and B-cells. EBER-ISH reveals small loose clusters of positive cells.
Post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder, plasmablastic lymphoma variant - See Comment and Microscopic Description

The small intestine biopsy shows a diffuse infiltration by large atypical cells with background coagulative necrosis. The lesional cells reveal large round nuclei with vesicular chromatin and a central prominent nucleolus. The cytoplasm is abundant and amphophilic. By immunohistochemical and in situ hybridization staining, the tumor cells are diffusely positive for CD138, MUM1, and EBER-ISH. Kappa and lambda ISH assays show kappa restriction. They are negative for CD3, CD20, PAX5, HHV8, and CK AE1/3. CMV is negative. The overall morphology and immunophenotype support a diagnosis of post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder, plasmablastic lymphoma variant.

The colectomy specimen shows focal acute inflammation, ulceration, submucosal atypical lymphoid infiltration, and prominent fibrosis. The lymphoid infiltration consists mostly of small mature lymphocytes and plasma cells with admixed histiocytes and granulocytes. In addition, there are scattered large atypical lymphocytes, which have one or two nuclei with vesicular chromatin and prominent eosinophilic or basophilic nucleoli. The cytoplasm is abundant and pale eosinophilic. No solid sheets of atypical lymphocytes or epithelial neoplasm is noted. Several diverticula are noted near the fibrosis/stricture.

Large cells show vesicular chromatin, abundant cytoplasm, and prominent nucleoli. The lymph node demonstrates scattered bands of fibrosis.

Thank you for allowing us to review this case for the purpose of continuing patient care. We agree with the diagnosis rendered by the originating pathologists. The findings in part B show a lymph node with effacement of normal architecture and proliferation of nodules and sheets predominantly lymphocytes with mixed histiocytes and eosinophils. Large, atypical cells are admixed within the infiltrate, showing occasional bi and multinucleation (Hodgkin/Reed-Sternberg cells; HRS cells). Large cells show vesicular chromatin, abundant cytoplasm, and prominent nucleoli. The large atypical HRS cells are positive for CD30, CD15, PAX5 (dim), BCL6 (weak), MUM1, and EBER, and negative for CD45, CD20, and CD3. The loss of CD20 expression and dim PAX5 staining reflect a downregulated B-cell transcriptional program, a defining feature of classical Hodgkin lymphoma. The background reactive lymphoid population is highlighted by CD20 and CD3, confirming the presence of mixed reactive B and T cells, while CD21 highlights residual follicular dendritic cell networks. Taken together, the morphologic and immunophenotypic findings support a diagnosis of classical Hodgkin lymphoma, mixed cellularity subtype.

Histologic evaluation shows sections of intestinal mucosa partially involved by a lymphoepithelial process with underlying expansion of the lamina propria with small to medium sized neoplastic cells arranged in sheets and some areas showing nodularity. The neoplastic cells are composed of small cells with irregular nuclear borders as well as some scattered medium sized cells with more prominent nuclei. Multiple levels were examined. These morphologic findings and immunohistochemistry staining (see below) support the diagnosis of a low grade B-cell non-hodkgin lymphoma. Further clinical correlation and evaluation is recommended.

Histologic evaluation demonstrates a diffuse atypical lymphoid infiltrate composed predominantly of small lymphocytes / centrocytes without formation of definitive follicles or germinal centers. The atypical cells show positivity for CD20, BCL2, and BCL6. Cyclin D1 is negative, and CD3 highlights background reactive T cells. The Ki-67 proliferation index is approximately 10–15%. By report, flow cytometry identifies a CD10-positive monoclonal B-cell population. Taken together, the morphologic and immunophenotypic findings support a diagnosis of low-grade follicular lymphoma.

Histologic evaluation shows a lymph node effaced by atypical nodular lymphocytic infiltrates composed mostly of centrocytes and occasional centroblasts. There are no tingible body macrophages or distinct polarization. By immunohistochemistry, the atypical lymphocytes are positive for CD20, CD10, BCL6, and BCL2. The atypical lymphocytes are negative for cyclin D1. Ki67 reveals low proliferation index overall 30% in the follicles. CD3 stains small T-cells in interfollicular areas. CD20 shows background B-cells. CD21 highlights multiple follicular dendritic meshworks underlying the B cell nodules. Overall, morphology, immunohistochemistry, and flow cytometry findings are suggestive of a follicular lymphoma, low grade. Further correlation with clinical, molecular, and genetic findings is recommended.

Histologic evaluation of part A shows sections of intestinal mucosa partially involved by a lymphoepithelial process with ulceration and an underlying expansion of the lamina propria with mixed inflammatory cells composed predominately of eosinophils, plasma cells, and lymphocytes. No morphologic or immunophenotypic evidence (see below) of a post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder is identified. Histologic evaluation of part B is not notable for any distinct inflammatory infiltrate. Further clinical correlation, evaluation, and monitoring is recommended.

Immunohistochemical and in-situ hybridization studies (Block A1) demonstrate CD20 and CD10 highlight background and reactive B-cells, while CD3 and CD5 highlight reactive T-cells. CD30 highlights rare immunoblasts. MUM1 and CD138 show positivity in plasma cells and background B-cells, and PAX5 highlights background B-cells. EBER demonstrates rare positive cells. Cyclin D1 and BCL6 highlight scant background B-cells. The Ki-67 proliferation index is unremarkable. Kappa and lambda in-situ hybridization demonstrate polytypic plasma cells in an approximately 1:1 ratio.

Microscopic examination reveals unremarkable sqamous mucosa involved by an underlying infiltrative lymhoid process. Sheets of lymphocytes occupy the dermis ranging in size from small to large. The large lymphocytes are pleomorphic with prominent nucleoli and brisk mitotic activity.

Immunohistochemical studies show the atypical lymphoid cells to be diffusely positive for CD20, confirming B-cell lineage, with CD3 highlighting admixed reactive T-cells. CD21 demonstrates expanded and partially disrupted follicular dendritic cell networks. The neoplastic cells are negative for CD10, BCL2, Cyclin D1, pancytokeratin, and SOX10, excluding follicular, mantle cell, and epithelial or melanocytic differentiation. MIB1 (Ki-67) demonstrates a low proliferative index within the neoplastic population. Kappa and lambda in-situ hybridization reveal polytypic plasma cells. Of note, Neogenomics reporting (FC25-33173) identified a conal immunoglobulin heavy chain (IgH) rearrangement. These findings support the diagnosis of a marginal zone lymphoma.

Immunohistochemical studies show the atypical lymphoid cells to be diffusely positive for CD20, confirming B-cell lineage, with CD3 highlighting admixed reactive T-cells. CD21 demonstrates expanded and partially disrupted follicular dendritic cell networks. The neoplastic cells are positive for BCL6 and negative for CD10, BCL2, Cyclin D1, pancytokeratin, and SOX10, excluding follicular, mantle cell, and epithelial or melanocytic differentiation. MUM1 shows variable expression within scattered large cells. MIB1 (Ki-67) demonstrates an increased proliferative index within the neoplastic population. Kappa and lambda in-situ hybridization reveal polytypic plasma cells. Of note, NeoGenomics testing (FC25-33173) identified a clonal immunoglobulin heavy chain (IgH) gene rearrangement.

Excisional biopsy of the lymph node reveals preserved nodal architecture with follicular hyperplasia and focal mild paracortical hyperplasia. Occasional immunoblasts are observed. There are no atypical lymphocytic infiltrates, LP cells or HRS-like cells identified. CD20, PAX5 and OCT2 stain B-cell areas. CD30 reveals focal mild increase in immunoblasts. CD3 stains mostly interfollicular T cells. CD4: CD8 ratio appears increased by immunohistochemistry. PD1 and CD57 positive cells are mostly confined within the germinal centers with a few scattered cells in the interfollicular areas. The germinal centers are positive for CD10 and BCL6 without expression of BCL2. CD21 stains follicular dendritic cell meshworks. CD138 shows focal plasma cell aggregates. The plasma cells are polytypic for kappa and lambda light chains by in situ description. EBER in situ hybridization shows a few scattered EBV-positive lymphocytes. The corresponding flow cytometry reveals 53% T-cells with CD4: CD8 ratio of 4:1 and no phenotypically aberrant T-cell population, and 25% B cells with no monotypic B-cell population.

Histologic evaluation reveals a preserved lymph node with nodal architecture and prominent follicular hyperplasia. The germinal centers have preserved polarization of germinal centers. Scattered immunoblasts are present. There are no atypical lymphocytic infiltrates, LP cells or HRS-like cells identified. Immunohistochemical studies demonstrate a reactive pattern. CD20 and PAX5 highlight diffuse B-cells within follicles, while CD10 marks germinal center B-cells showing appropriate polarization. CD3, CD4, and CD8 highlight the interfollicular and paracortical T-cell zones with a normal distribution, and CD56 shows scattered reactive T-cells. CD30 highlights scattered immunoblasts without aberrant large cell populations. BCL2 expression is present in background B-cells but absent within germinal centers. EBER is negative. Overall, the immunophenotypic findings support a benign lymph node with reactive follicular hyperplasia.

Histologic evaluation reveals fibromuscular tissue with a notable lymphocytic infiltrate composed of small lymphocytes as well as small aggregates of germinal centers. Scattered immunoblasts are present. There are no LP cells or HRS-like cells identified. Immunohistochemical studies demonstrate a reactive pattern. CD20 highlights diffuse B-cells, while CD10 marks germinal center B-cells. CD3 and CD5 highlight the interfollicular and paracortical T-cell zones with a normal distribution. CD30 highlights scattered immunoblasts without aberrant large cell populations. BCL2 expression is present in background B-cells but absent within the germinal centers. BCL6 is appropriately present within the germinal centers. CD21 stains follicular dendritic cell meshworks. The IgG4:IgG ratio is low and unremarkable. Overall, the immunophenotypic findings support a reactive changes.

Histologic evaluation of part C reveals respiratory mucosal tissue with a focal area of granulation tissue and a mild lymphoid infiltrate composed predominantly of small mature lymphocytes. No large atypical cells, including LP or HRS-like cells, are identified. Immunohistochemical studies demonstrate a reactive pattern. CD20 highlights scattered background B cells, while CD3 highlights a slightly increased population of reactive T cells. CD34 is negative for blasts and accentuates background vascular structures. CD117 highlights scattered mast cells. Overall, the morphologic and immunophenotypic findings support a reactive process.

Immunohistochemical studies support a reactive process. CD20 highlights diffuse B-cells within follicles, while CD10 and BCL6 mark germinal center B-cells showing overall appropriate polarization. CD3 and CD5 highlight interfollicular and paracortical T-cell zones with a normal distribution. CD30 highlights scattered immunoblasts without aberrant large cell populations. BCL2 expression is present in background B-cells but absent within germinal centers. Cyclin D1 is negative in lymphocytes. EBER is negative. Ki-67 proliferation index is low overall, with appropriately increased activity within germinal centers. The IgG4:IgG ratio is low and unremarkable. The corresponding flow cytometric analysis (see FC25-3424 for details) reveals no monotypic B-cell population and no phenotypic aberrant T-cell population. Overall, the immunophenotypic findings support a benign lymph node with reactive follicular hyperplasia and focal PTGC.

Microscopic evaluation of part A-C reveals fibroconnective tissue with a dense lymphocytic infiltrate composed mostly of centrocytes and rare centroblasts. The lymphocytes appear to be small in size and monotonous in appearance. Immunohistochemical studies demonstrate diffuse B-cell positivity for CD20 and PAX5, with the neoplastic cells expressing CD10, BCL6, and BCL2, supporting germinal center derivation. CD21 highlights expanded and partially disrupted follicular dendritic cell networks. CD3 and CD5 highlight admixed reactive T-cells, while Cyclin D1 is negative. The Ki-67 proliferation index is approximately 10%. In-situ hybridization for EBER is negative. Flow cytometric analysis (see FC25-3335 for further details) identifies a lambda-restricted, CD10-positive B-cell population, confirming clonality. Together, these findings support the diagnosis of low-grade follicular lymphoma.
Bone marrow; aspirate smear, touch imprint, clot section, and core biopsy:
MDS with low blasts and SFE3 (outside bone marrow and ihc summary)

Examination of the peripheral blood smears reveals subtle dysplastic features within the neutrophils (some pseudo–Pelger-Huët forms and hypogranulation). Although the bone marrow aspirate is relatively paucicellular, similar mild dysplastic changes are noted within the myeloid lineage. In addition, mild erythroid dysplasia is identified, characterized by irregular nuclear contours and rare binucleate forms. The bone marrow core biopsy is markedly hypercellular (approximately 80%) with erythroid and megakaryocytic predominance. Megakaryocytes show occasional loose clustering and rare atypical, small hypolobated forms. The estimated M:E ratio is approximately 1:1. An iron stain on the aspirate smear demonstrates increased ring sideroblasts (>15%). Immunohistochemical stains of the core biopsy reveal no increase in blasts by CD34. CD117 and E-cadherin highlight an expanded erythroid population and CD31 highlights an increased megakaryocyte population. Reticulin staining shows only minimal fibrosis. By report, next-generation sequencing identifies an SF3B1 K700E mutation, with a normal FISH karyotype. These morphologic, immunophenotypic, and molecular findings are consistent with a myelodysplastic neoplasm with low blasts and SF3B1 mutation.
AML (outside bone marrow and ihc summary)

Examination of the peripheral blood smears reveals leukopenia and anemia with an increased population of blasts (>20%). Although the bone marrow aspirate is relatively paucicellular and hemodilute (limiting morphologic assessment) an increased population of blasts is noted. The bone marrow core biopsy is hypercellular (approximately 60–70%) and shows extensive sheets and aggregates of immature cells replacing normal hematopoietic elements. No overt dysplasia is identified. Immunohistochemical stains demonstrate CD34 and CD117 positivity in a markedly expanded blast population comprising at least 50% of the marrow cellularity. MPO highlights a subset of these blasts, while TdT is negative. E-cadherin highlights erythroid precursors appropriately, and CD15 highlights maturing myeloid elements. CD20 and CD3 highlight background B and T cells, respectively. Reticulin staining demonstrates mild fibrosis (MF-1). By report, next-generation sequencing (NGS) identifies a KIT D816V mutation, while fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) detects an additional copy of 21q. NGS was negative for FLT3, IDH1, IDH2, NPM1, and TP53 mutations. Overall, the morphologic, immunophenotypic, and molecular findings are consistent with acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

Examination of the peripheral blood smears reveals subtle marked thrombocytosis with platelet clumping. The bone marrow aspirate is relatively paucicellular and hemodilute, rendering difficult for evaluation. The bone marrow core biopsy is markedly hypercellular (approximately 90%) with megakaryocytic predominance. Megakaryocytes are arranged in clusters with some mild dysplasia (to include small and hypolobated forms). An iron stain on the aspirate smear does not show any increased ring sideroblasts. Immunohistochemical stains of the core biopsy reveals  rare scattered blasts by CD34 (approximately 2% of marrow cellularity). CD117 and E-cadherin highlights mast cells and erythroid precursors. Reticulin and trichrome staining shows mild to moderate fibrosis consistent with MF-1. By report, flow cytometry shows 1.3% CD34+ blasts in the bone marrow without a clonal B-cell population or abberant T-cell population identified. By report, next-generation sequencing identifies a CALR mutation, with a normal FISH karyotype.

Examination of the peripheral blood smears reveals thrombocytosis with some large forms and a notable increase in monocytes and eosinophils. Rare blasts are present. The bone marrow aspirate is adequate and demonstrates mild myeloid dysplasia (including hypolobated nuclei and decreased cytoplasmic granulation) as well as mild megakaryocytic dysplasia (hypolobated forms and nuclear separation). The bone marrow core biopsy is hypercellular for age (approximately 40%) with trilineage hematopoiesis and an increased plasma cell population. Immunohistochemical stains demonstrate CD138 positivity in plasma cells, comprising approximately 12% of the marrow cellularity. CD34 and CD117 highlight no increase in blasts. CD20 and CD3 highlight background B and T lymphocytes, respectively. Reticulin staining reveals mild fibrosis (MF-1). An iron stain performed on the aspirate shows decreased iron stores without ring sideroblasts. By report, flow cytometry identifies a monoclonal plasma cell population expressing CD19, CD38, CD56, CD138, CD200, and cytoplasmic kappa light chain restriction. Next-generation sequencing (NGS) detects JAK2 V617F and TET2 Q273 mutations, while fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) demonstrates a complex karyotype including del(7q). NGS is negative for CALR, FLT3, IDH1, IDH2, MPL, NPM1, and TP53 mutations. Taken together, the morphologic, immunophenotypic, and molecular findings support the diagnosis of a plasma cell neoplasm. In addition, given the persistent monocytosis, mild bilineage dysplasia, and presence of JAK2 and TET2 mutations with complex cytogenetic abnormalities, this patient also fulfils the criteria for myelodysplastic chronic myelomonocytic leukemia (MD-CMML-1).

The markedly enlarged lymph node shows effaced architecture by multiple macronodules. The nodules are mostly composed of small mature lymphocytes; however, there are scattered atypical large lymphocytes with multilobulated nuclei, variably prominent nucleoli, and ample pale cytoplasm, compatible with LP cells. Scattered and small clusters of histiocytes and rare immunoblasts are noted in the nodules. No sheets of large lymphocytes are noted.

Immunohistochemical stains with appropriately stained controls are performed. The atypical large lymphocytes are positive for CD20 (strong), PAX5 (strong), BOB.1, OCT2, CD45 (subset, variable), and cyclin D1, but are negative for CD30 and CD15. Epstein-Barr virus in situ hybridization is negative. CD3 highlights background small T lymphocytes and show rosette formation around the atypical lymphocytes. Rosette formation around scattered large LP cells are also seen by CD4, MUM1, and CD57 (subset). CD21 shows a marked expansion of the follicular dendritic cell meshwork. Concurrent flow cytometry is negative for an abnormal B-cell or T-cell population. Overall, the morphologic and immunophenotypic findings are diagnostic of nodular lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin lymphoma (NLPHL).

Histologic evaluation of the specimen shows a lymph node with vaguely nodular proliferation composed predominately of small, mature lymphocytes with scattered larger atypical lymphocytes present. The larger cells display multilobated nuclei, variably prominent nucleoli, and moderate amounts of cytoplasm, morphologically consistent with lymphocyte predominant (LP) cells. No confluent sheets of large atypical lymphocytes are identified. By report, the LP cells express CD20, CD45, PAX5, OCT-2, BOB-1, and EMA (partial), and are negative for CD30, CD15, CD10, ALK-1, and pancytokeratin. Additional reported findings include partial/weak BCL6 and MUM1 expression, with LP cells often encircled by CD3 and PD-1 positive T cells. CD21 and CD23 highlight rare residual follicular dendritic cell meshworks, and the Ki-67 proliferation index is elevated within the atypical population. The original immunohistochemical stains were unavailable for in-house review; however, repeat immunohistochemical staining for *** demonstrates a similar pattern of expression.
CD20, CD3, CD138, PAX5, BCL6, MUM1, CD10, BCL2, c-myc, EBER, CD30, MIB1, CycD1, SOX11, CD34, ALK1

Immunohistochemical studies highlight a diffuse plasma cell infiltrate comprising greater than 90% of the marrow cellularity, with plasma cells showing strong membranous staining for CD138 and diffuse expression of MUM1, BOB1, and OCT2. CD43 also highlights the plasma cell population. Light-chain evaluation, including Kappa/Lambda-ISH and Kappa/Lambda immunostains on both the core biopsy and clot section, and a combined kappa/lambda stain, demonstrates weak and non-restrictive signaling, without a clear kappa- or lambda-restricted population. BCL1 is positive in neoplastic cells. CD20, CD19, and CD79a highlight rare reactive B-cells. CD56 highlights a subset of T-cells, while CD3 highlights scattered reactive T-cells. CD45 highlights appropriate background lymphocytes. CD34 and CD117 are negative for increased blasts, with CD117 also highlighting scattered background erythroid precursors and mast cells, and E-cadherin highlighting background erythroid precursors. CD1a, TdT, NKX3.1, and AE3/1 are negative. EBER, ALK, and HHV8 are negative. The proliferation index by MIB1 is approximately 40%. Special stain for Congo Red is negative for amyloid deposition.

Histologic evaluation of the needle core biopsy demonstrates a diffuse effacement of the normal nodal architecture by a monotonous population of small, mature lymphocytes. Subtle pale proliferation centers are identified. Immunohistochemical studies show the neoplastic cells are positive for CD20, CD5, CD23, and PAX5, with LEF1 expression accentuated within the proliferation centers. The cells are negative for CD10, BCL1, and SOX11. CD3 highlights a background population of reactive T cells. Ki-67 proliferation index is low, averaging approximately 5–10%. Concurrent flow cytometry demonstrates a kappa-restricted CD5-positive B-cell population. Taken together, the morphologic, immunophenotypic, and flow cytometric findings support involvement by chronic lymphocytic leukemia / small lymphocytic lymphoma (CLL/SLL).

Examination of the peripheral blood smear reveals a marked leukocytosis with numerous atypical lymphocytes, some of which showing circumferential cytoplasmic projections. The bone marrow aspirate is markedly hemodilute and paucicellular, limiting morphologic evaluation. However, the bone marrow core biopsy is markedly hypercellular for age (approximately 90%) and demonstrates a diffuse infiltration by atypical B-cells, replacing normal marrow elements and resulting in decreased trilineage hematopoiesis. Immunohistochemical studies show that the atypical cells are diffusely positive for CD20, PAX5, BRAF, and BCL1 (variable). CD3 highlights background T-lymphocytes. CD34 does not identify an increased blast population and CD71 highlights appropriate erythroid elements. A reticulin stain reveals mild reticulin fibrosis (MF-1). An iron stain performed on the aspirate is limited in interpretation due to lack of marrow particles. Taken together, the morphologic, immunophenotypic, and molecular findings are consistent with hairy cell leukemia.
Bone marrow, posterior iliac crest, core biopsy, clot section, aspirate, peripheral blood:

Examination of the peripheral blood smear demonstrates pancytopenia. The bone marrow aspirate is relatively paucicellular and hemodilute, limiting morphologic assessment. The core biopsy is markedly hypercellular (>90%) and shows a prominent lymphoid infiltrate involving approximately 50% of the marrow space. The infiltrate is composed of small mature lymphocytes that are positive for PAX5 and negative for BCL1. CD3 highlights background reactive T cells, CD34 does not demonstrate an increase in blasts, and an iron stain does not show increased iron stores. A reticulin stain reveals moderate fibrosis (MF-2). By report, flow cytometry identifies a monoclonal B-cell population (12.1%) expressing CD5, CD19, CD20 (dim), CD22, CD23 (partial), CD38, FMC7, HLA-DR, and kappa light chain. FISH studies show an IGH (14q32) gene rearrangement and are negative for CCND1/IGH t(11;14), BCL2/IGH t(14;18), 13q deletion, trisomy 12, 11q deletion, ATM, and TP53 alterations. Taken together, the morphologic, immunophenotypic, and cytogenetic findings support involvement of the bone marrow by a low-grade B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma, most consistent with chronic lymphocytic leukemia/small lymphocytic lymphoma (CLL/SLL).
Left posterior iliac crest, bone marrow aspirate, clot section, and core biopsy:

Histologic evaluation of the lymph node (NS25-003948) shows an enlarged node with surrounding fibroadipose tissue and a thin fibrous capsule. The nodal architecture is preserved with variably sized follicles and mild to moderate paracortical hyperplasia. The paracortex contains increased epithelioid histiocytes and Langerhans cells, some with intracytoplasmic pigment. No large atypical cells or Hodgkin Reed-Sternberg–like cells are identified. Immunohistochemical stains demonstrate a reactive pattern. CD20 highlights B-lymphocytes predominantly within follicles, while CD3 and CD5 highlight T-lymphocytes in the paracortical and interfollicular regions. CD10 dimly highlights germinal center cells, and BCL2 is appropriately negative within germinal centers while positive in mantle zones and background T-cells. CD68 highlights an increased histiocyte population. CD23 highlights overall intact follicular dendritic networks. CD30 highlights scattered immunoblasts, and CD15 highlights scattered granulocytes. Ki-67 shows an appropriately high proliferation index in germinal centers and low activity in the interfollicular areas. Pancytokeratin and SOX10 are negative. Overall, these findings are consistent with dermatopathic lymphadenitis. By report, there is no flow cytometric or immunophenotypic evidence of lymphomatous involvement.

Examination of the left posterior iliac crest specimen (NS25-000070) reveals a peripheral smear showing a normocytic, normochromic anemia with a slight left shift. The bone marrow aspirate is adequate and demonstrates rare erythroid dysplastic changes, including nuclear contour irregularities, nuclear-cytoplasmic asynchrony, and occasional budding forms. The core biopsy is slightly hypercellular for age (approximately 50%) with trilineage hematopoiesis. Immunohistochemical stains show no increase in blasts by CD34 or CD117. CD20 and CD3 appropriately highlight background B- and T-lymphocyte populations, respectively. Reticulin staining demonstrates minimal fibrosis (MF-0). An iron stain shows decreased iron stores without ring sideroblasts. By report, flow cytometry shows no immunophenotypic evidence of lymphoma or acute leukemia, and cytogenetic studies demonstrate a normal female karyotype. No additional FISH or molecular studies were performed. Taken together, the findings are consistent with a mildly hypercellular bone marrow with trilineage hematopoiesis and no evidence of a clonal hematolymphoid neoplasm.

The lymph node is well-encapsulated, with normal architecture distorted by a granulomatous inflammatory infiltrate. The granulomata are non-necrotizing and composed of epithelioid histiocytes with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. Immunohistochemical stains for CD20 and CD3 demonstrate background B and T lymphocytes, respectively. Special stains for acid-fast bacilli (AFB) and fungi (GMS) are negative for microorganisms, with appropriate positive controls.

Histologic evaluation of parts A and B demonstrates unremarkable nasopharyngeal mucosa with underlying adnexal structures showing mild edema and reactive changes. A small lymphoid infiltrate is present, composed of multiple primary (resting) follicles with small mature lymphocytes and without well-formed germinal centers. Immunohistochemical studies highlight admixed B-cells and T-cells with CD20 and CD3, respectively. BCL2 and PAX5 show appropriate expression within the primary follicles. BCL6 and CD10 are negative within follicles and stain scattered background B-cells. Cyclin D1 highlights scant background B-cells, and SOX11 is negative. Ki-67 demonstrates a low proliferative index. Kappa and lambda in situ hybridization reveals a scant polytypic plasma cell population. Congo red stain is negative for amyloid. Flow cytometric analysis performed on part B (see FC25-3504 for further details) shows no abnormal B-cell or T-cell population and no evidence of a clonal process. Taken together, the histologic, immunophenotypic, and flow cytometric findings support a benign reactive lymphoid process.
