Sections show squamous mucosa with a submucosal dense diffuse infiltrate of atypical lymphoid cells completing effacing the architecture. The atypical cells are large with irregular nuclei, vesicular chromatin, scant cytoplasm, and variably prominent central nucleoli. Immunohistochemistry staining showing the lymphoma cells are positive for CD20, Pax5, BCL6, MUM1, CD30 (>80%), C-myc (>90%). Ki-67 proliferation index is positive in over 85% of lymphoma cells. The lymphoma cells are negative for CD10, CD5, CyclinD1, BCL2, and ALK1. EBER highlights scattered small cells in the background.
[or this] 0.3% of all cells analyzed, expressing CD138, CD56 (dim partial), CD20 dim partial, CD38; not expressing CD22

Bone marrow sections show decreased trilineage hematopoiesis replaced by an increased population of atypical cells. These cells are medium in size with irregular nuclear borders and prominent nucleoli present in sheets within the bone marrow. On immunohistochemistry these cells express CD20 and PAX5 (diffusely positive), C-myc, CD10, and BCL6. Negative staining for CD30, CD5, Cyclin D1, BCL2, and EBER. There is a Ki67 proliferation index greater than 95%. CD3 highlights an appropriate T-cell population. These findings are suggestive of a CD10 positive, aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma with a differential of Burkitt Lymphoma or a Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma process. Further testing is warranted. Clinical correlation is recommended.

[plasmacytoma] The biopsy reveals sheets of monomorphic neoplastic plasma cells with increased nuclear size and prominent nucleoli. No atypical lymphocytic infiltrates are identified. Fragments of bone and fibrotic soft tissue with hemorrhage and granulation tissue formation is also noted. The plasma cells are positive for CD138 and CD56 with kappa light chain restriction by kappa/lambda in situ hybridization. The plasma cells are negative for CD20, PAX 5, and BCL2. CD3 stains a few scattered small T-lymphocytes in the background. Ki-67 reveals a high proliferation index of approximately 50%. Congo red stain reveals no evidence of amyloid deposition. The corresponding flow cytometry reveals 45% monotypic, kappa-restricted CD56+ plasma cell population. Overall findings indicate CD56+ plasmacytoma/plasma cell myeloma with kappa light chain restriction, clinically persistent

Thank you for allowing us to review this case for the purpose of continuing patient care. We agree with the diagnosis rendered by the originating pathologists. Only slides from endocervix were submitted for consultation review (A1-A2 and A6-A15). The findings in this specimen show sections of endocervical submucosa that are markedly involved by an atypical nodular lymphoid infiltrate. The morphologic and immunophenotypic findings are suggestive of a reactive atypical lymphoid hyperplasia. There are no features suggestive of aggressive/large cell lymphoma. B-cell IGH, IGK gene rearrangements, and BCL2 FISH studies are currently pending through NeoGenomics. Further clinical correlation is recommended.

Sections of the cervix show unremarkable endocervical and ectocervical mucosa with underlying submucosal involvement by an atypical nodular lymphoid infiltrate. The follicles are relatively monotonous in size and lack polarization or tingible body macrophages. Immunohistochemistry of these follicles reveals small B-cells positive for CD20 and PAX5. The follicles are also positive for BCL6, CD10 (dim), and are negative for BCL2 and MUM1. CD23 highlights an underlying disrupted follicular dendritic cell meshwork. CD3, CD5, and BCL2 highlight background perifollicular small T-cells. CD138, MUM1, and kappa/lambda-ISH highlight rare polytypic plasma cells. Ki-67 displays a patchy staining pattern ranging mostly from 5-10% within follicles, and focally up to 50% within the follicles. Cyclin D1 is negative.

**CONSULTS (case OS24-4043)** Thank you for allowing us to review these cases for the purpose of continuing patient care. We agree with the diagnoses rendered by the originating pathologists. The findings in these biopsies and peripheral blood analysis show involvement by a CD30-positive T-cell lymphoproliferative process. The morphologic and immunophenotypic findings are suggestive of a CD30-positive T-cell lymphoproliferative process with a differential based on a histomorphologic basis that includes primary cutaneous large cell lymphoma, transformed mycosis fungiodes, or peripheral T-cell lymphoma. Molecular studies for T-cell gene rearrangements from a peripheral blood specimen (collected 10/9/2024) were suspicious for clonality. NGS testing performed on peripheral blood (collected 10/23/2024) revealed the following: CHEK2 splice site variant and TET2 early terminating variants. These genetic aberrancies can be seen in the development of certain T-cell lymphomas. Further clinical correlation is recommended.

Sections from 24UB:IS-3819 and S24-064293 demonstrate unremarkable squamous mucosa with a diffuse proliferation of atypical lymphocytes effacing underlying architecture. The atypical cells are medium-sized with irregular nuclear contours and moderately condensed chromatin.

Immunohistochemistry performed on 24UB:IS-3819, collected 09/22/2024, demonstrate the atypical cells are positive for CD2, CD3, CD4 (patchy), CD5, and TCR-beta. There is equivocal expression of CD30 due to poor internal control, favor dim positive. The atypical cells are negative for BCL2, BCL6, CD7, CD8, CD10, CXCL2, ICOS, PD1, EBER, and TCR-delta. Ki-67 shows a high proliferation index of above 90%.

Immunohistochemistry performed on S24-064293, collected 09/16/2024 demonstrate the atypical cells are positive for CD30 and CD5. The atypical cells are negative for CD20, BCL2, BCl6, CD21, CD23, Kappa/Lambda, CyclinD1, CD4, and CD8. Additionally reported but not provided for review was immunohistochemistry performed at Michigan Medicine confirming atypical cells that are positive for CD2, CD5, CD3, and TCR beta F1; and negative for CD8 (with equivocal CD4 expression), EBER, and have complete loss of CD7.

(3 H&E, 1 Trichrome, 1 PAS, 1 PAS/D, 1 Iron, 1 PanCK): Sections show core liver tissue composed of predominately viable and few injured hepatocytes, with  marked giant cell transformation. The portal tracts shows  a bile ductular reaction as evidenced by pancytokeratin and PAS staining. There is abundant hepatocytic and canalicular cholestasis with areas showing bile duct plugs. There is also mild tochronic portal inflammation.  No PAS diastase resistant accumulations of alpha-1 antitrypsin are seen.  A trichrome staining shows fibrous expansion of the portal areas with some septa formation. Iron stain highlights mild hepatocytic iron accumulation, favored to represent a reactive change.  Additionally, there are focal areas show mild neutrophilic inflammation with microabscess formation. CMV and adenovirus special stains are ***.

(3 H&E, 1 Trichrome, 1 PAS, 1 PAS/D): Sections show liver tissue including 6 portal tracts represented in multiple levels, sufficient for evaluation. The lobular architecture is preserved, showing normal portal structures and central veins. The bile ducts in two portal tracts exhibit mild injury with ductular proliferation, as highlighted by both the trichrome and PAS stains. The portal tracts show no significant inflammation or fibrous expansion, and no interface inflammation is seen. The lobular parenchyma shows mild disarray, without inflammation, but there is ballooning degeneration, with prominent reactive changes, including multinucleation and nuclear enlargement along with frequently glycogenated nuclei. No viral cytopathic changes, or cholestasis is seen. Mild large droplet steatosis is present, with a more extensive component of microvesicular steatosis (involving 60% of the biopsy). No fibrosis is highlighted by the trichrome stain. Specific PAS-positive, diastase-resistant intracytoplasmic inclusions associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin disease are not recognized.

(3 H&E, 1 Trichrome, 1 PAS, 1 PAS/D): Sections show liver tissue including 27 portal tracts represented in multiple levels, sufficient for evaluation. The lobular architecture is preserved, though the majority of portal tracts (20/27) show expansion by a mixed inflammatory infiltrate composed mostly of lymphocytes with few eosinophils and scattered plasma cells.  The infiltrate spills into the interface parenchyma with early pseudoacinar transformation and hepatocellular damage, characterized by scattered necrotic hepatocytes.  All of the portal tracts show at least mild bile duct injury and ductular proliferation is seen in about half of the portal tracts, but there is no ductopenia.  5 of the portal tracts, all medium-sized) show periductal concentric fibrosis with edema and mixed inflammation with inflammatory cell infiltration of the duct epithelium, consistent with primary sclerosing cholangitis.  There is also lobular inflammation, sometimes accentuated around the central veins, which is mixed, and consists of neutrophils, eosinophils, lymphocytes (predominant), and plasma cells.  There is increased lipofuscin accumulation within Kupffer cells in these regions and there are scattered individual necrotic hepatocytes.  The trichrome stain highlights portal fibrous expansion with early bridging septa and shows increased pericentral perisinusoidal fibrosis, mild, aligning with the observed pattern of inflammation.  There is no hepatocellular ballooning degeneration, viral cytopathic changes, cholestasis, or steatosis. Specific PAS-positive, diastase-resistant intracytoplasmic inclusions associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin disease are not recognized.

(3 H&E, 1 Trichrome, 1 PAS, 1 PAS/D): Sections show liver tissue including at least 22 portal tracts represented in multiple levels, sufficient for evaluation. The lobular architecture is generally preserved, showing intact portal structures and central veins.  All portal tracts show at least mild to moderate fibroinflammatory expansion (highlighted with a trichrome stain), composed predominantly of lymphocytes with occasional plasma cells eosinophils and neutrophils.  There is extensive interface activity and bile duct injury, with ductular proliferation in about half of the portal tracts, but no ductopenia is appreciated with the cytokeratin stain.  Concentric periductal fibrosis and edema are prominent in the large portal tracts (4/22).  The lobular parenchyma shows scattered acidophil bodies/necrotic hepatocytes and reactive changes, with multinucleation, nuclear enlargement and ballooning degeneration near the portal interface.  No viral cytopathic changes, cholestasis, or steatosis are appreciated.  There is occasional lymphocytic lobular inflammation without cohesive lymphoid aggregates.  There is patchy pericentral lymphocytic inflammation.  The trichrome stain highlights the periductal fibrosis and the portal fibrous expansion, showing bridging between multiple portal zones (Ishak stage 3/6).  Specific PAS-positive, diastase-resistant intracytoplasmic inclusions associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin disease are not recognized.All controls show appropriate reactivity.

(3 H&E, 1 Trichrome, 1 PAS, 1 PAS/D): Sections show liver tissue including 6 portal tracts represented in multiple levels, sufficient for evaluation. The lobular architecture is preserved, showing normal portal structures and central veins. Macrovesicular and microvesicular steatosis involves approximately 10% of the hepatic parenchyma. The bile ducts are free of injury and inflammation, as highlighted by both the trichrome and PAS stains. The portal tracts show no inflammation or fibrous expansion, and no interface inflammation is seen. The lobular parenchyma shows normal architecture, without inflammation, ballooning degeneration, viral cytopathic changes, or cholestasis. No fibrosis is highlighted by the trichrome stain. Specific PAS-positive, diastase-resistant intracytoplasmic inclusions associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin disease are not recognized on PAS-D staining.

(3 H&E, 1 Trichrome, 1 PAS, 1 PAS/D): Sections show liver tissue including at least 15 portal tracts represented in multiple levels, sufficient for evaluation. The lobular architecture is preserved, showing portal structures and central veins. The bile ducts are free of injury and inflammation, as highlighted by both the trichrome and PAS stains. The portal tracts show only patchy mild chronic inflammation, and no interface inflammation is seen. The lobular parenchyma shows normal architecture, without viral cytopathic changes or cholestasis. Few ballooned hepatocytes are seen as are binucleate and glycogenated nuclei. Minimal lobular inflammation is present, and patchy macro and microvesicular steatosis are seen estimated at 15%. Trichrome staining shows mild fibrous expansion of portal areas with septa formation and focal areas suspicious for bridging. Specific PAS-positive, diastase-resistant intracytoplasmic inclusions associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin disease are not recognized.

(3 H&E, 1 Trichrome, 1 PAS, 1 PAS/D): Sections show liver tissue including 7 portal tracts represented in multiple levels, sufficient for evaluation. The lobular architecture is preserved, showing normal portal structures and central veins. The bile ducts or interface inflammation is seen. The lobular parenchyma shows diffuse sinusoidal dilatation without inflammation, ballooning degeneration, viral cytopathic changes, cholestasis, or steatosis. Focal bridging fibrosis and patchy sinusoidal fibrosis is highlighted by the trichrome stain. Mild degree of iron deposition is seen with an iron stain. Specific PAS-positive, diastase-resistant intracytoplasmic inclusions associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin disease are not recognized. All controls are appropriate.

(3 H&E, 1 trichrome, 1 PAS, 1 PAS/D, 1 iron): Sections show liver tissue with 11 portal tracts represented across multiple levels, sufficient for evaluation. The lobular architecture is preserved with unremarkable portal structures and central veins. Bile ducts are intact without injury or inflammation, highlighted by trichrome and PAS stains. Portal tracts show focal minimal chronic inflammation with focal interface activity and no fibrous expansion. The lobular parenchyma is largely unremarkable, without significant inflammation, ballooning degeneration, viral cytopathic effect, or steatosis. There is a single focus of necroinflammation. Mild cholestasis and sinusoidal dilation are present. Trichrome stain highlights mild sinusoidal fibrosis. PAS/PAS-D stains show no diastase-resistant intracytoplasmic inclusions to suggest alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. Iron stain shows no increased iron deposition.

(3 H&E, 1 Trichrome, 1 PAS, 1 PAS/D): Sections show liver tissue including 10 portal tracts represented in multiple levels, sufficient for evaluation. The lobular architecture is distorted by prominent expansion of half of the portal areas (5/10) by a mixed inflammatory infiltrate composed predominantly of lymphocytes and plasma cells, with few neutrophils. EBER staining is negative. The trichrome and PAS stains highlight extensive fibrosis in these expanded portal areas, along with bile duct and ductular proliferation and bile duct damage and inflammation. There are occasional clusters of entrapped hepatocytes with prominent ballooning degeneration in these areas. Occasional lymphoid aggregates are observed. Multifocal interface hepatitis is observed at the periphery of these expanded portal tracts with focal pseudorosette formation. No significant hepatocellular necrosis is seen. A pancytokeratin stain highlights the duct proliferation and ductular reaction, and no ductopenia is appreciated. Apart from the interface areas, the lobular parenchyma shows relatively normal architecture, without lobular inflammation, ballooning degeneration, viral cytopathic changes, cholestasis, or steatosis. No pale eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions are seen. The central veins show no pathologic change. Specific PAS-positive, diastase-resistant intracytoplasmic inclusions associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin disease are not recognized.

(3 H&E, 1 Trichrome, 1 PAS, 1 PAS/D): Sections show liver tissue including at least 13 portal tracts represented in multiple levels, sufficient for evaluation. The lobular architecture is markedly disrupted by a diffuse inflammatory process resulting in marked portal expansion, bridging fibrosis and inflammation surrounding residual nodules of hepatic parenchyma. The inflammatory infiltrate is composed predominantly of lymphocytes with abundant plasma cells and few neutrophils and eosinophils. There is extensive bile duct injury with prominent ductular reaction, highlighted by a pan cytokeratin immunohistochemical stain, and marked interface hepatitis. The residual parenchyma shows severe reactive changes, with multinucleation, giant cell formation, prominent cholestasis and ballooning degeneration. Occasional canalicular bile plugs are seen. There are scattered necrotic hepatocytes, without confluent necrosis. No viral cytopathic changes or steatosis is observed. Trichrome staining highlights the significant bridging fibrosis, occasionally circumferentially surrounding residual hepatocellular nodules (Ishak stage V/VI). Specific PAS-positive, diastase-resistant intracytoplasmic inclusions associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin disease are not recognized.

(3 H&E, 1 Trichrome, 1 PAS, 1 PAS/D, 1 PanCK): Sections show liver tissue including 22 portal tracts represented in multiple levels, sufficient for evaluation. The portal tracts demonstrate distortion and expansion by a mixed acute and chronic inflammatory infiltrate, with focal interface activity. The bile ducts show focal areas of pericholangitis, as highlighted by both the trichrome and PAS stains. Additionally, the bile ducts show evidence of ductular reaction and proliferation, as highlighted by a pan cytokeratin stain. The portal tracts also show fibrous expansion and mild fibrosis, as highlighted by the trichrome stain. The lobular parenchyma is largely preserved and shows scattered inflammatory cells, with focal hepatocellular ballooning and nuclear glycogen deposition. No viral cytopathic changes, cholestasis, or steatosis are identified. PAS-positive, diastase-resistant intracytoplasmic globules characteristic of alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency are not seen. *** An EBER stain is negative. ***

(3 H&E, 1 Trichrome, 1 PAS, 1 PAS/D): Sections show liver tissue including at least 12 portal tracts represented in multiple levels, sufficient for evaluation. The lobular architecture is preserved, showing portal structures and central veins. The bile ducts are free of injury and inflammation, as highlighted by both the trichrome and PAS stains. The portal tracts show only patchy mild chronic inflammation, and no interface inflammation is seen. The lobular parenchyma shows normal architecture, without viral cytopathic changes,  ballooning degeneration, or steatosis. There is patchy mild cholestasis present. No lobular inflammation is noted. There is mild patchy sinusoidal dilation with scattered hemorrhage distributed in an azonal pattern. Trichrome staining shows fibrous expansion of some portal tracts, with short fibrous septa, as well as patchy sinusoidal mild fibrosis. Specific PAS-positive, diastase-resistant intracytoplasmic inclusions associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin disease are not recognized.

(3 H&E, 1 Trichrome, 1 PAS, 1 PAS/D, 1 PanCK, 1 C4d, 1 CD163): Sections show liver tissue including at least 16 portal tracts represented in multiple levels, sufficient for evaluation. The lobular architecture is preserved, showing portal structures and central veins. The bile ducts are free of injury and inflammation, as highlighted by both the trichrome and PAS stains. The portal tracts show mild to moderate chronic inflammation with lymphocytes and occasional interface inflammation seen in approximately 6 out of 16 portal tracts. There is minimal bile ductular reaction, as highlighted by pancytokeratin stain. The lobular parenchyma shows normal architecture, without viral cytopathic changes, ballooning degeneration, or steatosis. There is minimal cholestasis as well as minimal sinusoidal dilation. Minimal lobular inflammation is present. Trichrome staining shows mild fibrous expansion of portal areas with septa formation and focal periportal bridging. Endotheliitis is present in some portal tracts. Specific PAS-positive, diastase-resistant intracytoplasmic inclusions associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin disease are not recognized. C4d does not significantly highlight any portal vasculature. CD163 highlights patches of intraparenchymal macrophages.
A. Chronic active AMR Banff 2016 Definition (meets 4/4 of required criteria).
B. Acute/Active AMR Banff 2016 AMR scoring criteria (h-score: 1 + C4d score: 2).

(3 H&E, 1 Trichrome, 1 PAS, 1 PAS/D, 1 PanCK, 1 Iron, 1 CMV, 1 Adenovirus, 1 C4d,1 1 CD163, EBV-EBER ISH): Sections show liver tissue including 6 portal tracts represented in multiple levels, suboptimal for evaluation and highlighted by pancytokeratin stain. The lobular architecture is preserved, showing normal portal structures and central veins. The bile ducts demonstrate rare bile duct injury without significant inflammation, as highlighted by both the trichrome and PAS stains. The portal tracts show mild to moderate inflammation with lymphocytes and rare eosinophils without significant fibrous expansion, and no interface inflammation is seen. One portal tract demonstrates a thickened sclerotic artery as well as cells with foamy cytoplasm. There is minimal bile ductular reaction, as highlighted by pancytokeratin stain. The lobular parenchyma shows normal architecture. There is patchy lobular inflammation consisting of small microabscesses of lymphocytes and neutrophils. There is mild/minimal cholestasis and minimal steatosis. There is no ballooning degeneration or viral cytopathic changes. Periportal fibrosis with fibrous septa and bridging and perivenular fibrosis with bridging are observed and highlighted by the trichrome stain. Endotheliitis is present in the portal tracts and central vein. The central veins are damaged and surrounded by extravasated red blood cells and an inflammatory infiltrate consisting of lymphocytes, plasma cells, histiocytes, and rare eosinophils. Specific PAS-positive, diastase-resistant intracytoplasmic inclusions associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin disease are not recognized. Iron stain demonstrates minimal iron deposition. CMV and adenovirus stains are negative. C4d highlights > 50% circumferential deposition within the portal vasculature in 2 of 6 portal tracts (1 staining a portal artery). CD163 highlights a are intravascular macrophage. An EBV-EBER ISH is negative.

[normal liver] Part B (1 H&E): Sections show hepatic parenchyma with preserved lobular architecture, including portal tracts and central veins. Portal tracts contain unremarkable bile ducts, hepatic arteries, and portal veins without significant inflammation. Hepatocyte plates are 1–2 cells thick with no significant steatosis, ballooning degeneration, cholestasis, or cytologic atypia. Sinusoids are patent without congestion, and no significant fibrosis is identified.

Part C (11 H&E): Sections show hepatoblastoma with mixed epithelial and mesenchymal components. The epithelial component demonstrates fetal and embryonal patterns. The fetal pattern shows hepatocytes with distinct cell membranes, uniform, polyhedral, slightly high nuclear/cytoplasmic ratio, some with cleared out cytoplasm, inconspicuous nucleoli and similar or slightly smaller size than those of normal hepatocytes. The tumor cells with embryonal pattern display rosettes with immature appearance, discohesive small cells with poorly defined cell borders, basophilic cytoplasm, high N:C ratio, prominent nucleoli,and coarse chromatin. Mitotic activity is low. The mesenchymal component shows fibrous and osseous differentiation. The fibrous component is composed predominantly of mature fibrous tissue with bland spindle cells. The osseous component consists of viable woven and remodeled bone with scant associated marrow material. There is focal capsular contour distortion/bulging in areas of tumor involvement; however, the liver capsule remains intact overall. Focal fibrous and hemorrhagic capsular adhesions are also present. Focal areas of fibrosis and hemosiderin deposition are present throughout tumor, suggestive of treatment effect/prior chemotherapy. Resection margins appear free of tumor involvement. The gallbladder shows unremarkable mucosa with no significant histopathologic abnormality. [Beta catenin, glypican 3 and glutamine synthetase immunostains show variable staining in both subtypes.]

(3 H&E, 1 Trichrome, 1 PAS, 1 PAS/D, Cytokeratin) Sections show liver tissue with architectural distortion characterized by bridging fibrous septa and regenerative parenchymal nodules. There is prominent bile duct proliferation and ductular reaction within fibrous septa. Central veins are not identified in the submitted material. The bile ducts are free of inflammation. The lobular parenchyma shows mild cholestasis and is otherwise without significant inflammation, ballooning degeneration, steatosis, or viral cytopathic changes. Portal tracts show no significant inflammation or interface activity. Immunohistochemical staining for cytokeratin highlights bile duct proliferation. Severe fibrosis is highlighted by trichrome stain. PAS stain is negative. PAS-positive, diastase-resistant intracytoplasmic inclusions suggestive of alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency are not identified.

(9 H&E, 1 Trichrome, 1 PAS, 1 PAS Diastase, 1 Pan CK, 1 reticulin): Sections reveal heterogenous and regionally distinct hepatic parenchyma. In one area, particularly in the peripheral aspects of the liver, the normal hepatic lobular architecture is preserved showing portal tracts and central veins. In this area, the portal tracts are relatively devoid of bile ducts as supported by pancytokeratin staining and PAS staining. However, scattered larger portal tracts contain bile ductular elements. There is minimal chronic portal inflammation. The lobules are similarly devoid of inflammation and show no significant steatosis, cholestasis, ballooning, or necrosis. Reticulin staining shows an intact hepatic trabecular network. Further, in this area, which includes subcapsular regions, there is substantial fibrosis including abundant portal portal bridging with rare portal central bridging and nodule formation as supported by trichrome staining. PAS diastase shows no alpha-1 particles.

Immediately adjacent to the previously described regions and more centrally within the liver, there is a relatively notable demarcation between the previously described hepatic parenchyma, and a region with notably more steatosis, which includes both macro and microvesicular steatosis most prominently around zone 3, but affecting zones 2 and 1. In this area, the portal tracts also almost all contain bile ductular reaction/proliferation as supported by pancytokeratin stain. The steatosis in this area is measured at proximately 80% by PAS stain. Trichrome stain shows less fibrosis in this area and shows only rare portal portal bridging. Reticulin shows a preserved trabecular network in this area as well. No histologic evidence of neoplasm or malignancy is identified. The gallbladder is poorly preserved with abundant cautery artifact but shows no histologic abnormality.
A (1 H&E): Sections show spleen with congested red pulp showing spherocytes and occasional hemosiderin-laden macrophages.
B. (1 H&E): Sections show normal spleen parenchyma composed of red and white pulp with periarterial lymphoid sheaths.

(1 H&E) Sections show hair-bearing skin with a subjacent hypodermal cyst lined by stratified squamous epithelium and filled with keratinaceous debris surrounded by a rim of foreign body type giant cells. No intramural adnexal structures are seen

(10 H&E): Sections reveal a proliferation of atypical squamous epithelial cells, extending the full-thickness of the epidermis and invading into the superficial dermis in independent epithelial islands. Atypical cells exhibit patchy nuclear hyperchromasia, pleomorphism, and scattered mitotic figures. Associated with invasive atypical cells is a predominantly chronic inflammatory cell infiltrate consisting of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and eosinophils. Focally (cassette A4), the deep margin is involved by tumor. Lymphovascular invasion is not identified. Background skin exhibits acanthotic squamous mucosa.

Sections show a vascular lesion with back-to-back vessels, irregular lumens of varying calibers (highlighted by CD31) and varying amounts of smooth muscle in the walls, consistent with abnormal veins. Many areas show adjacent congested thin-walled venous channels with an alveolar-like architecture and hemosiderin-laden macrophages. The abnormal vessels focally extend to the inked margin. Multiple lymphoid aggregates are scattered throughout the lesion. Focal areas of abnormally lymphatic channels (highlighted by D2-40) are present. The abnormal vasculature is surrounded by variable amounts of fibrosis, intercalated adipose tissue, and atrophic skeletal muscle fibers. No cytologic or architectural endothelial atypia is seen.

A (2 H&E), B (1H&E), C (1H&E):  Sections show bursal fibroadipose tissue extensively involved by acute suppurative inflammation with abundant fibrin and necrotic debris. There are associated areas of granulation tissue formation, hemorrhage, and fibrosis. Scattered basophilic bacterial debris is identified within the inflammatory exudate. No atypia is identified. The three provided parts show similar findings

Tissue Gram stain highlights focal gram-positive cocci. Please note that light microscopy is relatively insensitive for detection and characterization of microorganisms, and organisms seen on tissue stains may represent true infection, colonization, or contamination. No concurrent microbiologic cultures are available for correlation. Clinical correlation and follow-up are recommended.

(3 H&E, serial levels, decal): Sections reveal fragmented cores of viable trabecular bone with mild remodeling changes. Intraosseous spaces contain scattered marrow elements, patchy edema, and focally increased neutrophilic inflammation. The acute inflammatory cells abut adjacent osseous structures, which show occasionally mottled surfaces and focal osseous destruction. No definitive microorganisms are identified.

Comment: Overall histologic findings support the diagnosis of acute osteomyelitis. Correlation with the concurrent microbiology specimen (26A-013M0147) is recommended, which is polymerase chain reaction (PCR) positive for methicillin-susceptible Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) and shows rare polymorphonuclear leukocytes on culture.

A and B. (2 H&E, decal): Both specimens show similar features. The sections demonstrate predominately viable bone with mild to moderate remodeling changes. Intraosseous spaces contain sparse marrow elements and edema, largely replaced by an increased neutrophilic inflammation. The acute inflammatory cells abut adjacent osseous structures, which show occasionally mottled surfaces and focal osseous destruction. No definitive microorganisms are identified.

Overall histologic findings support the diagnosis of acute osteomyelitis in both specimen. Correlation with the concurrent microbiology specimens (26A-034M0142 and 26A-034M0143) is recommended, which are both polymerase chain reaction (PCR) positive for Staphylococcus aureus (SA) and shows gram positive cocci in pairs and groups on culture. Additionally noted, microbiology specimens for the ankle aspirates (26A-034M0140 for the left, and 26A-034M0141 for the right) are negative at the time of this report.

(1 H&E):  The pathologic process is that of a proliferation of swollen keratinocytes arranged in lobules within the superficial dermis. The cells demonstrate viral cytopathic changes in characteristic "Henderson Patterson body" inclusions. There is surrounding chronic lymphocytic inflammation and surface parakeratosis and crust.

Sections show fibrous tissue with proliferation of benign spindled cells with wire-like collagen fibrils (wavy serpentine nuclei and pointed ends. S-100 is positive in the spindled cells, and CD34 highlights a background lattice-like network. No atypia is seen. All controls show appropriate reactivity.

Sections show fibroadipose tissue with areas of dense collagen deposition as well as regions of more loosely arranged, pale collagenous stroma, consistent with reactive stromal changes. CD168 immunohistochemical staining highlights background macrophages, further supporting a reactive process. No cytologic atypia is identified.

Microscopic examination shows a fairly well-circumscribed, unencapsulated, cellular spindle cell neoplasm composed of bland, plump spindle cells arranged in a fascicular to storiform growth pattern within a variably myxoid and collagenous stroma. The tumor cells have eosinophilic cytoplasm and uniform nuclei without significant cytologic atypia. Scattered osteoclast-like giant cells and extravasated erythrocytes are present. Immunohistochemical stains show the spindle cells are diffusely positive for SMA and negative for MyoD1, myogenin, S100, and CD34. CD163 highlights scattered histiocytes. Overall, the morphologic and immunophenotypic findings support the diagnosis. All controls show appropriate reactivity.

(2 frozen sections, 2 touch preparations, 4 H&E): Permanent sections confirm the intraoperative diagnosis.  Sections reveal core biopsies of fibrovascular soft tissue with extensive involvement by a moderately pleomorphic, predominantly epithelioid cell population with prominent pink cytoplasm, round-to-ovoid-to-irregular nuclei, and occasionally prominent nucleoli.  Scattered binucleated and multinucleated cells are identified.  Malignant osteoid production is focally observed, adjacent to regions of calcification.  Mitotic activity is readily identified (up to 40 mitoses per 10 high-power field).  Scattered foci of tumor cell necrosis are identified.

(1 H+E): Sections show a nodular tumor composed of aggregates of pale, eosinophilic, anucleate "shadow cells" intermixed with basophilic matrical cells. There is associated calcification and foreign body granulomatous inflammation.
(1 H+E): Sections show bony trabeculae with a parallel formation at the periphery with normal trilineage hematopoiesis. Centrally, the bony trabeculae are arranged haphazardly or perpendicularly.
Comment: The sections show a dermal cyst lined by stratified squamous epithelium with attached sebaceous gland and hair follicle. The lumen contains loose keratin flakes and scattered hair shafts.
Comment: Microscopic exam reveals a dermal cyst lined by stratified squamous epithelium. Lamellated keratinous material is present in the cyst lumen.

(1 H+E): Sections show skin and underlying soft tissue containing dermal fascicles of thickened, focally intensely eosinophilic, ropey collagen, with loss of skin adnexal structures, surrounded by a reactive proliferation of spindled fibroblasts.

(2 H+E): Sections show epidermal hyperplasia and papillomatosis with an underlying proliferation of benign, disordered sebaceous glands in the superficial dermis, some of which open directly to the epidermal surface. Hyperplasia of eccrine glands is not seen. There is associated mild chronic inflammation.
Secondary to extensive treatment effect and necrosis, and after extensive sampling ***, there is minimal to no viable tumor for evaluation.

Extensive immunohistochemical studies were performed on the prior biopsy (SA25-05263) which demonstrated diffuse nuclear expression of SS18-SSX, TLE1, and Cyclin D1 in tumor cells, with patchy, nonspecific positivity for EMA and BCOR. CD99 shows blush cytoplasmic staining in the majority of tumor cells. Retained nuclear expression of INI1 and H3K27me3 in tumor cells was present. Negative markers included pancytokeratin, desmin, MyoD1, myogenin, NKX2.2, SOX10, synaptophysin, chromogranin A, ERG (highlighting vasculature only), pan-TRK, CD43 (highlighting background lymphocytes), SMA (highlighting background vasculature), SATB2, and DUX4.
See microscopic description, synoptic report, and comment.
The histologic findings are identical to the prior biopsy (SA25-5375), except that necrosis is much more extensive in the resection, accounting for the increase in FNCLCC grade from 2 to 3.

Extensive testing on the prior biopsy showed weak or patchy immunohistochemical expression for CD99 (nonmembranous), SATB2, ERG, BCOR, NKX2.2 and MYC, but no strong staining for any marker was observed. Negative markers include MyoD1, myogenin, pancytokeratin, CD31, S100, SOX10, CD68, CD163, DUX4.
Sections are of ulcerated skin with underlying granulation tissue and chronic inflammation.
Sections show a skin-covered, polypoid portion of soft tissue with underlying fibroadipose

(1 H&E): Sections show unremarkable epidermis overlying dense fibroconnective and adipose tissue with a tract extending into the deep soft tissues. The tract is associated with areas of atrophic skeletal muscle fibers. No acute inflammation, atypia, or malignancy is identified.

(1 H&E): Sections show fragments of respiratory-type epithelium lined by ciliated columnar cells overlying stroma with areas of fibrosis and chronic lymphoplasmacytic inflammatory infiltrate. There is underlying cavity formation filled with abundant mucoid material admixed with inflammatory debris and histiocytes. No epithelial dysplasia or malignancy is identified.

(1 H&E) Sections show keratin debris associated with keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium with a lymphoplasmacytic inflammation in the underlying bland fibrovascular connective tissue and blood.

(1 H&E) Sections show keratin debris associated with keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium with a minimal lymphoplasmacytic inflammation in the underlying bland fibrovascular connective tissue and blood. Additionally there are some foreign body giant cells present adjacent to the keratin debris.

(1 H&E): Sections show skin and underlying soft tissue containing a cystic structure lined by stratified squamous epithelium and containing keratin debris. Adjacent to the cyst and within the underlying soft tissue are areas of chronic inflammation and foreign body giant cell reaction, consistent with prior rupture.

(2 H&E, 1 Glut1, 1 CD31) Sections show fibroadipose tissue containing a lobular proliferation of capillaries within intervening delicate fibrous septae which contain focal larger-caliber vessels. Dilated capillaries within the lesion show a focally plump hobnailing endothelium, consistent with early involution. Hemorrhage of the surrounding tissue is noted, involving some cores more than others. Vascular endothelium is diffusely highlighted by a CD31 immunostain; a Glut1 immunostain highlights patchy endothelial cells as well as red blood cells. No thrombosis or significant inflammation is identified.

(1 H+E): Sections show a lobular proliferation of capillaries lined by cytologically bland endothelial cells surrounded by an epithelial collarette, with focal surface ulceration. The lobules are separated by bands of loose connective tissue.

(1 H&E): Sections show skin with a deep sinus tract containing keratinous debris and associated inflamed subcutaneous fibroadipose tissue characterized by mixed perivascular inflammation, granulation tissue, and abscess formation.

(1 H&E, 1 S100): Sections show predominately dense fibrosis with associated fibroadipose and nerve bundles. At the central aspect of the fibrous tissue there are small bundles of irregular nerve roots which show positivity with S100 immunohistochemical staining.
(1 H&E) Sections show fragments of a cystic structure without an epithelial lining with a fibrovascular soft tissue wall without significant inflammation.
3. Moderate interstitial inflammation with chronic tubulitis.

(3 H&E, 2 PAS, 1 Jones silver impregnation, 1 trichrome): Multiple H&E levels are examined. Sections contain renal cortex and medulla with 31 glomeruli available for evaluation. No global or segmental glomerulosclerosis is identified. In the majority of glomeruli (~80%), there is mesangial expansion with increased mesangial cellularity, with scattered intraglomerular neutrophils. Focal lobular accentuation is noted, Approximately half of the glomeruli demonstrate patent, thin capillary loops, highlighted on PAS and Jones stains. No necrosis or crescent formation is seen. Double contours are not appreciated. The tubules in places are separated by moderate interstitial inflammation, composed predominantly of lymphocytes and eosinophils and edema. Frequent tubules demonstrate marked cytoplasmic vacuolization. Rare tubulitis is seen. No tubular atrophy is identified. The interstitium shows minimal fibrosis, highlighted by a trichrome stain.  The vasculature is unremarkable, without evidence of vasculitis.

(3 H&E, 2 PAS, 1 Jones silver impregnation, 1 trichrome): Multiple H&E levels are examined. Sections contain renal cortex and medulla with 31 glomeruli available for evaluation. No global or segmental glomerulosclerosis is identified. In the majority of glomeruli (~80%), there is mesangial expansion with increased mesangial cellularity, with scattered intraglomerular neutrophils. Focal areas have thrombotic microangiopathy present within glomerular tufts. Most glomeruli demonstrate patent, thin capillary loops, highlighted on PAS and Jones stains. No necrosis or crescent formation is seen. The tubules are back-to-back and show no significant epithelial injury or tubular basement membrane thickening. No tubular atrophy is identified. The interstitium shows minimal fibrosis, highlighted by trichrome. Medullary rays show moderate interstitial inflammation, composed predominantly of lymphocytes and eosinophils. Scattered tubules demonstrate cytoplasmic vacuolization, a finding that can be seen in drug-related tubular injury but can be non-specific. The vasculature is unremarkable, without evidence of vasculitis.

(3 H&E, 2 PAS, 1 Jones silver impregnation, 1 trichrome) Multiple H&E levels are examined. Sections contain renal cortex and medulla with 20 glomeruli available for evaluation. No global or segmental glomerulosclerosis is identified. In a subset of glomeruli (7/20; ~35%), there is mild mesangial expansion with increased mesangial cellularity; and within some of these glomeruli (5/20; ~25%), scattered intraglomerular neutrophils are present. The glomerular capillary loops are patent and thin, highlighted by PAS and Jones stains. No necrosis or crescent formation is identified. The tubules are back-to-back and show no significant epithelial injury or tubular basement membrane thickening. No tubular atrophy is present. The interstitium shows negligible fibrosis, highlighted by trichrome stain. Medullary rays are unremarkable. The vasculature is unremarkable, with no evidence of vasculitis.

(3 H+E, 2 PAS, 1 Silver Impregnation (Jones), 1 Trichrome): Multiple H+E stained levels are examined. Permanent sections confirm the intraoperative assessment. Sections show the presence of renal cortex and medulla.  28 glomeruli are present for evaluation.  Six are globally sclerotic, two appear to be segmentally sclerotic.  The mesangial cellularity appears mildly increased.  No areas of necrosis are seen. One glomerulus appears to have cellular crescent formation. The capillary loops are open and thin, as highlighted by the PAS and Jones silver stains.  The tubules are back-to-back, without significant inflammation or basement membrane thickening.  No notable tubular atrophy is seen.  Interstitial fibrosis is mild, as highlighted by the trichrome stain. There is focal and mild interstitial inflammation seen.  The vasculature is unremarkable, without evidence of vasculitis. Fragments of skeletal muscle present.

(3 H+E, 2 PAS, 1 Silver Impregnation (Jones), 1 Trichrome): Permanent sections confirm the intraoperative assessment. Multiple H+E stained levels are examined. Sections show the presence of renal cortex and medulla.  29 glomeruli are present for evaluation. Two are globally sclerotic and one has segmental sclerosis. The mesangial matrix and cellularity appears expanded, with some involved focally by acute inflammation. Four glomeruli have crescentic cellular sclerosis. No areas of necrosis are seen.  The capillary loops show some rare findings of occlusion of the capillaries in some glomeruli as well as rare spike-and-dome features identified in capillary loop walls , as highlighted by the PAS and Jones silver stains.  Intraluminal microthrombi are seen in scattered capillary loops. The tubules are back-to-back, without significant inflammation or basement membrane thickening.  There area focal areas of tubular epithelial damage and mild to moderate tubular atrophy is seen. Interstitial fibrosis is mild and patchy, as highlighted by the trichrome stain.  Interstitial inflammation is not increased.  The vasculature is unremarkable, without evidence of vasculitis.
Fibrinoid necrosis/karyorrhexis:	Absent, score 0
Interstitial inflammation:	<20%, score 1
Interstitial fibrosis:	10-25%, score 1

(3 H+E, 2 PAS, 1 Silver Impregnation (Jones), 1 Trichrome): Permanent sections confirm the intraoperative assessment. Multiple H+E stained levels are examined. Sections show the presence of renal cortex and medulla. Six glomeruli are present for evaluation.  One is globally sclerotic, and one is segmentally sclerotic.  The mesangial matrix and mesangial cellularity are expanded.  No areas of necrosis or crescent formation are seen.  The capillary loops are open and thin, as highlighted by the PAS and Jones silver stains. The tubules are closely packed with focal patchy interstitial lymphocytic inflammation, with minimal associated tubulitis. No significant tubular atrophy or basement membrane thickening is identified. Interstitial fibrosis is minimal, as highlighted by the trichrome stain. The vasculature is unremarkable without evidence of vasculitis. Fragments of benign skeletal muscle are present.

(3 H+E, 2 PAS, 1 Silver Impregnation (Jones), 1 Trichrome): Multiple H+E stained levels are examined. Sections show the presence of renal cortex and medulla.  27 glomeruli are present for evaluation.  The majority of glomeruli show markedle prominent mesangial and/or endocapillary cellularity (E1). Within a subset of glomeruli, there are scattered segmental neutrophils. The majority of glomeruli additionally show epithelial reactive changes and proliferation with crescent formation (at least 2/3 of glomeruli have epithelial crescents; C2). Few glomeruli show increased mesangial collagen (S1), but globally sclerosed glomeruli are not identified. No tubular atrophy is seen.  Interstitial fibrosis is mild, as highlighted by the trichrome stain, involving <25% of parenchyma (T0).  Mixed acute and chronic interstitial inflammation is present. The vasculature is unremarkable, without evidence of vasculitis.

(5 H+E, 1 Trichrome, 2 Immunostains -- 1 C4d, 1 CD68): Serial sections show 5 pieces of endomyocardium, all of which are predominantly composed of myocardium, sufficient for evaluation. Two small foci of inflammation with associated myocyte damage are seen. The trichrome stain highlights the endocardium but interstitial fibrosis is not seen. Histologic features of antibody-mediated damage are not identified. The CD63 immunostain highlights normal interstitial histiocytes [***and rare intravascular histiocytes (<10%)], without evidence of endothelial disruption. The C4d immunostain is negative.

(5 H+E, 1 Trichrome, 1 C4d, 1 CD68): Serial sections show 5 fragments of endomyocardium, composed predominantly of myocardium and adequate for evaluation. One small focus of inflammatory infiltrate with associated myocyte injury is identified (best seen in A9), possibly in a subendocardial/perivascular distribution, though this relationship is difficult to definitively establish in the current sample. The infiltrate is predominantly T-cell rich (CD3 positive) with a minute B-cell component (CD20 positive). CD138 highlights no plasma cells. The remaining myocardium shows mild myocyte hypertrophy and interstitial edema. Trichrome highlights the endocardium and shows mild interstitial fibrosis. No histologic features of antibody-mediated injury are identified. CD68 highlights scattered interstitial histiocytes without evidence of endothelial disruption, and C4d is negative.

MILD - (5 H+E, 1 Trichrome, 1 C4d, 1 CD68): Serial sections show 5 fragments of endomyocardium, composed predominantly of myocardium and adequate for evaluation. One small focus of inflammatory infiltrate with associated myocyte injury is identified (best seen in A3). Trichrome highlights the endocardium and shows no significant interstitial fibrosis***. No histologic features of antibody-mediated injury are identified. CD68 highlights scattered interstitial histiocytes without evidence of endothelial disruption, and C4d is negative.

(5 H+E, 1 Trichrome, 1 C4d, 1 CD68): Serial step sections show 6 pieces of endomyocardium, all of which are predominantly composed of myocardium, sufficient for evaluation. There is no inflammation or myocyte damage. The trichrome stain highlights the endocardium but fibrosis is not seen. Histologic features of antibody-mediated damage are not identified. The CD68 stain highlights normal interstitial histiocytes, without endothelial disruption. The C4d stain is negative.

(1 H+E): Sections show intact gallbladder mucosa with deep-seated glands consistent with Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses, focal smooth muscle hypertrophy [as well as pyloric gland metaplasia], and mild submucosal chronic inflammation.

(1 H&E): Sections show gallbladder wall with edema and hemorrhage. Additionally, there are areas with deep-seated glands consistent with Rokitansky–Aschoff sinuses, focal smooth muscle hypertrophy, and pyloric gland metaplasia. The lamina propria/submucosa shows mild chronic inflammation.
Perforated acute appendicitis with gangrenous necrosis.

(1 H&E) Sections demonstrate marked transmural acute inflammation with areas of necrosis, consistent with gangrenous appendicitis. Focal mural disruption consistent with perforation and associated acute serositis are also present.

(1 H&E): Sections show transmural acute inflammation characterized by dense neutrophilic infiltrates extending from the mucosa through the muscularis propria into the serosa, with focal areas of wall disruption consistent with perforation. The serosal surface is covered by fibrinopurulent exudate and acute inflammatory cells, consistent with serositis. Associated fecal material and hair debris is also noted within the lumen.

(1 H&E): Sections demonstrate acute inflammation with neutrophilic infiltrates extending from the mucosa into the muscularis propria. The serosal surface also exhibits sparse acute inflammatory cells, consistent with serositis.

Part A (9 H&E) Sections show small intestinal and colonic mucosa with areas of ulceration and prominent active inflammation. In some areas, the inflammatory process extends transmurally with associated granulation tissue and fibrinopurulent serositis, consistent with perforation. The ileocolonic anastomotic site demonstrates ulcerated mucosa with active ileitis/colitis and polypoid granulation tissue / inflammatory polyp formation. Sections of mesenteric soft tissue demonstrate prominent acute (neutrophilic) serositis. Proximal and distal margins are viable, however, the distal margin shows associated serositis. No dysplasia or malignancy is identified.

Part A (7 H&E): Sections show small bowel with prominent ischemic changes involving both segment #1 and segment #2. In segment #1, one margin is viable and shows unremarkable small bowel mucosa without significant inflammation or hemorrhage. The opposing margin shows ischemic injury with partially preserved mucosa, superficial epithelial sloughing, and prominent underlying hemorrhage and congestion. The remaining sections of segment #1 show similar ischemic features. In segment #2, one margin is partially preserved with intact submucosa, but shows ischemic-type mucosal injury including superficial mucosal atrophy with mild submucosal hemorrhage/congestion and prominent reactive lymphoid follicles. The opposing margin shows similar partial preservation, but with more pronounced submucosal hemorrhage/congestion and more marked mucosal atrophy. The remaining sections of segment #2 show similar findings.

A.(7 H&E): At least 70 tissue levels are available for evaluation, revealing rectum with ganglion cells arranged in complete neural units in the submucosal plexuses in both portions of tissue. Hypertrophic nerves are not identified, and no eosinophilic infiltrate is seen. No mucosal abnormality is identified.
(1 H&E): Sections show enterocutaneous tissue with congestion, prominent lymphoid follicles, and fibrosis, consistent with reactive changes.
Accelerated villous maturation

Features of fetal vascular malperfusion, high-grade, mixed global and segmental patterns (numerous stem villi with intramural fibrin deposition, single stem villus with obliterated vasculature and associated large cluster of avascular villi, numerous intermediate-caliber villi with occlusive calcification of villous vasculature, and scattered avascular villi); see comment 1

(5 H+E) The fetal membranes show no inflammation and normal maternal decidual blood vessels; scattered fine pigment-laden macrophages are present within the amnion. The three vessel umbilical cord contains no inflammation or thrombus. The placental disc shows an intact fetal surface with normal fetal surface vessels and no acute inflammation. A focus of subchorionic thrombus material demonstrates numerous entrapped hemosiderin-laden macrophages. The placental villi are small for gestational age, with an increased number of syncytial knots. Villi demonstrate a normal number of fetal vessels and show no inflammation. Numerous stem villi demonstrate large-caliber fetal vessels with intramural fibrin deposition. Many intermediate-caliber terminal villi demonstrate occlusive calcification within fetal vessels (scattered across several slides). A single stem villus in A5 demonstrates obliteration of vasculature, with a large swath of associated avascular villi. Scattered additional avascular villi are present on multiple slides. The intervillous space contains maternal blood without intervillositis, as well as copious fibrinoid material and parenchymal calcifications. The maternal surface shows decidualized endometrial stroma with no inflammation and appropriately adapted maternal vessels. Bands of smooth muscle fibers adhere to the decidua, with decidua intervening between muscle fibers and placental villi.
Placental disc with patchy delayed villous maturation, and scattered intermediate villi with obliterative fetal vessel calcifications (consistent with remote thrombi)

(5 H+E): The fetal membranes show prominent muscularization of maternal vascular walls in the decidua. No acute chorioamniotic inflammation is present. The two vessel umbilical cord contains no inflammation or thrombus. The placental disc shows a fetal surface with normal fetal surface vessels and no acute inflammation. The placental villi show mixed villous maturation, with some appearing mature and others appearing large for gestational age with decreased syncytial knots. Villi show a normal number of fetal vessels. A single villus shows inflammatory changes; no additional foci are identified. Numerous stem villi demonstrate obliterative calcification of vascular lumens. However, no significant villous avascular or karyorrhectic changes are seen. The intervillous space contains maternal blood without intervillositis. The maternal surface shows decidualized endometrial stroma with no plasmacytic inflammation, and appropriately adapted maternal vessels. Bands of smooth muscle fibers adhere to the decidua, without decidua intervening between muscle fibers and placental villi (A2).

(5 H+E): The fetal membranes show no inflammation and normal maternal decidual blood vessels. The two-vessel umbilical cord contains no inflammation or thrombus. The placental disc shows intact fetal surface with normal fetal surface vessels and no acute inflammation. The placental villi show accelerated development for gestational age with normal fetal vessels and no inflammation. The intervillous space contains maternal blood without intervillositis. The maternal surface shows decidualized endometrial stroma with no inflammation and appropriately adapted maternal vessels.

(5 H+E): The fetal membranes show no inflammation and normal maternal decidual blood vessels. The three-vessel umbilical cord contains no inflammation or thrombus. The placental disc shows intact fetal surface with normal fetal surface vessels and no acute inflammation. The placental villi are appropriately developed for gestational age with syncytial knots and scattered occasional avascular villi and scattered fibrin deposits but otherwise normal fetal vessels without inflammation. The intervillous space contains maternal blood without intervillositis. The maternal surface shows decidualized endometrial stroma with no inflammation and appropriately adapted maternal vessels.

(5 H&E) A1-A5: Twin A component: Sections show fetal membranes with meconium-laden macrophages and no significant acute inflammation. The umbilical cord is a three-vessel, hypercoiled cord with eccentric insertion, without funisitis, vasculitis, or thrombi. The placental disc shows patchy accelerated villous maturation with increased syncytial knotting. In addition, there are villous vascular changes of fetal demise noted, including numerous avascular villi, stromal hyalinization, and increased intervillous/perivillous fibrin deposition. Focal subchorionic hemorrhage is present. Maternal surface sections show focal placental infarcts, up to 0.6 cm.

(5 H&E) A6-A10: Twin B component: Sections show fetal membranes with no significant inflammation. The umbilical cord is a three-vessel, flat cord with marginal insertion, without funisitis, vasculitis, or thrombi. The placental disc shows accelerated villous maturation with prominent syncytial knotting, along with prominent villous vascular changes of fetal demise, including numerous avascular villi with stromal hyalinization, and increased intervillous/perivillous fibrin deposition. Focally, there is a subchorionic thrombus/infarct. Maternal surface sections show no significant pathologic abnormality.

(5 H+E) The fetal membranes show patchy acute inflammation extending into the amnion. Membranes contain normal maternal decidual blood vessels. The three-vessel umbilical cord is unremarkable. There is no thrombus. The chorionic plate and vessels show no inflammation. The placental villi show patchy areas of accelerated villous maturation, but are otherwise appropriately developed for gestational age with normal fetal vessels and no inflammation. The intervillous space contains maternal blood without intervillositis. There is slightly increased perivillous fibrin deposition noted. The maternal surface shows decidualized endometrial stroma with areas of minimal chronic inflammation, and appropriately adapted maternal vessels.

(6 H+E): The fetal membranes show a small focus of neutrophilic inflammation confined to the subchorionic plate, without extension into the chorion. The maternal decidual blood vessels appear unremarkable. The three-vessel, normocoiled umbilical cord contains no inflammation or thrombus and shows no histopathologic abnormality. The placental disc shows an intact fetal surface with normal fetal surface vessels and no acute inflammation. The placental villi demonstrate appropriate maturation for gestational age with normal fetal vessels and no inflammation. The intervillous space contains maternal blood without intervillositis. The maternal surface shows decidualized endometrial stroma with an associated 1.7 cm subchorionic / basal plate thrombus.

(5 H+E): The fetal membranes show a small focal areas of mixed acute and chronic inflammation confined to the subchorionic plate, without extension into the chorion. There are focal areas of hemosiderin laden macrophages within the infiltrate. Additionally, few meconium-laden macrophages are noted. The maternal decidual blood vessels appear unremarkable. The three-vessel umbilical cord contains no inflammation or thrombus and shows no histopathologic abnormality. The placental disc shows an intact fetal surface with normal fetal surface vessels and no acute inflammation. The placental villi demonstrate appropriate maturation for gestational age with normal fetal vessels and no significant inflammation. The intervillous space contains maternal blood without intervillositis. The maternal surface shows decidualized endometrial stroma with associated scattered areas of chronic lymphoplasmacytic inflammation.

(10 H&E): Pathologic examination is limited by the fragmented nature of the specimen, which has been arbitrarily designated as umbilical cord A and umbilical cord B. The fetal membranes demonstrate patchy acute inflammation involving the chorionic mesoderm and focally extending into the amniotic mesoderm. Scattered hemosiderin-laden macrophages are identified within the membranes. Maternal decidual blood vessels within the membranes are unremarkable without evidence of vasculitis or thrombosis. Both umbilical cords contain the three vessels and are unremarkable, showing no signs of inflammation or thrombi. The chorionic plate and its vessels are free of inflammatory infiltrates. Multiple subamniotic hematomas are present beneath the chorionic plate. Placental villi exhibit maturation appropriate for gestational age with well-formed fetal vessels and no inflammatory changes. The intervillous space contains maternal blood but lacks intervillositis. The maternal surface reveals decidualized endometrial stroma with maternal vessels demonstrating normal adaptation.

(5 H&E) A1-A5: Twin A component: Sections demonstrate fetal membranes without significant inflammation. The umbilical cord is three-vessel and hypocoiled, without funisitis, vasculitis, or thrombi. The placental disc exhibits features of accelerated villous maturation characterized by increased syncytial knotting and relative villous size reduction. The intervillous space contains maternal blood without intervillositis. The maternal surface shows decidualized endometrial stroma with no inflammation and appropriately adapted maternal vessels.

(5 H&E) A6-A10: Twin B component: Fetal membranes contain hemosiderin-laden macrophages without significant inflammation. The umbilical cord is two-vessel and hypercoiled without funisitis, vasculitis, or thrombi. The placental disc shows appropriate villous maturation for gestational age without evidence of accelerated or delayed maturation. The maternal surface shows decidualized endometrial stroma with no inflammation and appropriately adapted maternal vessels.

(6 H&E) Sections show cystic mass with various components of squamous epithelium, skin with cutaneous appendages and granulation tissue, glial tissue, adipose tissue, columnar epithelium with goblet cells,  and multiple mucinous epithelial lining and pseudostratified ciliated epithelial lining cysts. No immature components or malignancy is identified.
(1 H&E): Sections show fragments of a simple cyst lined by a single layer of columnar type epithelium. No significant inflammation is present, nor is dysplasia.
(1 H&E): Section demonstrate unremarkable fibroadipose tissue that contains benign breast tissue. Focal areas show apocrine metaplasia. No malignancy is identified.

(10 H&E): Sections show lung parenchyma with numerous variably enlarged and cystically dilated airspaces lined by ciliated respiratory epithelium. Several of these spaces contain intraluminal mucin, as well as surrounding accumulation of mixed inflammatory cells. The background parenchyma is largely unremarkable with focal areas showing dilated, mucus-filled bronchioles. No cytologic atypia or malignancy is identified.

Sections show lung parenchyma with areas of back to back cystically dilated bronchiolar structures lined by ciliated respiratory epithelium. The background parenchyma is largely unremarkable except for dilated and mucus filled bronchioli and alveolar mucostasis ( block A). Focal, peribronchial chronic inflammation is seen. An SMA immunostain highlights thinned muscular wall of the cysts. A CD 31 show appropriately developed alveolar capillary network. A D2-40 stain does not show lymphangiectasia and a trichrome stain is negative for fibrosis. A gram stain is negative. No atypia or malignancy is seen. All controls show appropriate reactivity.

(3 H&E, 1 Trichrome, 1 PAS, 1 PAS/D): Sections show liver tissue including *** portal tracts represented in multiple levels, sufficient for evaluation. The lobular architecture is preserved, showing normal portal structures and central veins. The bile ducts are free of injury and inflammation, as highlighted by both the trichrome and PAS stains. The portal tracts show no inflammation or fibrous expansion, and no interface inflammation is seen. The lobular parenchyma shows normal architecture, without inflammation, ballooning degeneration, viral cytopathic changes, cholestasis, or steatosis. No fibrosis is highlighted by the trichrome stain. Specific PAS-positive, diastase-resistant intracytoplasmic inclusions associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin disease are not recognized.

Electron microscopic examination of this sampling of renal tissue reveals the single glomerulus subjected to study to display no abnormalities at the ultrastructural level of organization. No electron dense deposits are detected within the glomerular basement membranes or mesangial matrix. The glomerular basement membranes appear normal in thickness for patient age. Foot process effacement of the epithelial cell podocytes is minimal.
Light Microscopy:

(3 H+E, 2 PAS, 1 Silver Impregnation (Jones), 1 Trichrome): Multiple H+E stained levels are examined. Sections show the presence of renal cortex and medulla.  *** glomeruli are present for evaluation.  None are globally or segmentally sclerotic.  The mesangial matrix and mesangial cellularity are normal.  No areas of necrosis or crescent formation are seen.  The capillary loops are open and thin, as highlighted by the PAS and Jones silver stains.  The tubules are back-to-back, without significant inflammation, tubular epithelial damage, or basement membrane thickening.  No tubular atrophy is seen.  Interstitial fibrosis is absent, as highlighted by the trichrome stain.  Interstitial inflammation is not increased.  The vasculature is unremarkable, without evidence of vasculitis.
Immunofluorescence Studies:

(1 IgG, 1 IgA, 1 IgM, 1 Complement, 1 Fibrinogen, 1 C1q, 1 Albumin; all controls are appropriate): The tissue includes cortex and medulla with. Immunofluorescent staining is observed for the following antibodies as follows:
Electron Microscopy:
C: No infectious agents are identified by routine H&E stain. Therefore, this likely represents a villitis of unknown etiology, which may recur in subsequent pregnancies.

C: The placenta shows patchy advanced/accelerated villous maturation as well as increased parenchymal fibrin and calcifications for gestational age.  These findings are common in term placentas, but are considered abnormal within preterm placentas, and therefore these findings suggest advanced placental senescence for age.

(Or if you don’t see abruption but they suspect it, write comment that says:” The clinical concern for abruption is noted. Although there is no histologic evidence of acute abruption, this diagnosis is best made clinically “).

1.  The presence of delayed villous maturation, chorangiosis, and increased fetal nucleated red blood cells implies a component of fetal hypoxia. Nucleated fetal red blood cells should be extremely rare in placental circulation after 28 weeks gestational age and their presence indicates in utero stress of indeterminate duration.
Ref: Hecht JL, et al. Classification and reporting guidelines for the pathology diagnosis of placenta accreta spectrum (PAS) disorders: recommendations from an expert panel. 2020 Modern Pathology

This placenta demonstrates small size, prominent accelerated maturation of villi, bleeding and clot at the basal plate with focal evidence of chronicity (hemosiderin-laden macrophages), and multiple parenchymal infarcts, in the setting of muscularization and fibrinoid necrosis of maternal vessels. During normal placental development, implantation site trophoblast should convert muscular arterioles in the basal plate to low-resistance vessels. Persistence of the muscular wall indicates inadequate conversion and may be associated with pre-eclampsia or maternal hypertension, as suggested by this patient’s clinical history. Altogether, these placental findings suggest an underlying problem with maternal perfusion of the placenta, called maternal vascular malperfusion. Common causes include maternal vascular disease, diabetes, chronic hypertension/preeclampsia, thrombophilia, and maternal drug use. While downstream effects for the fetus are variable, worse outcomes are typically associated with larger parenchymal lesions. In this case, the thrombi and infarct encompass a relatively small proportion of parenchyma.

This placenta demonstrates mild findings of fetal vascular malperfusion (FVM), with a minority of parenchymal villi affected by this process (including avascular villi and villi with stromal-vascular karyorrhexis).  Upstream obstruction to fetal blood flow is present, as evidenced by intramural fibrin deposition within large-caliber fetal vessels.  The delayed villous maturation is also often associated with this diagnosis.  The foci of damaged villi are distributed across several parenchymal slides, but involve small clusters of villi (global/partial pattern, low-grade). These changes suggest intermittent restriction in fetal blood flow to the placenta, often caused by umbilical cord pathology. Fetal vascular malperfusion is commonly associated with obstructive umbilical cord lesions or thrombi within large fetal vessels, often due to an "umbilical cord at risk" (long umbilical cord, hypercoiled cord, stricture, velamentous insertion, prolapse or cord entanglements such as nuchal cord).  None of these risk factors were reportedly present at delivery or upon gross examination of this placenta. Fetal coagulopathy or cardiac failure can also present as fetal vascular malperfusion, although the pattern of injury is often different from findings in this case (i.e. segmental pattern FVM). In this case, clinical correlation is required to determine the most likely etiology. The low grade designation of this lesion typically correlates in isolation with benign fetal outcomes; again clinical correlation and followup are recommended.

This placenta demonstrates findings of high-grade fetal vascular malperfusion (FVM), overall affecting less than 5% of parenchyma. The pattern of injury is most consistent with a segmental/complete distribution, including intermediate-caliber stem villi with occlusive vascular calcifications, and 2 large foci (greater than 45 villi affected per focus) of clustered villi with stromal vascular karyorrhexis. Scattered avascular villi are also present in these areas. The delayed villous maturation is also common in FVM. Fetal vascular malperfusion is commonly associated with obstructive umbilical cord lesions or thrombi within large fetal vessels, often due to an "umbilical cord at risk" (long umbilical cord, hypercoiled cord, stricture, velamentous insertion, prolapse or cord entanglements). None of these risk factors were reportedly present at delivery or upon gross examination of this placenta. Of note, the segmental pattern (more than the global/partial pattern) may be associated with fetal coagulopathy including protein C or S deficiencies, factor V Leiden, or MTHFR mutations, or with maternal antiphospholipid or antiplatelet antibodies which cross into fetal circulation. In this case, clinical correlation is required to determine the most likely etiology. The high grade designation of this lesion has been shown to correlate with adverse clinical fetal outcomes, including cerebral palsy and neonatal encephalopathy. However, this placenta demonstrates a relatively low percentage of involved sampled parenchyma. Again clinical correlation and followup are recommended.
gross:
[SOURCE: Cervix LEEP or cone Gross Protocol and Template 041624.docx]
Cervix (LEEP or Cold Knife Cone)

[SOURCE: Cervix LEEP or cone Gross Protocol and Template 041624.docx]
GROSS DESCRIPTION:
Orient the specimen if an orienting stitch is provided (usually designated “stitch at 12:00”) and measure in three dimensions. If no orienting stitch is present, you do NOT need to arbitrarily designate anything as 12:00.
Ink the rim of the endocervical margin blue and the remaining margin (deep/stromal, and ectocervical) black.
When possible, note the size in each dimension; the presence/diameter of an os
Note the presence of absence of a mass or lesion
If a mass or lesion is present, note the size and distance to margins
Make radial (like a pizza) serial sections at 2-3 mm intervals.

[SOURCE: Cervix LEEP or cone Gross Protocol and Template 041624.docx]
Note that these specimens range from well-oriented cervical cones with an identifiable os, ectocervix, and endocervical canal; to a LEEP fragment of tissue with no orientation and no identifiable landmarks. Please tailor the gross description accordingly. If there is an ectocervix/os, provide the diameter(s).

[SOURCE: Cervix LEEP or cone Gross Protocol and Template 041624.docx]
SECTIONS FOR HISTOLOGY:
Submit the entire specimen sequentially into cassettes (no more than 3 per cassette) with the 4 quadrants designated separately.
If a “top hat” (additional endocervix in a separate part) is present submit it separately. Check if the clinician has oriented the top hat, by designating the (true) margin, and if so, preserve the orientation through inking and gross description. If the clinician has not made any designation, no inking is required. Note, for the majority of top hat specimens, clinician input is required for orientation.

[SOURCE: Cervix LEEP or cone Gross Protocol and Template 041624.docx]
SAMPLE DICTATION: “Cervical Cone”
Received in formalin container labeled “[patient's name/ medical record number/"___"]” is a[n] [un]oriented fragment of tissue measuring [__ x __ x __] cm [___ cm ectocervix diameter; cervical wall thickness of ____; ____cm from ecto cervix into endocervical canal] with a stitch designating [12 o'clock]. [The cervical os measures ___ in diameter.] The overlying epithelium is [smooth and glistening without grossly visible lesions]. The endocervical margin is inked [blue] and the remaining margin inked [black]. [No masses or lesions are identified. / A mass measures ___ cm and is ___cm from the deep margin; ____ cm from the ectocervical mucosal margin; and ____cm from the endocervical mucosal margin.]  The specimen is divided into quadrants, serially sectioned and submitted entirely in cassettes as follows:
(A1-A3): 12-3:00
(A4-A6): 3-6:00
(A7-A9): 6-9:00

[SOURCE: Cervix LEEP or cone Gross Protocol and Template 041624.docx]
(A10-A12): 9-12:00

[SOURCE: GI 1&2 Grossing TEMPLATES.docx]
Principle
To describe the grossing procedures and provide templates to be followed and used as a guide in the Gross Room/Frozen Section Room for specimens from the luminal organs of the gastrointestinal tract. This section describes all the procedures that need to be followed to ensure that specimens are prepared, handled, and processed properly.
Scope
This protocol applies to the procedure and dictation for all specimens from the luminal organs of the gastrointestinal tract.
Safety
Scrubs, fluid resistant gowns, gloves, goggles, safety glasses, face shields, masks and/or respirators (optional) are to be always worn when handling specimens and/or requisitions.
Dictating Frozen Sections
Procedure:
Scan case barcode into CoPath and PC Dictate from the requisition.
Dictate the case number, patient name, and MRN.

[SOURCE: GI 1&2 Grossing TEMPLATES.docx]
State you are dictating a frozen (because it is in a different tab for transcription) and then dictate the frozen section diagnosis AS WRITTEN. If a word or phrase is illegible--- ask your co-workers for help deciphering, the frozen resident, or call the attending who signed it out.
Dictating the frozen can be done at the end of the dictation but keep it to one or the other and dictate them for all parts at the same time.
If using Dragon, dictate this in the “Intraop Diagnosis Entry/Edit” screen from the main menu and after clicking “Edit Text” so the word document opens.
Scan the container and dictate the patient’s name, MRN, and designation on the container label as written and if using Dragon switch to the “Histology Entry/Edit” screen.

[SOURCE: GI 1&2 Grossing TEMPLATES.docx]
If multiple containers received similarly can say “Received are 8 fresh containers all entirely submitted for frozen section diagnosis labeled with patient’s name and MRN. Part A designated “designation”. So, the name and MRN are checked on each container, but you don’t have to repeat yourself.
If there is a description written on the side of the container, dictate that as such. If not, look at the specimen in the cassette and describe it. If there are any questions defer to the frozen resident or someone else who can help you figure out what happened during the frozen.
If the tissue was entirely submitted for frozen section diagnosis, scan the container, then the cassette and put in rack.
If additional tissue is needed, print additional cassettes, and submit additional sections for routine histology.

Peritoneum, nodule, biopsy:

[SOURCE: GI 1&2 Grossing TEMPLATES.docx]
