[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
GU Grossing Guide

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Principle:
To describe the procedures to be followed in the Surgical Pathology Laboratory/ Gross Room for Genitourinary Specimens. This section describes all the procedures that need to be followed to ensure that specimens are prepared, handled, and processed properly.
Scope:
This protocol applies to the grossing procedure and dictation for Genitourinary specimens.
Safety:
Scrubs, fluid resistant gowns, gloves, goggles, safety glasses, face shields, masks and/or respirators are to be always worn when handling specimens and/or requisitions.
Dictating Frozen Sections
Procedure:
Scan case barcode into PC Dictate and CoPath.
Dictate the case number, patient name, MRN, and clinical history (if not provided).

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Say you are dictating a frozen (because it is in a different tab for transcription) and then dictate the frozen section diagnosis AS WRITTEN. If a word or phrase is illegible--- ask your co-workers for help deciphering, the frozen resident, or call the attending who signed it out.
This can be done at the end of the dictation but keep it to one or the other and dictate them for all parts at the same time.
If using Dragon, dictate this in the “Intraop Diagnosis Entry/Edit” screen and after clicking “Edit Text” so the word document opens.
Dictate the patient’s name, MRN, and designation on the container label as written.
If there is a description written on the side of the container, dictate that as such.
If the tissue was entirely submitted for frozen section diagnosis, scan the container, then the cassette and put in rack.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
If additional tissue needs to be submitted, print additional cassettes, and submit additional sections for routine histology.
Sample Header:
Ureter, right, resection:

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Dictation Example:
“Received fresh and entirely utilized for frozen section diagnosis is a container labeled “patients name/ MRN/ right ureter” is an unoriented cross section of ureter, 0.7 x 0.3 cm, and the frozen remnant is resubmitted in (FSA1).
Calculus/Calculi
Description:
Kidney and ureter stones are routinely sent for stone analysis and are on the exemption list meaning they can bypass the pathology laboratory unless a report is required/requested by the clinician. If received in the gross room—they are accessioned and are gross only specimens. They require a brief physical count and description along with a picture before being forwarded to the clinical laboratory for stone analysis.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Procedure:
Count the calculi. What is the shape, color, size and consistency of the calculi/calculus?
Take a gross photograph. Ensure they are centered, in focus, zoomed in, and a ruler is in the photograph for scale.
State they’re being forwarded for stone analysis and return the container to the lab assistants who will fill out a miscellaneous test request (in black book of misc. forms) and send to the clinical lab for analysis.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Sections for Histology:
The specimen is for gross examination only. No stones are ever submitted for routine histology.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Header Example:
Stone, right ureter, removal:

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Dictation Example:
Received without fixative in container labeled “patient name/ MRN/ kidney stone” is a brown, multi-faceted, hard calculus, without adherent soft tissue, 0.3 cm in diameter. A gross photograph is taken and the specimen is forwarded for stone analysis. Gross only.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Vas Deferens (sterilization)
Description:
Vas deferens for sterilization need to be confirmed under the microscope to ensure the procedure was a success. Inking the periphery black aids in orientation of the small tissue so that it is embedded on end and the lumen is visible.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Procedure:
Describe and measure (length x diameter)
Ink the outside black and if longer than 0.4 cm then bisect.
Submit entire cross section(s)

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Sections for Histology:
The entire cross section needs to be on the slide to confirm sterilization. Often these can be either submitted entirely or bisected and submit entirely.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Header Example:
Vas deferens, right, sterilization:

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Dictation Example:
Labeled "L vas deferens" is a segment of tan-white vas deferens measuring 0.7 cm in length and 0.2 cm in diameter. The specimen is inked black and bisected then submitted entirely in (A1).
Penis
Description:
Penile tumors are often advanced at time of receipt in the surgical pathology lab largely due to the sensitivity of its location. It is important to note the relationships between the tumor and surrounding tissue layers and structures for accurate staging. Small tumors may be fixed for a couple of hours prior to grossing, but larger ones may be best to hold overnight largely based on the friability and nature of the tumor and relationships to surrounding structures.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Procedure:
Triage upon receipt to include measurements, any suture designations or orientation, and ink margins for orientation preservation and/or to demonstrate any specific areas of interest. This may vary due to shape, size, presence/absence of structures due to nature of resection so if unsure confirm with PA/pathologist/senior resident.
At time of grossing, describe all lesions and note if there are more than one and the locations of each. The majority will be solitary tumors, but satellites or additional lesions can occur.
Take gross photographs of the outside and the cut surfaces to show depth of invasion.
Take margins as described below.
Section the remaining specimen and describe tumor involvement of all structures including subepithelial connective tissue, Dartos muscle, Buck’s fascia, corpus spongiosum, urethra, corpora cavernosum, scrotum, prostate, and/or pubic bone.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Submit sections of these relationships
Submit normal tissue if possible.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Sections for Histology:
Urethral and corpora spongiosum margin, en face
Corpora cavernosum margin, left and right, en face
Closest skin margins, left and right
Vascular margins, en face
Tumor to urethra
Tumor involvement of corpora cavernosum, with greatest depth of tumor invasion
Additional representative tumor at 1/cm intervals
Tumor to urethral meatus
Uninvolved corpora cavernosum
Additional representative skin

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Header Example:
Penis, (radical/partial) penectomy:

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Dictation Example:
Received in formalin in a container labeled "patients name/MRN" and designated "____" is a radical penectomy specimen, __ x __ x __ cm, that includes the glans penis, __ x __ x __ cm, and shaft of penis, __ x __ x __ cm with/without foreskin. The resection margin is inked Right = Green, Left = Blue.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
The ulcerating lesion is __ cm to the closest skin and soft tissue margin, and __ cm from both the right and left corpora cavernosum margins. Surrounding the proximal resection margin is a moderate amount of hair bearing, presumed scrotal skin.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Cut surfaces demonstrate an infiltrative tan-white mass, deep to the skin surface lesion, invading into the corpora cavernosum and abutting but not grossly involving the urethra. The corpora cavernosum involvement is __ cm from the resection margin. Further sectioning reveals no gross lymphovascular involvement. The uninvolved corpus cavernosum are tan-pink, spongy, and unremarkable. The urethra is pink-red with focally heaped and striated mucosa. Gross photographs are taken, and representative sections are submitted as follows:

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
(A1) Urethral and corpora spongiosum margin, en face
(A2) Right corpora cavernosum margin, en face
(A3) Left corpora cavernosum margin, en face
(A4) Closest right and left skin margins, en face
(A5) Right and left sutured vascular margins, en face
(A6) Tumor with closest urethra, right
(A7) Tumor to closest urethra, left
(A8) Tumor involvement of right corpora cavernosum, with greatest depth of tumor invasion
(A9) Tumor invasion of right and left corpora cavernosum
(A10-A12) Additional representative tumor
(A13) Tumor to urethral meatus
(A14) Uninvolved corpora cavernosum
(A15) Additional representative urethra
Testicle- Tumor
Description:

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Small testicle tumors should be submitted entirely, so long as they can be submitted in ten cassettes or less. Larger tumors can be submitted using the 1 section per cm of tumor to include the tumor relationship to normal testis, tunica albuginea, and relationships to surrounding structures as described below for adequate staging.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Procedure:
Weigh the total specimen
Measure the spermatic cord (length and diameter)
Measure the testicle and epididymis (together)
Ink the outside of the specimen (tunica vaginalis) and bivalve
Pin overnight for fixation if appropriate
Describe the inside of the testicle and epididymis noting any lesions or abnormalities
Note if tumor is limited to testis or there is invasion into the hilar soft tissue, epididymis, tunica albuginea, spermatic cord, or into the scrotum
Note the stringiness (or lack thereof) of the testicle parenchyma? What structures are you looking at?

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Sections for Histology:
Spermatic cord margin, en face
Spermatic cord relationship to testicle/tumor
Epididymis to lesion/testicle
Lesion involvement of tunica vaginalis and albuginea
Lesion to testicle parenchyma 1/cm
Rete testis to tumor

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Header Example:
Testicle, left, radical orchiectomy:

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Dictation Example:
Received is a formalin container labeled "patient name/MRN" and designated "left testicle and cord" containing a __g testicle, __ x __ x __ cm with attached distal spermatic cord, __ x __ cm, and intact tunica vaginalis. The outer surface is inked blue. Cut surfaces demonstrate an ill-defined, invasive, yellow-red-white, variegated induration, ___ x ___ x ___ cm, that extends into the spermatic cord ___ cm from the margin, obliterates the involved tunica albuginea and abuts the tunica vaginalis without evidence through the vaginalis. The lesion also obliterates the epididymal tail in the involved distal third, extends into the testicle with 50-60% involvement. The remaining testicular parenchyma is stringy and without additional lesion. The tumor shows chalky, yellowish discoloration suggestive of necrosis in ~5% of its total volume.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Additionally, between the tunica albuginea and vaginalis is a yellow, transparent, serous fluid. Gross photographs are taken, and representative sections are submitted as follows:
(A1) Spermatic cord margin, en face
(A2) Spermatic cord involvement to blue-inked margin
(A3-A5) Epididymal involvement and involvement of vaginalis to lesion
(A6-A9) Lesion
(A10) Testicular component of lesion
Testicle- Castration
Description:
Testicles are often submitted for torsion and/or castration. Castration can be a part of a gender affirmation procedure or prostate cancer for hormone therapy in cases of metastatic cancer. A basic gross description and sampling is sufficient for documentation and processing.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Procedure:
Weigh the total specimen
Measure the spermatic cord (length and diameter)
Measure the testicle and epididymis (together)
Ink the outside of the specimen and bivalve
Describe the inside of the testicle and epididymis noting any lesions or abnormalities.
Note the stringiness (or lack thereof) of the testicle parenchyma? What structures are you looking at?

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Sections for Histology:
Spermatic cord margin, en face
Representative testis and epididymis

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Header Example:
Testicle, left, castration:

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Dictation Example:
Received are two formalin containers both labeled "patients name/ MRN".
A) Designated "right testicle and cord" consists of a __g orchiectomy specimen composed of a testicle, __ x __ x __ cm, with an attached __ cm in length x __ cm in diameter spermatic cord. The intact tunica vaginalis is pink purple, mildly ragged and dull. The specimen is inked black and sectioned to reveal grossly unremarkable, tan-brown, stringy testicular parenchyma with an adjacent unremarkable tubular epididymis. No distinct masses or lesions are grossly identified. Representative sections are submitted as follows:
(A1) Spermatic cord margin, en face
(A2) Representative testicle and epididymis

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
B) Designated "left testicle and cord" consists of a __g orchiectomy specimen composed of a testicle, __ x __ x __ cm, with an attached spermatic cord, __ cm in length x __ cm in diameter. The intact tunica vaginalis is pink-purple, mildly ragged and dull. The specimen is inked blue and sectioned to reveal grossly unremarkable, tan-brown, stringy testicular parenchyma with an adjacent unremarkable tubular epididymis. No distinct masses or lesions are grossly identified. Representative sections are submitted as follows:
(B1) Spermatic cord margin, en face
(B2) Representative testicle and epididymis

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Foreskin- Circumcision (Benign)
Description:
Circumcision specimens are often benign even in adults and may be a result of phimosis. The specimen should be examined for possible cutaneous infection or lesion even if not the primary reason for the procedure. If no lesions are identified, representative sections are sufficient for processing.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Procedure:
Determine if specimen is oriented or unoriented and why procedure was performed
Measure in 3 dimensions (can do L x W and excised to maximum depth of __ cm)
Describe the skin surface including any lesions
Serially section and submit one or two pieces in 1 cassette or more to include any lesions

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Sections for Histology:
Representative sections to include any described lesions
If no lesions- one to two pieces in on cassette is sufficient or if serially sectioned and all fits in 1 cassette ok to submit entirely

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Header Example:
Foreskin, glans penis, circumcision:

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Dictation Example:
Received in a formalin container labeled "patients name/ MRN" and "designation" is an unoriented brown-grey, wrinkled, and hair bearing skin, __ x __ x _ cm. The skin surface has no discrete lesions. The resection margin is inked blue and representative sections are submitted in (A1).
Foreskin- Resection (Lesion)
Description:
Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common lesion for circumcision in adults. An in-situ lesion will need to be entirely submitted to rule out an invasive component. Margins, both peripherally and deep, are important to ensure the lesion was entirely excised. These specimens may or may not be oriented by the surgeon, but if they are, the orientation will need to be preserved throughout processing.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Procedure:
Determine if specimen is oriented or unoriented and why procedure was performed
Measure in 3 dimensions (can do L x W and excised to maximum depth of __ cm)
Describe the skin surface including any lesions
Serially section and submit entirely sequentially and consider annotating gross photograph

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Sections for Histology:
If reasonably sized, submit entirely
If large, demonstrate relationship of lesion to peripheral and deep margins
Consider blocking in entire lesion to rule out invasive component of lesion

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Header Example:
Foreskin, glans penis, excision:

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Dictation Example:
Received in a formalin container labeled "patients name/ MRN" and "designation" is an unoriented  brown-grey, wrinkled, and hair bearing skin, __ x __ x _ cm, with/without orienting sutures. There is a ___ suture designating ___ and a ____ suture designating ____.  The specimen is inked as follows:  The skin surface is remarkable for a roughened, tan, exophytic lesion, __ x __ cm, which is __ cm to the closest ___ margin. A gross photograph is taken. The specimen is serially sectioned and sequentially submitted as follows:
(A1) 12:00 end, perpendicularly sectioned
(A2-A4) central cross sections
(A5) 6:00 end, perpendicularly sectioned

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Ureterectomy
Description:
In situ lesions can be focal or multifocal and often not obvious even to the trained grosser. The ureter is entirely submitted to examine the mucosa along the length of the specimen and rule out any multifocal lesions and/or invasion. Lesions such as these are often seen in patients with a history of smoking.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Procedure:
The outer roughened surface of the ureter specimen is a true margin and needs to be inked prior to examination.
The margins are taken and submitted for examination.
The remaining specimen is cut longitudinally so the mucosa is exposed for examination.
Care is taken to ensure the mucosa is not unnecessarily disturbed or rubbed due to agitation.
Once all lesions are documented and measured to applicable margins, the specimen is serially sectioned from one end to the other and sequentially submitted.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Sections for Histology:
Margins (orientation maintained if provided)
Sequentially sectioned central cross sections. There can be multiple per cassette if appropriate.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Header Example:
Ureter, left, ureterectomy:

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Dictation Example:
Designated "____" is an oriented ureter with roughened attached fibroadipose along the length of the specimen which is inked ___. There is an orienting suture at one end designating ___. The mucosal surface demonstrates scant hemorrhage near the marked stitched end, but no lesions or masses. A gross photograph is taken. The specimen is serially sectioned with the margin marked by the stitch in (A1) and the remainder of the specimen in (A2-A5).
Kidney- Allograft/Non-function
Description:

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
A small percentage of allograft kidneys fail after transplant or they never function as intended. To make sure this kidney does not become infected, it is removed and sent to the gross room. The vasculature needs to be examined closely for clots along with looking at the parenchymal cut surfaces to try to pinpoint any vascular issue. In addition to clots, patency should also be assessed throughout the vasculature. Any possible reason for allograft failure and/or non-function should be described and sampled for microscopic examination.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Procedure:
Weigh the specimen
Measure the specimen in three dimensions
Describe the outer surface and ink if you feel its appropriate
Note if the vasculature and ureter are open/patent/occluded/non viable at the margins
Open the ureter and describe mucosa.
Bivalve the kidney and describe the parenchyma, vasculature, any lesions
Take gross photographs of any lesions and the surfaces of the kidney parenchyma
Submit sections of the vascular and ureter margins
Submit sections of possible lesions and/or clots
Submit sections of representative kidney

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Sections for Histology:
Vascular and ureter margins
Representative lesion/clot
Representative kidney including interface between lesional and uninvolved kidney

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Header Example:
Kidney, allograft, nephrectomy:

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Dictation Example:
Received in formalin, labeled "patients name/ MRN" and designated "____", is a __ g nephrectomy specimen, __ x __ x __ cm, with stapled hilar resection margins. The outer surface of the specimen is inked black.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
The renal capsule is smooth and intact with scant attached perinephritic fat and brown and congested-appearing fibroadipose tissue at the hilum. The external surface of the kidney appears congested and purple in appearance. The ureter is opened to reveal tan-red to hemorrhagic mucosa with no visible masses or lesions. Cut surfaces demonstrate a hemorrhagic renal pelvis and dusky to pale tan medullary renal parenchyma. There is moderate loss of architecture of the hemorrhagic renal sinus fat which is protruding in between the pyramids of the kidney. One of the hilar vein vessels is sectioned and reveals a blood clot.  Further sectioning of the kidney parenchyma fails to reveal masses or suspicious lesions. Gross photographs are taken, and representative sections are submitted as follows:
(A1) Renal artery, renal vein, and ureter margin
(A2) Potential vascular clot
(A3) Renal pelvis

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
(A4-A5) Superior pole
(A6-A7) Middle pole
(A8-A9) Inferior pole
Kidney- Non-Urothelial Tumor
Description:
Most non urothelial tumors, specifically RCC, are staged and graded based on both size and extent. For the lower stages it is more size, </= 4 cm, 4-7 cm, 7-10cm, and >10cm but all limited to the kidney. For stages 3 and 4 (and subcategories) extension into surrounding vein, branches, perirenal/renal sinus fat, vena cava, and tumor invades beyond Gerota’s fascia and adrenal gland. *If your tumor has the appearance or differential to include Wilm’s tumor, look up the specific synoptic for submission guidelines and staging criteria.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Procedure:
Weigh the specimen
Measure the specimen in three dimensions
Describe the outer surface and ink if you feel it’s appropriate
Note if the vasculature and ureter are open/patent/occluded/non-viable at the margins
Open the ureter if attached and describe mucosa
Bivalve the kidney and describe the parenchyma, urothelium, vasculature, and any lesions
Take gross photographs of any lesions and the surfaces of the kidney parenchyma
Submit sections of the vascular and ureter margins
Submit sections of possible lesions at 1 section/cm to include relationships to surrounding tissues and structures
Submit section of representative kidney

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Sections for Histology:
Vascular and ureter margins
Tumor to Gerota’s fascia
Tumor to hilum
Tumor to kidney parenchyma
Tumor to pelvis
Tumor to capsule
Representative uninvolved kidney

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Header Example:
Kidney, left, nephrectomy:

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Dictation Example:
Received in formalin labeled “patients name/ MRN/ designation” consists of a __ gram, total nephrectomy specimen, __ x __ x __ cm. The external surface is pink-purple, moderately ragged and dull with adherent yellow, lobular adipose tissue. A ureter, __ cm in length x __ cm in diameter, renal artery, __ cm in length x __ cm in diameter, and renal vein, __ cm in length x __ cm in diameter, are present at the hilum and appear patent and unremarkable.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
The specimen is inked black and bivalved demonstrating a multilobulated, tan-pink, homogeneous fleshy mass, __ x __ x __ cm, grossly obliterating approximately __% of the renal parenchyma with prominent protrusion into the minimal intact renal pelvis which is with signs of hydronephrosis in the upper pelvis.  Perirenal extension is grossly identified, and the mass appears to abut but not grossly invade Gerota’s fascia. The mass displays focal areas of opaque, tan-yellow, dusky presumed necrosis occupying approximately __% of the mass surface area. Minimal uninvolved renal parenchyma is grossly identified, which is tan-brown with no grossly discernible normal renal architecture. No adrenal gland is identified. Gross photographs are taken, and representative sections are submitted as follows:

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
(A1) Ureteral and vascular margins, en face
(A2-A3) Renal urothelium involved by tumor
(A4-A5) Tumor abutting Gerota’s fascia
(A6) Tumor with adjacent uninvolved renal parenchyma
(A7) Tumor with adjacent uninvolved vasculature at the hilum
(A8-A10) Additional representative tumor
Kidney (+/- ureter)- Urothelial Tumor
Description:
Urothelial tumors and their variants are staged based primarily the depth of invasion and involvement of surrounding structures. Each tumor needs to be examined and sampled to determine if it invades the subepithelial connective tissue, muscularis, into the peripelvic/periureteric fat, renal parenchyma, or into adjacent organs or perinephric fat.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Procedure:
Weigh the specimen
Measure the specimen in three dimensions
Describe the outer surface and ink if you feel it’s appropriate
Note if the vasculature and ureter are open/patent/occluded/non viable at the margins
Open the ureter and describe mucosa.
Bivalve the kidney and describe the parenchyma, vasculature, any lesions
Take gross photographs of any lesions and the surfaces of the urothelium of the pelvis and ureter
Submit sections of the vascular and ureter margins (noting presence/absence of bladder cuff)
Submit sections of tumor (kidney or ureter) 1 section/cm to include greatest depth of invasion and involvement of surrounding tissues and structures
Submit section of normal or uninvolved kidney

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Sections for Histology:
Vascular and ureter margins
Ureter proximal and distal to lesion
Ureter lesion, entirely and sequentially submitted
Renal pelvis and calices
Tumor to kidney parenchyma
Representative uninvolved kidney

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Header Example:
Kidney, nephroureterectomy:

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Dictation Example:
Received in a formalin container labeled "patients name/ MRN/ designation" and consists of an intact, __ g ureteronephrectomy specimen composed of __ x __ x __ cm kidney with attached ureter, __ cm in length x __ cm in diameter. The kidney is entirely encapsulated by perinephric adipose tissue measuring up to __ cm in thickness and is inked green. No distinct bladder cuff is grossly identified on the ureter. The ureter external surface is entirely inked black. The renal vein and artery are probe patent.
The ureter is opened longitudinally to reveal a circumferential __ cm in length exophytic papillary tan mass, __ x __ x __ cm, __ cm from the ureteral margin and __ cm distal to the renal pelvis.  Sectioning through the ureteral mass reveals no grossly invasive component with a well-defined border separate from the ureteral submucosa.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Cut surfaces demonstrate a distended renal pelvis filled with a copious amount of loose, tan-pink, exophytic, friable tumor, __ x __ x __ cm, originating in the renal caliceal mucosa. Further sectioning reveals that the calices and urothelial collecting system are diffusely involved by tumor but with no definitive invasion into the underlying renal parenchyma. The uninvolved cortical renal parenchyma is pink-brown, rubbery, and unremarkable with a well-defined cortical medullary junction and a cortical thickness of approximately __ cm.  No lymph nodes or adrenal gland are identified within the perinephric adipose tissue. Gross photographs are taken, and representative sections are submitted as:
(A1) Ureter, artery and vein margins, en face
(A2) Distal ureter
(A3) Ureter immediately distal to mass
(A4-A7) Ureteral mass, entirely and sequentially submitted from distal to proximal

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
(A8) Ureter immediate proximal to mass
(A9) Representative proximal ureter adjacent to renal pelvis
(A10-A11) Representative renal pelvis urothelium
(A12-A15) Urothelial mass within the renal calices with candidate parenchymal invasion
(A16-A19) Additional representative tumor within the renal calices
(A20) Atherosclerosis within renal artery
Bladder- Transurethral Resection of Bladder Tumor (TURBT)
Description:
Transurethral resections are most often performed for the removal of superficial bladder tumors. This procedure is minimally invasive and tissue fragments are removed and submitted to the gross room. These types of samples vary in size and entire submissions of these cases could result in upwards of 100 blocks so a formula is used for initial sampling. If cancer or invasion are identified in the initial sampling, the remainder of the specimen may need to be submitted.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Procedure:
Set out specimen to drain formalin from around the tissues. If in the plastic filtering container, the tissues can be kept in there for weighing and subtract 9 grams from the total weight.
Once most of the formalin has been absorbed by chuck or napkin, weigh the specimen.
Submit the first 12 grams in 8-10 cassettes, and 1 additional cassette for each additional 5 grams of tissue chips.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Example: container and tissue chips weigh 84 grams.
84-9 (container) = 75 grams
75 grams – first 12 grams to submit (A1-A10) = 63 grams
63 grams / 5 grams for additional cassette = 12 cassette
Total cassettes submitted = 22

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Sections for Histology:
Use the above formula and submit the appropriate number of blocks of bladder chips. Keep in mind these should nicely fill the bottom of the cassette without stacking as only the bottom will be put onto the slide. Do not overfill!
Make sure if any pieces have a change in color to make sure those get sampled as well.
If your total using the above formula means you will be submitting over twenty blocks—call and confirm with the attending, they want to stop at 20 or submit the entire amount.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Header Example:
Urinary bladder, transurethral resection:

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Dictation Example:
Received in a formalin container labeled "Patient’s Name/MRN" designated "bladder tumor" is a 75 gram aggregate of irregular, pink-tan, rubbery soft tissues, with each fragment up to 0.7 cm in greatest dimension, and approximately 35% of the specimen is submitted in (A1-A22).

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Bladder-cystectomy
Description:
All cystectomies should be inspected on the inferior posterior for the presence/absence of vaginal skin whether it is listed in the specimen description. Often, a small tag is attached to the bladder specimen without mention or gross involvement. Consulting the OP Note for a detailed description of the procedure should give details about whether additional structures were removed. If removed for prolapse or other nonfunctional reasons, care should still be taken for incidental or previously unknown lesions can be found.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Procedure:
The bladder should be triaged and pinned open for fixation prior to grossing. This can be as little as a couple of hours or overnight as appropriate. Due to the friable nature of many urothelial tumors, overnight may lend to the best sections.
Orient the specimen (usually can orient based on peritoneal surface, and urethra and ureter insertion) and ink right and left sides. Typical scheme is Left = Blue, Right = Green but can differ as long as mentioned in the gross.
Shave ureter margins en face and put in different cassettes to maintain orientation.
Shave urethra margin en face
Using scissors, insert into urethra and begin a Y shaped incision, stop when you get to the bladder, and use your finger to feel mucosa for a lesion prior to making cuts in the wall.
Probe ureters and pin to corkboard.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
To gross, describe lesion location and appearance noting depth of invasion as well as relationship to other areas specifically any attached tissues and the ostia of the ureters.
Look at the biopsy results in EMR to determine possible location of scar if no gross lesion is noted.
Look in ureters for additional lesions.
Describe the remaining mucosa and take representative section.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Sections for Histology:
Urethral and ureteral margins
Lesion with greatest depth of invasion
Lesion 1/cm
Lesion to trigone or additional structures
Representative uninvolved bladder
Palpate/section for and submit any lymph nodes

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Orientation:
vas deferens loops posterior to ureters
seminal vesicles are posterior /  inferior
“fat pad” on posterior side when lying flat; main resection is typically anterior side

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Tips for opening:
Identify anterior / posterior; find vas deferentia then probe around for ureters (typically 1 cm from base of VD where it crosses over ureters on posterior side); PAPER CLIP ureters; take all margins then open

Bladder and prostate- radical cystoprostatectomy
Description:
Like with the cystectomy specimens involved, the cystoprostatectomy specimens may be removed for both lesional and nonfunctioning pathologies. No matter the principal problem, every specimen should be examined for possible lesions. These specimens may be removed for either bladder tumors or prostate tumors. Occasionally, they are part of a pelvic exenteration for a variety of primary tumors.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Procedure:
The bladder should be triaged and pinned open for fixation prior to grossing. This can be as little as a couple of hours or overnight as appropriate. Due to the friable nature of many urothelial tumors, overnight may lead to the best sections.
Orient the specimen (usually can orient based on peritoneal surface, prostate, urethra, and ureter insertion) and ink right and left sides. Typical scheme is Left = Blue, Right = Green but can differ as long as mentioned in the gross.
Shave ureter margins en face and put in different cassettes to maintain orientation.
Shave urethra margin (and commonly prostate apex) and perpendicularly section. Submit in right and left cassettes.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Using scissors, insert into urethra and begin a Y shaped incision ANTERIORLY (you should see ureter orifices on posterior wall, I think?), stop when you get to the bladder, and use your finger to feel mucosa for a lesion prior to making cuts in the wall.
Probe ureters and pin to corkboard.
To gross, describe lesion location and appearance noting dept of invasion as well as relationship to other areas specifically any attached tissues and the ostia of the ureters.
Look at the biopsy results if in EMR to determine possible location of scar if no gross lesion is noted.
Look in ureters for additional lesions.
Section through prostate and submit representatives unless additional sampling required.
Submit seminal vesicles and vas deferentia margins as well (can batch based on laterality).
Describe the remaining mucosa and take representative sections.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Palpate/section for and submit any lymph nodes

Bladder prostate junction, left and right
Additional bladder surfaces uninvolved by lesion
Entire prostatic urethra and 2 sections for each lobe (+ any lesions found or biopsied)
+/- 4 cassettes total of mid prostate (2 from each side)

Lymph node- Regional dissection
Description:
Lymph nodes are typically taken for Genitourinary cases for staging purposes. These specimens are largely composed of adipose from a given area with a single to several embedded lymph nodes. All lymph nodes must be examined to rule out metastasis. The remaining adipose should be submitted (up to five (5) cassettes) after palpated for lymph nodes for additional possible lymph node capture.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Procedure:
Measure aggregate of lymph nodes and adipose
Palpate and section to find all lymph nodes and lymph node candidates
If they’re bisected keep both parts together for submission and do not count them as multiple lymph nodes
Submit all lymph nodes noting in the gross how many candidates are present in each block
If bisected it would be “1 lymph node, bisected”
If multiple bisected lymph nodes are in the same block, differentially ink them and note “3 possible lymph nodes, each bisected and differentially inked”

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Sections for Histology:
All lymph node candidates need to be entirely submitted unless grossly positive.
All remaining adipose up to 5 cassettes for possible additional lymph node capture.

The specimen is entirely submitted as follows:
(A1) Two intact candidate lymph nodes
(A2) One bisected candidate lymph node
(A3-A4) Remaining fibroadipose

Spermatocele or Spermatic Cord Lipoma
Description:
Spermatoceles or lipomas of the spermatic cord are often removed for cosmetic purposes and less likely because they are symptomatic. The specimens should be sectioned and thoroughly examined to ensure that no underlying lesion or malignancy is within the specimen. Representative sections are to be taken at 1/cm interval to include the outer surface (capsule).

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Procedure:
Describe outer surface, and integrity of the specimen
Measure in three dimensions
If intact, ink the outside
Serially section perpendicular to the long axis
Describe the cut surface
Sample 1/cm including any area of abnormality of different appearance

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Sections for Histology:
Representative sections (1 per cm) of the outer surface, capsule, and cut surface including any areas that are different in appearance. If >4cm, can put two pieces in one cassette.

Prostate- TUR
Description:
Transurethral resections are most often performed for the removal of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) that commonly affects adult men. This procedure is minimally invasive and tissue fragments are removed and submitted to the gross room. These types of samples vary in size and entire submissions of these cases could result in upwards of 100 blocks so a formula is used for initial sampling. If cancer or something suspicious shows up on the initial blocks, the remainder of the specimen may need to be submitted.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Example: container and tissue chips weighs 84 grams.
84-9 (container) = 75 grams
75 grams – first 12 grams to submit (A1-A10) = 63 grams
60 grams / 5 grams for additional cassette = 12 cassette
Total cassettes submitted = 22

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Sections for Histology:
Use the above formula and submit the appropriate number of blocks of prostate chips. Keep in mind these should nicely fill the bottom of the cassette without stacking as only the bottom will be put onto the slide. Do not overfill!
Make sure if any pieces have a change in color to make sure those get sampled as well.
If your total using the above formula means you will be submitting over twenty blocks—call and confirm with the attending they want to stop at 20 or submit the entire amount.

Prostate- Adenoma
Description:
Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is removed to improve symptoms. While these specimens are largely benign, an occult malignancy can not be excluded. Representative sections are sufficient to include any lesional areas especially if morcellated.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Procedure:
Weigh and measure the specimen overall and confirm orientation. (Edit procedure and gross if no prostate is present and specimen is only adenomatous nodule(s))
Ink the specimen resection margins or for orientation purposes
Serially section the specimen. What does it look like? Describe the cut surfaces including any discrete nodules/masses/abnormalities.
Take an en face margin of the apex and perpendicularly section to capture the urethra margin.
Sample the mid prostate including any nodules or abnormalities including any relationship to the urethra and/or capsule.
Take an en face margin of the base and perpendicularly section to capture the urethra margin.
Sample any vasa deferentia and seminal vesicle margins
Sample any relationship of nodules/abnormalities to the vasa deferentia or seminal vesicles as needed.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Sections for Histology:
If intact, the apex, shaved then perpendicularly sectioned. This should also include the urethra margin. These are easily organized into left and right.
Mid prostate, right, left, anterior and posterior, to include any nodule, firm area, mass or discoloration
Prostate, base, shaved then perpendicularly sectioned. This should also include the urethra margin. These are easily organized into left and right

Pelvic Exenteration
Description:
Pelvic exenterations can be overwhelming to see what organs and tissues are involved. These specimens come in for a variety of primary tumors and they have infiltrated numerous organs in the pelvis being the common thread. There is no set list of what is or is not included and what to same or not. A very general rule of thumb is to measure and describe what is present, the tumor both appearance and where it is going, and margins. If you talk about/describe it, then sample it. This is more often a confirmation of spread rather than an in-depth workup, but by the complexity of the specimen, adequate sections of the lesion are covered in the relationships to each location.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Procedure: **note based on presence of organs make the procedure may vary widely**
These specimens should be opened and triaged. Same day grossing is acceptable but may be open and held overnight for fixation.
Routinely, the bowel, bladder, and uterus are opened to allow for fixation of the internal surfaces.
Ink may be used to preserve orientation and true margins but may be submitted as additional specimens.
After triage and inking, take all identifiable margins prior to serially sectioning the specimen. These may include vagina, urethra, ureters, proximal and distal bowel.
Determine the best plan for sectioning. This could be to follow an organ or section the entire specimen (breadloaf) and assess margins and relationships. This is a specimen that your attending may want to see/discuss so make sure they are contacted. PAs and senior residents are also useful resources.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Due to the nonstandard nature of these complex specimens you may gross it using different methods and submit different sections each time.

[SOURCE: GU Specimens COMPLETE.docx]
Sections for Histology: **note based on what is attached this list may vary widely**
Urethra margin, en face
Ureter margin, right and left, en face
Mass to vaginal margin, perpendicular
Remainder of vagina and vaginal margin with mass, serially sectioned
Mass with greatest depth of invasion, perpendicular
Mass to cervix, perpendicular, bisected
Representative bladder to include non-tumor and tumor relationships
Representative uterus, fallopian tubes, ovaries if attached

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
HNE Grossing Guide
Principle:
To describe the procedures to be followed in the Cutting Room/Frozen Section Rooms of Head and Neck, and Endocrine organs. This section describes all the procedures that need to be followed to ensure that specimens are prepared, handled, and disposed of properly.

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
Scope
This protocol applies to the procedure and dictation for Head and Neck, and Endocrine specimens.

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
Safety
Scrubs, fluid resistant gowns, gloves, goggles, safety glasses, face shields, masks and/or respirators are to be always worn when handling specimens and/or requisitions.

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
HEAD AND NECK
A.  Neck Dissection

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
Procedure:
Orient the specimen. Is it a right or left neck dissection? If frozen sections were performed, consult respective resident/staff pathologist. Consult with the surgeon if necessary for accurate orientation.
Is the internal jugular vein included? If so, the length should be stated. Is the vein invaded by tumor?
Is the primary neoplasm present in the specimen? Is there metastatic tumor?
Is there gross involvement of the lymph nodes, submaxillary salivary gland, soft tissue, or muscle by tumor? Measure the largest lymph node identified. Note whether extra nodal invasion is suspected grossly.
Describe areas affected by disease, as well as, briefly, normal structures (salivary gland, muscle, etc).

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
The lymph nodes are divided into groups/levels as per the accompanying diagrams, or following consultation with the surgeon. It is convenient to dissect the nodes of the different anatomical regions before fixing the specimen in formalin. ALL lymph nodes identified must be submitted for microscopic evaluation. Residual fibro adipose tissue (up to 5 blocks) should be submitted to identify non-palpable lymph nodes.
In addition to the lymph nodes, take sections of the following structures when they are included in the specimen: parotid gland, submaxillary gland, thyroid and parathyroid glands, and internal jugular vein nearest to involved nodes.

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
Description:
State the overall dimensions of the specimen. State the length of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, if included
If the internal jugular vein is present, the length should be stated. State whether the vein invaded by tumor.
If the primary or metastatic neoplasm is present in the specimen, describe.
State whether there is gross involvement of the lymph nodes, submaxillary salivary gland, soft tissue, or muscle by tumor
Measure the largest lymph node identified. Note whether extra nodal invasion is suspected grossly.
Describe the lymph nodes by their neck levels

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
Sections for histology:
Submit all lymph nodes identified
Submit representative sections of any additional structures present (i.e., salivary gland; veins; muscle)
Take and label the neck levels if possible:

The [short] suture designates [location] and the [long] suture designates [location] per the [EMR, requisition/surgeon].

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
B.  Jaw Resection for Cancer
Mandibulectomy
Procedure:
Photograph the specimen.
Fix the entire specimen in formalin overnight (if a mucosal or soft tissue tumor is present, serial section tumor to optimize fixation, noting if tumor grossly extends in to bone).
Paint the surgical margins with ink.
For bone tumors: Make multiple parallel sections with the handheld oscillating saw through bone, photograph and fix further in formalin before decalcification. ASK PA FOR HELP WITH THIS STEP! 
NOTE: DO NOT ATTEMPT TO CUT THROUGH TEETH OR METAL!
Take photographs. Draw a diagram and identify in one of them the site of the section taken.
If the specimen includes a neck dissection, process according to instruction for "Neck Dissection".

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
Description:
Type of resection (partial or total) and size.
Tumor: size in three dimensions, color, appearance, edges; bone invaded?
Non-neoplastic mucosa: leukoplakia?
Bone: appearance on cross-sections.
Teeth: number and appearance (gross only).

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
Sections for histology:
Tumor: three sections (at least one including deepest extent of gross invasion)
Non-neoplastic mucosa
Perpendicular mucosal surgical margins
Perpendicular soft tissue surgical margins
Bone surgical margins
Mandibular nerve (surgical margins). Note: inferior alveolar nerve is a branch of mandibular nerve
Bone if grossly involved or suspicious

Maxillectomy
Procedure:
Photograph the specimen.
Fix the specimen in formalin overnight if a mucosal or soft tissue tumor is present, serial section tumor to optimize fixation, noting if tumor grossly extends into bone)
Paint the surgical margins with ink.
Take perpendicular surgical margins (anterior, posterior, external and superior); cut the specimen with the handheld oscillating saw in parallel slices. Fix them overnight. Take photographs and images with our small x-ray machine (Faxitron) if indicated.

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
Draw a diagram and identify the site of the sections taken.

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
Description:
Extent of resection, size.
Presence of following structures: hard palate; soft palate; superior, middle, and inferior turbinates; medial and lateral pterygoid plate of sphenoid bone; air cells of ethmoid; bony floor of orbit; orbital contents, zygomatic arch; masseter, temporalis, external, and internal pterygoid muscles.
Tumor characteristics: location, extent, size; limited to the maxillary sinus? involving superior, medial, lateral, anterior, posterior, or inferior part of sinus? extending into infratemporal fossa, nasal cavity, ethmoid cells, or any other of aforementioned structures? presence of tumor at surgical margins?
Condition of ostium of maxillary sinus and any other sinuses present; fistulae present.

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
Sections for histology:
Tumor: as many sections as necessary, with a minimum of three, at least one including deepest extent of gross invasion)
Perpendicular surgical margins
Non neoplastic mucosa
Bone if grossly involved or suspicious.

C.  SALIVARY GLAND - RESECTION FOR TUMOR

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
Procedure:
Paint surgical margins with ink.
Cut parallel sections and fix.
Look for intraparotid lymph nodes and for major nerves in total parotidectomy specimens.
If the specimen includes a neck dissection, process according to instructions for "Neck Dissection."

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
Description:
Type of specimen: parotid lobectomy, total parotidectomy without facial nerve, total parotidectomy with facial nerve, total submandibulectomy; site of operation.
Tumor: size, location, shape, distance from closest margin. Solitary or multiple? Cystic or solid? Encapsulated, circumscribed, or poorly defined? Hemorrhage or necrosis? Extra glandular extension?
Appearance of non-neoplastic gland.
Appearance of intraparotid and other lymph nodes.

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
Sections for histology:
Tumor: four or more, depending on size. Perpendicular capsule or tumor margins should be included.
Non-neoplastic gland
Surgical margins
Facial nerve margins, if included
Lymph nodes, if included

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
D. LARYNX, PHARYNX AND HYPOPHARYNX
Procedure:
Photograph the specimen
Ink the outer surface of soft tissue margins
Separate the larynx from the neck dissection specimen (if latter is included).
Measure larynx and open it along the posterior midline.
Photograph the opened specimen
Fix in 10% formalin with a wooden stick to keep it open

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
Description:
Describe the lesion, noting especially its size, location and extent. Is the lesion an ulcerated or fungating tumor. Is it invasive?
Describe the orientation of the specimen and provide overall measurements from anterior to posterior, left to right, and inferior to superior.
Describe involvement in relation to supraglottic, glottic, subglottic, anterior space, etc.

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
Sections for histology:

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
Take a shave margin of the inferior tracheal ring mucosal margin. If the tumor is within 1 cm of the inferior tracheal margin do a perpendicular section rather than a shave margin.
Take superior margins (shave margins) of the residual right and left pharyngeal mucosa including arytenoids and aryepiglottic folds, if present.
Take perpendicular sections of right, left, anterior and posterior soft tissue margins.
Take perpendicular sections of right and left aryepiglottic folds to include the pyriform sinus.
Take 1 section (perpendicular to the mucosa) of the epiglottis.

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
Take 3 to 4 sections of the tumor perpendicular to the mucosa, to include the true and false vocal cords and ventricle.  The sections must be able to demonstrate the depth of invasion of the tumor and the extent of infiltration of any adjacent cartilage or soft tissue. Sections as well as gross description should describe and show any involvement of the thyroid cartilage, epiglottis, supraglottis, subglottis or contralateral vocal cords. If tumor is grossly unilateral take 1 or 2 sections from the contralateral vocal cords to document absence of involvement.
If the tumor is confined to one side, section the anterior commissure. If the larynx is part of a larger surgical procedure, ask the attending pathologist about selecting blocks.

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
Calcified and/or ossified thyroid cartilage can be cut with a sharp scalpel blade after brief decalcification. Look for tumor involvement of cartilage and document it with a section.
Submit sections of hyoid bone overlying the tumor for decalcification if grossly involved by tumor. If hyoid bone is not grossly involved no section is needed
Look for thyroid and parathyroid glands, and submit representative blocks at the site of maximum tumor invasion (if any).

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
E. TONSILS AND ADENOIDS
Procedure:
Often removed for recurrent tonsillitis, obstructive sleep apnea, or middle ear infections, but rarely may be involved by hematolymphoid malignancy, carcinoma, or granulomatous processes
Rarely, bilateral or unilateral tonsillectomy may be done in a patient with metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in a neck lymph node with unknown primary.

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
Description:
Make note if one tonsil is asymmetrically enlarged. If there is suspicion of squamous cell carcinoma, ink the cauterized base of the tonsil and examine for gross tumor involvement.
Measure, weigh, and describe the specimen
Serially section through the tonsil; the cut surfaces should be lobulated, and friable yellow-green “sulfur” granules, representing Actinomyces colonies, may be grossly identified within tonsillar crypts.
Submit one representative section per tonsil.
If there is suspicion of lymphoma (e.g. unilateral enlargement, past clinical history, post-transplant setting etc), then perform lymphoma workup if fresh tissue is available

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
Sections for histology:
Submit one representative section per tonsil.
If mass/lesion identified, take additional sections.

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
ENDOCRINE
A. THYROID
Note: Prior to grossing the specimen, look up the ultrasound report and attempt to correlate imaging findings (number/location of nodules) with the gross findings. If possible, review laboratory data (e.g., TSH, T3, T4, Calcitonin, serologies for autoimmune process)

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
Procedure:
Weigh, measure the size of the organ (right lobe, left lobe, isthmus), dimensions of any abnormalities and location, presence/absence of parathyroid glands or possible lymph nodes.
Paint with ink for orientation (right lobe, left lobe, and isthmus each in different colors)
Anterior= blue, Posterior= black and Isthmus margin= orange if a lobectomy.
Make few sections and let the gland fix for at least two hours.

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
Description:
Describe external surface
Provide measurements of the organ (right lobe, left lobe, isthmus)
State dimensions of any abnormalities and location. Describe them – i.e., circumscribed nodule, infiltrating, multinodular, etc.
Describe its relationship to the capsule of the gland. Gross extra thyroidal extension of papillary thyroid carcinoma is prognostically important and its presence or absence should be commented upon.
State the presence/absence of parathyroid glands or possible lymph nodes

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
Sections for histology:
Sections at 4 mm intervals
Sections to submit:
No obvious nodules: 1 section per cm lobe length.
Solitary nodule up to 2 cm should be submitted entirely.
Solitary nodule larger than 2 cm: submit entire tumor capsule including a 2 to 3 mm rim of underlying lesional tissue and of overlying parenchyma.
Two to three sections of tumor capsule can be submitted per cassette.
Multinodular goiter: 1 section per nodule, up to 10 sections per lobe and 2 sections per isthmus.

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
Header example:
Thyroid, right, hemithyroidectomy:

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
Dictation example:
“Thyroid Gross”

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
Received [fresh / fresh for intra-operative consultation / in formalin] is a container labeled "[Patients name/MRN/Site]" is a [____] gram [total/hemi] thyroidectomy specimen consisting of right lobe [__ x __ x __] cm, left lobe [__x __ x __] cm, and isthmus [__ x __ x __] cm. A pyramidal lobe is [not] present [__ x __ x __] cm.] Parathyroid glands are [not] identified. [If present, note how many and describe.] The thyroid capsule is [smooth and intact] and inked as follows: [anterior- blue], [posterior- black] and [isthmus margin is inked orange]. The specimen is serially sectioned to reveal [describe any lesions/nodules], [__ x __ x __] cm, that are [#] cm from the anterior capsule, [#] cm from the posterior capsule, and [#] cm from the isthmus margin. The nodule[s] [is/are] [well circumscribed / color / solid / cystic / gelatinous / hemorrhagic / calcified].

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
The remainder of the thyroid parenchyma is beefy red and homogenous. Representative sections are submitted as follows:

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
([A1]) Lesion to anterior capsule
([A2]) Lesion to posterior capsule
([A3]) Lesion to isthmus margin
([A4]) Additional lesions
([A5]) Uninvolved thyroid

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
B.  PARATHYROIDS
All glands should be weighed. Look for and describe fibrous bands, hemorrhage, necrosis and extraparathyroid extension. If any of the above are present, submit the entire gland (up to 10 sections). If absent, 1 section per cm is sufficient.

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
Header example:
Parathyroid, right superior, biopsy:

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
Dictation example:
“Para”
Received is a fresh container entirely utilized for frozen section diagnosis labeled, "[Patients name/MRN/site]" containing a [__] gram [encapsulated] tan soft tissue, [ __ x __ x __] cm, and the frozen remnant is resubmitted in ([FSA1]).

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
C.  ADRENALS
Procedure:
Weighed and photographed
Inked entirely without removing the fat (one color is fine) in the event the tumor is present at resected margin
Weigh glands after careful dissection of peri-adrenal adipose tissue
Serially sectioned perpendicular to the long axis (Adrenal glands should be sectioned in a plane perpendicular to their long axes, going from head to tail regions at intervals of 3 mm. Measure cortical thickness and note its color.)
Any and all nodules/masses should be measured and described
Photographs of cut sections taken

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
Description:
Describe overall configuration of glands, identify head (medial), body (middle) and tail (lateral) aspects, and measure length, width and thickness at the crest.
Describe any irregularities (nodules, etc.) in cortex or medulla. (The medulla is concentrated in the head and body regions of the gland.)
Describe the size and color of the nodule; look for extra adrenal spread and necrosis

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
Sections for histology:
For suspected metastatic carcinoma:
If a grossly apparent metastasis is present, submit one complete cross-section of the gland, including the tumor.
If there are no obvious metastases, one representative section from the head, body and tail should be submitted for microscopic study.
For cortical hyperplasia:
One representative section from head, body and tail.
For cortical Nodules:
Lesions less than 2 cm: submit nodule entirely including capsule and relationship to adjacent adrenal gland.
Lesions larger than 2 cm: three cassettes plus an additional cassette for each 1 cm of greatest dimension, (up to 10 sections) including capsule, areas of hemorrhage, necrosis, and relationship to adjacent adrenal and soft tissue.
If nodule is infiltrating into soft tissue, take the nearest perpendicular margin.
Submit two additional sections of gland away from the nodule.

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]
For suspected pheochromocytoma:
Depending upon the size of the tumors, submit two to four sections of the tumor, including the capsule, fixed in formalin.
Submit at least two representative sections of the gland away from pheochromocytoma, including adjacent cortical and medullary tissue.
For adrenal medullary hyperplasia:
After fixation in formalin, submit all sections from head, body and tail regions, sequentially labeled, for routine sectioning.

[SOURCE: HNE Grossing Guide TEMPLATES.docx]

[SOURCE: Hysterectomy ~CANCER~ for endometrial hyperplasia cancer Gross Protocol and Template 041724.docx]
Hysterectomy for Endometrial Hyperplasia or Cancer

[SOURCE: Hysterectomy ~CANCER~ for endometrial hyperplasia cancer Gross Protocol and Template 041724.docx]
GROSS DESCRIPTION:
Orient the uterus and weigh it.
Ink the anterior and posterior resection margins (not serosa), and parametrial tissue (only if present; will only be there for radical hysterectomy specimens).
Remove the bilateral parametrial/paracervical tissues (if present, usually only in cervical cancer cases) and perpendicularly section.
Bivalve the uterus and take a gross photo.
Examine the cavity and mucosa and describe any lesions present. Record the size, location, and appearance of the tumor. Serially section the entire endometrial cavity and describe the pattern of invasion (pushing, infiltrative, or discontinuous?).  Measure the greatest depth of invasion and the maximum myometrial thickness in this area.
Each case must have an average (uninvolved) endometrial thickness and myometrial thickness recorded
Take gross photos, including a cross section of tumor

[SOURCE: Hysterectomy ~CANCER~ for endometrial hyperplasia cancer Gross Protocol and Template 041724.docx]
SECTIONS FOR HISTOLOGY:
Cervix
If the cervix is normal and there is no history of dysplasia, take one section each of anterior and posterior cervix to include the squamocolumnar junction
If there is a concurrent history of dysplasia one section per quadrant

[SOURCE: Hysterectomy ~CANCER~ for endometrial hyperplasia cancer Gross Protocol and Template 041724.docx]
Lower Uterine Segment
One longitudinal section each of anterior and posterior, noting if there is tumor involvement

[SOURCE: Hysterectomy ~CANCER~ for endometrial hyperplasia cancer Gross Protocol and Template 041724.docx]
Corpus
Frozen section remnant
Pilot tumor section (this only needs to be done if submission of sections is on the day following receipt of the specimen - if the specimen is received and completely grossed/submitted on the same day, no "pilot" is needed)
Bilateral parametria (if present), serially sectioned and submitted entirely, separating left from right
Tumor: Submit two full thickness slices of the uterine wall in the area where the tumor appears the deepest and two additional superficial sections of tumor. Submit additional sections of tumor such that you have at least 1 section of tumor per cm (if tumor is >4 cm)
Uninvolved endomyometrium: one full thickness section each of anterior and posterior endomyometrium to demonstrate histology away from the tumor

[SOURCE: Hysterectomy ~CANCER~ for endometrial hyperplasia cancer Gross Protocol and Template 041724.docx]
If there is no lesion grossly visible, submit one full thickness section each of the anterior and posterior endomyometrium, then submit the remainder of the endometrium in superficial strips (usually 2-3/cassette) - these should be deep enough to include the endomyometrial junction, but not the entire myometrium

[SOURCE: Hysterectomy ~CANCER~ for endometrial hyperplasia cancer Gross Protocol and Template 041724.docx]
Bilateral Fallopian Tubes and Ovaries
If grossly normal, submit one cassette containing the left ovary and one cassette containing the right ovary
Submit the entire fimbriated ends of the fallopian tubes (perpendicularly sectioned) and at least 1 representative cross section, separating left from right

[SOURCE: Hysterectomy ~CANCER~ for endometrial hyperplasia cancer Gross Protocol and Template 041724.docx]
Lymph Nodes
For small nodes that will fix well, multiple per cassette submitted in toto OR multiple nodes inked and bisected (so we can tell microscopically which pieces of nodes belong together)
All sentinel lymph nodes need to be sectioned at 2 mm intervals and entirely submitted
We often receive sentinel nodes for endometrial cancer. In CoPath, these will be accessioned as a “lymph node, sentinel (GYN)” and have “SNE” on the cassette. The SNE protocol should be indicated on all blocks of lymph node and not on remaining adipose that is submitted.  The protocol and stains should be copied to all additional lymph node blocks in addition to the “SNE” code on the block, but only 1 H&E assigned to the block the remaining adipose tissue is in (if submitted).
Submit extra fibroadipose tissue, up to 10 cassettes total for that part

[SOURCE: Hysterectomy ~CANCER~ for endometrial hyperplasia cancer Gross Protocol and Template 041724.docx]

[SOURCE: Hysterectomy for ~CERVICAL CANCER~ Gross Protocol and Template 041724.docx]
Radical Hysterectomy for Cervical Cancer

[SOURCE: Hysterectomy for ~CERVICAL CANCER~ Gross Protocol and Template 041724.docx]
GROSS DESCRIPTION:
Orient the uterus, weigh it, and differentially ink the anterior/posterior surfaces including the parametrial soft tissue
Remove the parametrial tissue, perpendicularly section it, and submit each side (right, left) entirely (NOT JUST THE MARGINS).
Amputate the cervix and open like a cone biopsy. Describe the tumor. Measure maximum tumor width, length and distance to nearest cervical margin and vaginal margin
Examine vaginal cuff. If tumor is <1 cm from the cuff, submit perpendicular sections of tumor with margin, if not, submit shave margins.
Section the cervix longitudinally at 3 mm intervals and describe tumor depth and measure maximum wall thickness in this area.
If prior therapy has been done no gross tumor may be seen.
Cut the uterus into anterior and posterior halves. Make transverse sections to examine the endometrium and myometrium.

[SOURCE: Hysterectomy for ~CERVICAL CANCER~ Gross Protocol and Template 041724.docx]
Take gross photos, ideally including a cross section of tumor

[SOURCE: Hysterectomy for ~CERVICAL CANCER~ Gross Protocol and Template 041724.docx]
SECTIONS FOR HISTOLOGY:
Cervix
Parametrial tissue, bilateral, in separate cassettes
If gross tumor present: three slices of tissue with full wall thickness in the deepest areas of invasion, as well as one slice of uninvolved cervix, always designate o’clock position so that tumor size can be reconstructed at sign-out (cervical cancer staging rests upon precise tumor measurements in multiple dimensions). Consider annotating a gross photograph so that it is obvious where each section came from. Make sure there is at least 1 section per cm of tumor
If no gross tumor present, e.g. after a cold knife cone: entire cervix needs to be amputated and submitted radially (like a cone)
 Uterine Corpus
Two transverse section of lower uterine segment
Full-thickness anterior and posterior endomyometrium in one cassette each

[SOURCE: Hysterectomy for ~CERVICAL CANCER~ Gross Protocol and Template 041724.docx]
Bilateral Fallopian Tubes and Ovaries
If grossly normal, submit one cassette containing the left ovary and one cassette containing the right ovary
Submit the entire fimbriated ends of the fallopian tubes (perpendicularly sectioned) and at least 1 representative cross section, separating left from right

[SOURCE: Hysterectomy for ~CERVICAL CANCER~ Gross Protocol and Template 041724.docx]
Lymph Nodes
For small nodes that will fix well, multiple per cassette submitted in toto OR nodes inked and bisected (so we can tell microscopically which pieces of nodes belong together)
If the node is very fatty, make sure it is sectioned THINLY
Submit extra fibroadipose tissue, up to 10 cassettes total for that part

[SOURCE: Hysterectomy for ~CERVICAL CANCER~ Gross Protocol and Template 041724.docx]

[SOURCE: Hysterectomy gravid with Placenta in Situ Gross Protocol and Template 061621.docx]
S25-Protocol for grossing gravid hysterectomy specimens with placenta in situ (placenta accreta spectrum)
1. Gather the following information before opening the specimen bucket:
Clinical/Radiologic diagnoses (Placenta accreta/increta/percreta and uterine location of abnormality, is placenta previa present?)
Intraoperative assessment of uterine serosa on entering the abdomen (this may not be available depending on timing of the operative report; if you don’t find it prior to grossing, be sure to have it available at the time of signout)
Whether adjacent structures (e.g. portion of bladder wall) were resected en bloc with the uterus
2. Initial photography: Prior to formalin fixation, take a photo of the anterior and posterior surfaces of the uterus, with a close-up of any areas of disruption
3. Record the following information:

[SOURCE: Hysterectomy gravid with Placenta in Situ Gross Protocol and Template 061621.docx]
Weight of the uterus with placenta in situ (if the cervix comes detached from the uterus in the same part, this should be included in the weight)
3-dimensional measurements of the uterus (fundus-cervix, anterior-posterior, left-right)
Hysterotomy site (length and location)
Appearance of uterine serosa (intact vs disrupted; if the latter, note anatomic location and size of disruption, whether there is a visible C-section scar)
Whether other structures are present (e.g. fallopian tubes, adherent adipose, bladder wall) and their measurements
4. Ink the specimen(any areas without smooth serosal surface): The right anterior surface = green, left anterior surface = blue, posterior surface = black.  Make sure you blot/dry the ink thoroughly, as it tends to run in the best of circumstances and especially will run if there is exposed placental tissue.

[SOURCE: Hysterectomy gravid with Placenta in Situ Gross Protocol and Template 061621.docx]
5. Call the attending on service to be present for slicing.  If the attending on service is not available, call any one of Drs. Berning, Post, or Wolsky.
6. The uterus should be sliced in the axial plane (superior to inferior, perpendicular to the long axis of the uterus) at 2 cm intervals with a long blade and the slices numbered 1 through X, where 1 is the most superior slice.  This may be easier to do with one person holding the uterus and the other cutting.
At some point you will encounter the umbilical cord – document the number of vessels, total length of the cord, an approximate insertion site (central/paracentral/marginal/velamentous).  The umbilical cord can then be amputated at its insertion site.

[SOURCE: Hysterectomy gravid with Placenta in Situ Gross Protocol and Template 061621.docx]
7. Document the number of slices, which slices contain the hysterotomy site, and which slices are involved by adherent or invasive placenta.  The best way to determine if placenta is abnormally adherent is to gently put traction on the placenta and see if it easily separates from the underlying uterine wall.  If it does not readily separate, those are areas of PASD grade 1 (formerly placenta accreta).

[SOURCE: Hysterectomy gravid with Placenta in Situ Gross Protocol and Template 061621.docx]
Measure the thinnest area of myometrium, and/or note that placental tissue extends to (or through) the serosal surface and which slices contain that finding.
8. Lay out the slices in sequence (slice 1 in upper left corner of image) and photograph (see image below) – take one picture of all sections, with additional close-up photos of any areas of serosal disruption or the area of maximal placental invasion (thinnest myometrium).
9. The slices can be fixed in formalin overnight or grossed the same day, depending on case load, attending preference, or other factors.
10. Additional information required (see also sample dictation below):
Overall size of the placental disc, to include maximal thickness
Endometrial thickness in areas away from placental disc
Myometrial thickness in areas away from placental disc

[SOURCE: Hysterectomy gravid with Placenta in Situ Gross Protocol and Template 061621.docx]
Any additional uterine lesions (endometrial/endocervical polyps, leiomyomata, etc.)
Any placental lesions (e.g. infarcts, thrombi, masses)
11. Take sections for microscopic examination.  The number/extent of sections will depend on the pre-operative diagnosis and your findings after slicing the uterus.
Gross pathologic grade 1 (see diagram below): Requires the most extensive sampling of placental:uterine wall interface.  Submit 1 cassette (with a single section per cassette) for each slice of uterus which contains adherent placenta.  These do not need to be full thickness, as our goal is to assess the presence/absence of decidua at the placental:myometrial interface.

[SOURCE: Hysterectomy gravid with Placenta in Situ Gross Protocol and Template 061621.docx]
Gross pathologic grade 2 and above: 3 cassettes (1 section per cassette) of placental:myometrial interface at area of maximal thinning of myometrium (or of placental:serosal interface or perforation if present).  Additional 3 sections of placental:myometrial interface in regions of grade 1 adherent placenta to evaluate for extent of decidual loss.
All cases should also include:
Anterior and posterior cervix (if it is a supracervical hysterectomy, an en face section of the anterior and posterior LUS resection margin should be submitted)
Longitudinal section of inferior-most placenta in relation to LUS/endocervix
“Uninvolved” endometrium with overlying membranes, generally from the posterior wall or fundus, full thickness (this may require multiple cassettes)
Additional lesions (e.g. endometrial/endocervical polyp, leiomyoma)
2 cross sections of umbilical cord from different areas

[SOURCE: Hysterectomy gravid with Placenta in Situ Gross Protocol and Template 061621.docx]
1 section of full-thickness placental disc without gross abnormalities
Additional sections to demonstrate any placental lesions (fibrin deposition, infarcts, thrombi, etc.)
Fallopian tubes (if present) – serially sectioned fimbriated end and representative cross-sections

Received [fresh / in formalin], labeled "[patient's name/MRN/specimen name]” is a [__] g uterus with in situ placenta, [__ ] cm (superior-inferior) x [__] cm (cornu- cornu) x [__] cm (anterior-posterior), [with / without attached cervix / fallopian tubes / ovaries / other structures (give measurements if any of these are present)].  There is a [__] cm hysterotomy site at the [anatomic location – fundus vs LUS, anterior vs posterior] which [has sutures closing the incision, and is without protruding placental tissue].

[SOURCE: Hysterectomy gravid with Placenta in Situ Gross Protocol and Template 061621.docx]
The serosa [appears intact and without lesions vs with adherent adipose or bladder wall vs appears disrupted with protruding placental tissue]. The anterior right aspect is inked green, the left anterior aspect inked blue, and the posterior aspect inked black. The uterus is sliced axially from superior to inferior into [__] sections, with section #1 representing the fundus. There is a [__] cm trivascular umbilical cord inserted [centrally/paracentrally/marginally/velamentously] onto the placental disc (include distance of membranous vessels if velamentous insertion). The fetal surface is [purple-blue and without lesions], with vessels [extending to the disc edge]. The membranes are [tan and clear vs green tinged vs brown]. The placental parenchyma, present in slices [__] through [__], ranges in thickness from [__] to [__] cm.

[SOURCE: Hysterectomy gravid with Placenta in Situ Gross Protocol and Template 061621.docx]
((Describe appearance of parenchyma, as well as any lesions that are seen)). In slices [__] through [__], there is [abnormal adherence without myometrial thinning / thinned myometrium to a thickness of __ / absent myometrium with only serosa covering placenta / disrupted serosa with protrusion of placental tissue].
Endometrium away from the placental implantation is covered by membranes, with a total thickness of [__] cm.  The myometrial thickness away from placental disc ranges from [__] to [__] cm thick.  (Also describe additional lesions such as polyps or leiomyomata)
