[SOURCE: Lung Grossing and Templates.docx]
Principle
To describe the templates and grossing procedures to be followed in the Gross Room/Frozen Section for specimens from the thoracic cavity including lung and thymus. This section describes all the procedures that need to be followed to ensure that specimens are prepared, handled, and processed properly.
Scope
This protocol applies to the procedure and dictation for all specimens from the thoracic cavity including lung and thymus.
Safety
Scrubs, fluid resistant gowns, gloves, goggles, safety glasses, face shields, masks and/or respirators (optional) are to be always worn when handling specimens and/or requisitions. Lung specimens also should always be grossed for frozen or routine grossing at a bench with adequate ventilation or in the biosafety cabinet if concerned.

[SOURCE: Lung Grossing and Templates.docx]
**Aerosol (freeze) spray is NOT to be used with any lung specimens to limit risk of aerosolizing anything within the lung lesions**
Dictating Frozen Sections
Procedure:
Scan case barcode into CoPath and PC Dictate.
Dictate the case number, patient name, MRN, and clinical history (if not auto populated).
State you are dictating a frozen (because it is in a different tab for transcription) and then dictate the frozen section diagnosis AS WRITTEN. If a word or phrase is illegible--- ask your co-workers for help deciphering, the frozen resident, or call the attending who signed it out.
Dictating the frozen can be done at the end of the dictation but keep it to one or the other and dictate them for all parts at the same time.
If using Dragon, dictate this in the “Intraop Diagnosis Entry/Edit” screen and after clicking “Edit Text” so the word document opens.

[SOURCE: Lung Grossing and Templates.docx]
Dictate the patient’s name, MRN, and designation on the container label as written.
If there is a description written on the side of the container, dictate that as such.
If the tissue was entirely submitted for frozen section diagnosis, scan the container, then the cassette and put in rack.
If additional tissue is needed, print additional cassettes, and submit additional sections for routine histology.
Sample Header:
Lymph node, level 7, biopsy:
Dictation Example:
Received [fresh and entirely utilized for frozen section diagnosis] is a container labeled “[patients name/ MRN/level 7 lymph node]” is an [anthracotic] lymph node candidate, [0.4 x 0.3 x 0.2] cm, and the frozen remnant is resubmitted in (FS[A1]).
Lung biopsies (endobronchial, transbronchial, transplant, native)
Sample Header: Lung, left upper lobe, transbronchial biopsy:

[SOURCE: Lung Grossing and Templates.docx]
Description: These biopsies are important in both neoplastic and lung function cases. Often, a nodule or irregularity is identified on imaging along with symptoms that suggest a lung condition. The biopsy diagnosis not only helps with continuation of care, but also drives which options are possible and most appropriate.
Triage Needed? No, specimen should arrive in formalin and be submitted entirely.
Procedure:
Scan case barcode into CoPath and PC Dictate.
Dictate the case number, patient name and MRN.
Scan the container barcode into CoPath and read the container and confirm it is correct and matches the information in CoPath and on the requisition.
Describe the specimen and pour contents into the mesh bag and fold to fit in the cassette.
How specimen was received (fresh vs in formalin).
Count the number of pieces of tissue in each container (# > 10, use “multiple”).

[SOURCE: Lung Grossing and Templates.docx]
Describe the tissue appearance (red soft-tissue fragment is sufficient).
Provide a three-dimensional aggregate size of all tissues together.
Submit entirely and in 1 cassette.
Place one bag in each cassette, and print additional cassettes as needed.
Scan each of the cassettes in order and put them in the rack for holding.
Sections for Histology: All specimens must be submitted for examination.
Dragon Template: “ST Bx”
Dictation Example: Received in a [formalin] container labeled “[patients name/ MRN/site]” is an [aggregate of 6], [red], soft tissue fragments, [0.2 x 0.1 x 0.1] cm, which are submitted in toto in [A]1).
Lung Lymph Nodes
Sample Header: Lymph node, left level 2, biopsy:

[SOURCE: Lung Grossing and Templates.docx]
Description: While these are accessioned as lymph node, excision because it is an excision of the whole lymph node in that level, our headers are biopsy. Also, numbers are used versus roman numerals or spelling them out. These are submitted whole to ensure we have examined the whole tissue to state whether it is positive or negative for metastasis.
Triage Needed? No, specimen should arrive in formalin and be submitted entirely. If fresh, confirm no lymphoma protocol is requested.
Procedure:
Scan case barcode into CoPath and PC Dictate.
Dictate the case number, patient name and MRN.
Scan the container barcode into CoPath and read the container and confirm it is correct and matches the information in CoPath and on the requisition.
Describe the specimen and put the pieces in the cassette.
How specimen was received (fresh vs in formalin).

[SOURCE: Lung Grossing and Templates.docx]
Count the number of pieces of tissue in each container (# > 10, use “multiple”).
Describe the tissue appearance (tan soft-tissue fragment is sufficient).
Measure the greatest dimension of the smallest and largest pieces of tissue.
Provide a three-dimensional aggregate size of all tissues together.
Submit entirely. If small- make sure to put in bag or tissue paper.
Place one bag in each cassette, and print additional cassettes as needed.
Scan each of the cassettes in order and put them in the rack for holding.

[SOURCE: Lung Grossing and Templates.docx]
Sections for Histology: Each lymph node candidate must be submitted for examination.
Dragon Template: “Lung LN”
Dictation Example: Received in a [formalin] container labeled “[patients name/ MRN/left level 2 lymph node]” is an [anthracotic] lymph node candidate, [0.4 x 0.3 x 0.2] cm, and the specimen is submitted in toto in ([A]1).
MAC Lungs
Sample Header: Lung, left lower lobe, lobectomy:

[SOURCE: Lung Grossing and Templates.docx]
Description: MAC= Mycobacterium avium complex is one of the lung diseases where we often get specimens to either decrease organism burden or to hopefully improve symptoms and quality of life. All our MAC lungs are infections but not necessarily pertaining to MAC itself. We take great care to make sure these are processed at a ventilated bench to limit aerosolization and potentially getting infected. There is a simple formula to determine how many days it needs to fix to make sure it has had adequate time prior to grossing which is described below.
Triage Needed? Yes, see below.
Procedure:
Inflate under the hood.
Measure lesion under the hood and take the smallest measurement in cm, divide by 2, = the number of days to fix the lung before grossing.
Write the grossing day on the requisition and/or container lid.
Gross under the hood – follow the lobe procedure.
Sections for Histology:

[SOURCE: Lung Grossing and Templates.docx]
Bronchial margin, en face
Vascular margins, en face
Parenchymal margins, en face
Reps of mass/lesion 1/cm
Lung parenchyma (central and peripheral of attached lobe(s)
Hilar lymph nodes
Dragon Template: “infect lung”

[SOURCE: Lung Grossing and Templates.docx]
Dictation Example: Received in a formalin container labeled "[Patients name/ MRN/ Site]” is a [#] g, [# x # x #] cm [lobectomy] specimen with stapled bronchovascular and parenchymal margins. The bronchovascular margins are patent and unremarkable surrounded by [multiple enlarged peribronchial anthracotic] lymph nodes. The pleura is [tan-purple, wrinkled, and dull] with [multifocal areas of ragged adhesions and a # x # x # cm surgical defect]. [An additional # x # cm defect is present within the middle lobe with an exposed underlying cavitary, purulent lesion].

[SOURCE: Lung Grossing and Templates.docx]
Cut surfaces demonstrate [an ill-defined, tan-brown, indurated and focally cavitary lesion throughout the middle and lower lobes], [# x # x #] cm, occupying approximately [#] % of the [middle lobe and #% of the lower lobe]. The [cavitary lesion] is [#] cm from the stapled parenchymal margin, and [adjacent to the hilar region approximately # cm from the bronchovascular margins, and grossly extends to the pleura, involving the previously described disruption]. The uninvolved lung parenchyma is [tan-brown and spongy with [appropriately sized] air spaces. Gross photographs are taken, and representative sections are submitted as follows:

[SOURCE: Lung Grossing and Templates.docx]
([A1]) Pilot section of [cavitary lesion]
([A2]) Bronchial margin, en face
([A3]) Vascular margins, en face
([A4-A5]) [Middle and lower lobe] parenchymal margins, en face
([A6]) [Lower lobe component of cavity lesion]
([A7]) [Additional middle lobe component of cavity lesion]
([A8]) [Additional lower lobe component of cavity lesion]
([A9]) Uninvolved central lung parenchyma
Wedge resection
Sample Header: Lung, left lower lobe, wedge resection:

[SOURCE: Lung Grossing and Templates.docx]
Description: Wedge resections commonly come in to reduce diseased lung volume (resect large bullae or area of consolidation) or to remove a nodule of either biopsy proven malignancy or identify and confirm diagnosis of a lesion identified on imaging. If it is a wedge for identification of possible malignancy or identify a nodule on imaging, they will come in for frozen section diagnosis. They may want both margin status and the lesion, or just the lesion so confirming the clinical question on the requisition or by calling the OR is advised. If a malignancy is identified they may go back for the lobe, but that is not always the case.
Triage Needed? Can inflate and let fix for a couple of hours but do not need to. Do not have to fix overnight.
Procedure:
Record weight and measurement in three dimensions.

[SOURCE: Lung Grossing and Templates.docx]
Comment on the integrity of the pleural surface and if there are any adhesions or puckered areas. Consider the advantage of inking that area or not. Ask someone if unsure.
Remove the staple line by trimming it off leaving 0.3 cm of tissue attached to the staples.
Once the staple line is free, trim it close to the staples and put that end face up on the frozen chuck or face down in the cassette if no frozen in performed. This would be an en face margin.
Most manuals will say to ink the resection margin or under the staple line, but we do not typically ink lung specimens unless there is a specific necessity. Since the margin is en face it does not need to be inked and the pleural surface denotes that it is not a margin. Ask someone if you are unsure.

[SOURCE: Lung Grossing and Templates.docx]
Section the specimen sequentially into 0.3 cm slices and once it is completed lay each section flat sequentially to maintain orientation and locate any mass lesions or abnormalities. Note their size, shape, color, consistency, relationship to the pleura and stapled margin. There should be no hilar areas in these specimens, but if so they need to be described and the distance from the abnormality to this area should be noted in the gross description.
Take a gross photograph if appropriate.
Submit any mass lesions or abnormalities 1/cm or entirely if they are less than 2 cm. Include a section of unremarkable lung if possible. The lesion to the margins can count in the 1/cm calculation.
Sections for Histology:
Margin, en face
Serially section and submit 1/cm or entire lesion (usually entire due to size)
Representative normal (can be remainder of wedge depending on size)

[SOURCE: Lung Grossing and Templates.docx]
Sample Header: Lung, left upper lobe, wedge resection:
Dragon Template: “Part Lung”
Dictation Example: Received in formalin labeled "[patients name/MRN/location]" is a [#] g, lung wedge resection, [# x # x #] cm, with [an intact/ruptured/smooth/glistening/ roughened/puckered] pleural surface and staples across the resection margin. Cut surfaces demonstrate [describe all lesions including size, color, involvement of pleura, and distance from margin]. The remaining parenchyma is [emphysematous/spongiform/fibrotic/with appropriate size airspaces]. Gross photographs are taken. Representative sections are submitted as follows:

[SOURCE: Lung Grossing and Templates.docx]
([A1]) Pilot, tumor
([A2]) Closest staple margin, en face
([A#]) Tumor to pleura/uninvolved parenchyma
([A#]) Representative uninvolved lung parenchyma
Lobectomy
Sample Header: Lung, left upper lobe, lobectomy:

[SOURCE: Lung Grossing and Templates.docx]
Description: Lung lobes are typically removed for malignancy either as a completion to a wedge resection or including the lesion when indicated. Lobectomy specimens for disease are also received in the gross room and the MAC lung templates (above) may be more appropriate. The hilar lymph node search and a pilot section of the tumor are often forgotten but are very important in a proper diagnosis workup, so the tumor has a limited amount of formalin exposure. Lymph nodes are important in addition to any additionally submitted containers for examination of all possible lymph nodes to look for metastasis. Imaging should be consulted to estimate the plane of sectioning to get a full face to submit the greatest dimension of the lesion entirely to confirm microscopically. If you need assistance with this, be sure to ask.

[SOURCE: Lung Grossing and Templates.docx]
Triage Needed? Yes, inflate and fix for a couple of hours. Does not have to wait overnight. If overnight for fixation, submit a pilot section of the tumor.
Procedure:
Record weight, specimen measurement in three dimensions, and if the hilar margins are open or stapled and patent.
Comment on the integrity of the pleural surface and if there are any adhesions or puckered areas. Consider the advantage of inking that area or not. Ask someone if unsure.
Remove the staple lines of hilar structures and true parenchymal margins (not adhesion staple lines between lobes) by trimming the staples off leaving 0.3 cm of tissue attached to the staples.
Once the staple line is free, trim it close to the staples and put that end face up on the frozen chuck or face down in the cassette if no frozen in performed. This would be an en face margin.

[SOURCE: Lung Grossing and Templates.docx]
Dissect the bronchi starting at the hilum for a couple centimeters and remove all lymph node candidates and submit. If no candidates are found, sampling this peribronchial tissue is required.
Most manuals will say to ink the resection margin or under the staple line, but we do not typically ink lung specimens unless there is a specific necessity. Since the margin is en face it does not need to be inked and the pleural surface denotes that it is not a margin. Ask someone if you are unsure.
Section the specimen sequentially into 0.3 cm slices and once it is completed lay each section flat sequentially to maintain orientation and locate any mass lesions or abnormalities. Note their size, shape, color, consistency, relationship to the pleura and stapled margin.
Take a gross photograph if appropriate.

[SOURCE: Lung Grossing and Templates.docx]
Describe the uninvolved lung parenchyma and note the size of the airspaces and if it is consolidated (pneumonia like) or any additional lesions.
Submit any mass lesions with a pilot section (a representative of tumor) and any additional abnormalities 1/cm or entirely if they are less than 2 cm. The lesion to the margins can count in the 1/cm calculation.
Include a section of unremarkable lung
Sections for Histology:
Pilot section of mass/lesion, state it is a pilot in cassette summary
Bronchial and vascular margins, en face (parenchyma margin, en face, if present)
Hilar/intraparenchymal lymph nodes
Tumor to pleura/uninvolved parenchyma
Representative uninvolved lung parenchyma
Dragon Template: “Lung Lobe”

[SOURCE: Lung Grossing and Templates.docx]
Dictation Example: Received in formalin labeled "[patients name/MRN/location]" is a [___] g, [intact/previously incised], [left/right], [upper/middle/lower] lung lobe, [# x # x #] cm, with [stapled/open] hilar margins. The pleural surface is [intact/ruptured/smooth/glistening/roughened/puckered] with [minimal, moderate, extensive] anthracotic pigmentation. There are [multiple], [anthracotic], [hilar or intraparenchymal] lymph node candidates identified, ranging from [# - #] cm in greatest dimension. Cut surfaces demonstrate [describe all lesions including size, color, involvement of pleura, involvement of hilum, and distance from margins (vascular, bronchial, staples)]. The remaining parenchyma is [emphysematous/ spongiform/fibrotic/red]. Gross photographs are obtained.
Representative sections are submitted as follows:

[SOURCE: Lung Grossing and Templates.docx]
([A1]) Tumor, pilot section
([A2]) Bronchial and vascular margins, en face (parenchyma margin, en face, if present)
([A3]) Hilar/intraparenchymal lymph nodes
([A#]) Tumor to pleura/uninvolved parenchyma
([A#]) Representative uninvolved lung parenchyma
Pneumonectomy transplant (including research lungs)
Sample Header: Lung, left, transplant pneumonectomy:

[SOURCE: Lung Grossing and Templates.docx]
Description: We are fortunate that we have a well-respected lung transplant program, so we see lung explants regularly. Transplants usually happen due to advanced lung diseases including Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), interstitial lung disease (ILD), cystic fibrosis and Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. Additionally, we have clinical trials and research related to these cases and patients where we give tissue to research groups to further study the diseases. While PAs usually procure the research tissue, you may have to gross the remnants of either an ILD collection or a COPD collection and if it is not straight forward, please ask a PA to help explain.
Triage Needed? Can inflate and let fix for a couple of hours but not required. Do not have to fix overnight.
Procedure:

[SOURCE: Lung Grossing and Templates.docx]
Record weight, specimen measurement in three dimensions, and if the hilar margins are open or stapled and patent.
Comment on the integrity of the pleural surface and if there are any adhesions or puckered areas. Consider the advantage of inking that area or not. Ask someone if unsure.
Remove the staple lines of hilar structures and true parenchymal margins (not adhesion staple lines between lobes) by trimming the staples off leaving 0.3 cm of tissue attached to the staples.
Once the staple line is free, trim it close to the staples and put that end face up on the frozen chuck or face down in the cassette if no frozen in performed. This would be an en face margin.
Dissect the bronchi starting at the hilum for a couple centimeters and remove all lymph node candidates and submit. If no candidates are found, sampling this peribronchial tissue is required.

[SOURCE: Lung Grossing and Templates.docx]
Most manuals will say to ink the resection margin, but we do not typically ink lung specimens unless there is a specific necessity. Since the margins are en face it does not need to be inked and the pleural surface denotes that it is not a margin. Ask someone if you are unsure.
Section the specimen sequentially into slices and locate any mass lesions or abnormalities. Note size, shape, color, consistency, relationship to the pleura and margins.
Take a gross photograph if appropriate.
Describe the uninvolved lung parenchyma and note the size of the airspaces and if it is consolidated (pneumonia like) or any additional lesions.
Submit representative tissue of each of the lobes, central and peripheral, and the hilar margins and any easily identified lymph nodes in the hilum.
Sections for Histology:
Bronchial and vascular margins, en face
Hilar/intraparenchymal lymph nodes

Thymus
Sample Header: Thymus, thymectomy:
Description: Thymuses/Thymi are useful in the human body until approximately puberty and then degenerate into primarily adipose. They can persist and thymomas and thymic carcinomas can arise from the persistent thymic tissue typically in adulthood. Important staging and prognostic factors include the invasion of the tumor into adjacent structures and margin status. There is a better prognosis if it is entirely resected. The weight is important especially in cases of hyperplasia.

[SOURCE: Lung Grossing and Templates.docx]
Triage Needed? No, usually submitted in formalin. If fresh, confirm lymphoma protocol is not requested.
Procedure:
Weigh and measure specimen in three dimensions (cm).
Determine orientation (if possible).
Describe any adherent structures (e.g., pericardium [posteriorly], pleura, lung, vessels, nerves).
The anterior and posterior surfaces should be differentially inked; if requested, left and right aspects can also be inked and adjacent margins from other structures.
Serially section and describe the cut surfaces including any masses present (size, shape, color, texture, etc.) including its location within the thymus.
Give distances to margins and distances to anterior and posterior surfaces if relevant.
Note and submit any identified lymph nodes.
Submit sections of the lesion (1/cm) including relationship of mass to anterior and posterior surfaces, margins, all structures.

[SOURCE: Lung Grossing and Templates.docx]
Submit uninvolved thymus and all lymph nodes.
Sections for Histology:
Representative nodular mass, submit entirely if small, include distance to margins.
Random uninvolved thymus from remaining lobes.
Dragon Template: “Tyme B9” “Tyme CA”

Benign- Unoriented

The non-peritonealized aspect is inked [black]. The specimen is sectioned to demonstrate [tan-grey, lobulated] thymic parenchyma [surrounded by yellow, lobulated adipose]. [No] discrete lesions or abnormalities are identified. Representative sections are submitted in ([A1-A3]).

The specimen is inked: anterior [blue] and posterior [black]

[SOURCE: Mastectomy Grossing.docx]
MASTECTOMY GROSSING WITH TEMPLATE

[SOURCE: Mastectomy Grossing.docx]
To ensure proper key characteristics, measurements and sampling occur in the grossing of breast specimens (partial/simple/skin sparing/nipple sparing/modified radical/radical mastectomy, etc.) please take note of the following considerations, required sections, and template below. ALL cancer breasts need to be scanned in the Faxitron and images used for clip localization and confirmation. The prophylactic side can be bypassed if no clips/suspicion for bilateral disease.

[SOURCE: Mastectomy Grossing.docx]
Keep in mind each breast specimen is unique and deviation from the template can occur as long as all required elements and sections are included.

[SOURCE: Mastectomy Grossing.docx]
Confirm laterality of breast on container and requisition. Additionally confirm with orientation sutures. (IF discordant, confirm with PA/attending and/or call OR)
Write down the weight/measurements (superior/inferior, medial/lateral, anterior/posterior (deep))
Ink according to protocol. Any deviation from the protocol must be noted on the requisition
Slice perpendicular to superior/inferior axis into thin slices (approx. 1 cm or less) trying to get the posterior surface in each slice. Cut slices deep enough to be able to view the whole slice. If skin along the anterior- it will help hold the specimen together.
When the entire specimen is sectioned, collect for tissue bank (if consented) otherwise put in formalin
If a clip/savi scout is dislodged, secure a safety pin in the slice/location for reference.

[SOURCE: Mastectomy Grossing.docx]
IF A RADIOACTIVE SEED IS FOUND STOP WHAT YOURE DOING AND TELL A PA OR GROSS TECH TO MAKE SURE ITS HANDLED PROPERLY
Note the in formalin time on the requisition and if tumor/normal was given to the biorepository

[SOURCE: Mastectomy Grossing.docx]
Elements to include:
Weight of entire specimen (look on lid or requisition if triaged)
Dimensions- superior-inferior, medial-lateral, anterior-posterior and overall size of axillary dissection (if present)
Measurements of skin ellipse (if present) along with description of any lesions
Nipple size, retraction, inversion, and description
Deep margin irregularities (fascial plane should be smooth and intact)
Lesion- size, location, quadrant, length from nipple, color, distance to margins, presence of clip(s)
Description- color, borders, consistency, relationship to margins (anterior,
Posterior/deep, skin (medial/lateral if involved))
Description of remaining tissue
Faxitron findings
Lymph nodes and size if axillary dissection is present- also ALWAYS check lateral aspect \for low lymph nodes incidentally removed and submit entirely.

[SOURCE: Mastectomy Grossing.docx]
Muscle dimensions and presence/absence of involvement if present on the deep aspect

[SOURCE: Mastectomy Grossing.docx]
Required Sections:
Nipple and skin, perpendicular
Lesion in plane of greatest dimension including to all closest margins
Sections in plane of lesion on either side of greatest dimension (appear uninvolved)
Tissue between two lesions (if applicable)
Representative sections (2 and can be in 1 cassette) of uninvolved breast in each of the 4 quadrants
Muscle if present

Place cassettes in rack along with other (non-breast) cassettes M-F except if the breast was removed on Thursday afternoon (see below)
If removed on Thursday afternoon (and grossed Friday) it will have an old biohazard sticker on requisition by the case label
These cassettes will need to be separated in the rack on top of the decal and labeled with the Thursday breast sign
These racks will be loaded Friday night and the weekend residents will take them out of the processor on Saturday morning
If there is a lot to process during the week and it all won’t fit on the Peloris machines- prioritize the breast racks to go on the Peloris machines (you do not have to move them to different racks)
Circle the appropriate processing information on the breast log on the door to histology. This is to complete the fixation times and ensures we do not have to log each individual case

[SOURCE: Pelvic Exenteration Gross Protocol 101121.docx]
Pelvic Exenteration
PROCEDURE:
Specimens include uterus, cervix, and vagina. Anterior: if bladder is included; posterior: if rectum is included; total: has both bladder and rectum included.  It is important to show the relationships of the cervical or vaginal tumor with all the structures present in the specimen.  Attending MUST lay eyes on these specimens.
GROSS DESCRIPTION:
Identify and measure each organ present.
Shave the vaginal, ureteral and urethral margins.
Inflate the bladder with formalin.
Fill the vagina with formalin soaked gauze. Let it fix.
After fixation bisect the specimen down the center into right and left halves.
Look for nodes in the paracervical tissues and submit them.

[SOURCE: Pelvic Exenteration Gross Protocol 101121.docx]
SECTIONS FOR HISTOLOGY:
Cervical tumor and its relationship to paracervical soft tissues, vagina, bladder and rectum.
Standard sections of endomyometrium, ovary and tubes
All lymph nodes and remaining fibroadipose tissue (up to 10 cassettes total for that part)
All margins: bilateral ureters, urethra, vagina, proximal and distal rectum.

Placentas
Placentas are sent to us fresh, and formalin added upon receipt in pathology. Please be sure your gross addresses this (“received fresh and subsequently placed in formalin labeled………….)+
Placentas with clinical history that mentions post-partum hemorrhage (PPH) and/or manual removal – submit an additional 2 cassettes with 1-2 sections each of basal layer (superficial maternal surface) to look for placenta accreta. These sections should include areas of disruption as well as intact cotyledons.

[SOURCE: Placenta ~SINGLETON~ Gross Protocol and Template 041624.docx]
For any placenta with intrauterine fetal demise (IUFD), always submit 10 cassettes – 1 each umbilical cord and membranes (more if you see something unusual, obviously), and the remaining 8 for placental disc.
Please be sure to measure placental discs in 3 dimensions. There have been cases where one of the dimensions has been cut off (the report has only shown X x X cm), so I’ve asked the transcriptionists to insert a blank/notify us so that it can be filled in appropriately.
If you gross a specimen with a study sticker on the req/container (indicating that the specimen was handled/tissue taken prior to it coming to us), please take a gross photo; they are otherwise handled per our standard procedure. If there is any information on the container or requisition with weight and/or amount of tissue removed by research, please include in your gross.

[SOURCE: Placenta ~SINGLETON~ Gross Protocol and Template 041624.docx]
When you have an (attached) umbilical cord with a *true* knot, submit your proximal/distal sections in separate cassettes, and designate which is in which cassette. Please take a gross photo of the true knot.
If you are grossly concerned for anastomosis of vessels in a multiple gestation placenta, take pictures for documentation
For a forked cord, state distance to disc edge, can take sections of both forks

[SOURCE: Placenta ~SINGLETON~ Gross Protocol and Template 041624.docx]
Gross Examination:
1. Examine the membranes and cord:
Cord: How many vessels? Any nodules on the surface? Thrombi in the vessels? TRUE knots? Membranous or marginal insertion? Hematomas, cysts, aneurysms...
Membranes: Color (green, brown, pink), Transparency (can you see the fetal vessels on the chorionic plate clearly? can you read a ruler through the membranes easily?), Nodules? yellow or white?, Insertion into disk: marginal, inside margin (circummarginate), inside margin with prominent fibrin deposition (circumvallate)

[SOURCE: Placenta ~SINGLETON~ Gross Protocol and Template 041624.docx]
After measurements and examination, cut the cord off at the disc and take two sections of cord (proximal and distal).  Take TWO membrane rolls: one at the site of rupture (if identified) and one elsewhere. Cut a strip of membranes about 2 cm wide from the most distal portion of the disk. Include a small portion of disk margin. Wrap a "jelly roll" of membranes. Cut transversely and submit one section from each roll. Once the membrane rolls are done, trim the remaining membranes off the disc and then weigh and measure the disc.
2. Examine the placental disc:

[SOURCE: Placenta ~SINGLETON~ Gross Protocol and Template 041624.docx]
After the placenta has been weighed, bread loaf the placenta at 1-2 cm intervals perpendicular to the maternal surface. Examine the parenchyma for infarcts, thrombi, cysts, masses, pallor, or other pathology. Examine the maternal floor for hematomas (fresh or organized) and/or excessive bandlike fibrin. Examine the fetal surface for discoloration, fibrin, nodules, cysts, or other pathology. Dictate findings including color and texture (red/boggy/beefy, pink/firm, etc.). Any of these abnormalities are what you will want to include in your 3 parenchyma sections. Try to stay away from the edge when taking the parenchymal sections unless it’s the site of a lesion/abnormality. Take one parenchymal section from at or near the cord insertion site and note in which cassette this is submitted.
REFERENCES:
Lester, Susan. Manual of Surgical Pathology; 2nd Ed. Churchill Livingstone, 2005.

[SOURCE: Placenta ~SINGLETON~ Gross Protocol and Template 041624.docx]
Rosai, Juan. Rosai and Ackerman’s Surgical Pathology; 9th Ed. C.V. Mosby Company. 2004.
Robboy, Stanley.  Pathology of the Female Reproductive Tract; 2nd Ed. Churchill Livingstone, 2009.

[SOURCE: Placenta twin 2 discs Gross Protocol and Template 041624.docx]
Twin Placenta (separate discs)

[SOURCE: Placenta twin 2 discs Gross Protocol and Template 041624.docx]
One of the main reasons we examine these placentas is to determine zygosity from placentation. This is possible only in monochorionic placentation (all monochorionic placentas arise from a single fertilized ova = monozygous; dichorionic placentation can arise from either dizygous or monozygous gestations). Therefore IT IS VERY IMPORTANT TO OBTAIN A GOOD SAMPLE OF DIVIDING MEMBRANES AND A CLEAR GROSS DESCRIPTION!

[SOURCE: Placenta twin 2 discs Gross Protocol and Template 041624.docx]
They come in 4 categories:
A. 2 completely separate placentas (therefore dichorionic)- handle each as a singleton placenta; no obvious dividing membrane will be present, and dividing membranes are not required in this scenario.
B. 2 placental discs which are held together by thick dividing membranes (difficult to read a ruler through the membrane). Describe the dividing membrane and where it inserts, but dictate the placentas separately, since one you've trimmed off the membranes, they will be completely separate discs
C. 1 fused placenta with a thin dividing membrane (easy to read a ruler through; monochorionic diamnionic).
D. 1 fused placenta with no dividing membrane (monochorionic monoamnionic). Dictate as a singleton with two umbilical cords.

[SOURCE: Placenta twin 2 discs Gross Protocol and Template 041624.docx]
It is important to orient the placentas as to order of delivery. Generally there will be one cord clamp on the presenting twin and two on the non-presenting; alternatively, one clamp may be labeled “A” and the other “B”. This can vary though, be sure you dictate how the cords were oriented. If they were not oriented, dictate so and arbitrarily orient them.

[SOURCE: Placenta twin 2 discs Gross Protocol and Template 041624.docx]
SECTIONS FOR HISTOLOGY:

[SOURCE: Placenta twin 2 discs Gross Protocol and Template 041624.docx]
Submit two to three sections of full-thickness parenchyma (trimmed to maximum thickness 3 mm), to include at least one section of grossly normal parenchyma and any lesions. One of these sections should be at or near the cord insertion site. Sections should NOT come from the periphery of the placental disc.
Submit two sections of umbilical cord (proximal and distal) and two membrane rolls from different sites
For twin placentas, there needs to be one cassette with the dividing membrane as a roll and a sample of the T-zone underlying dividing membrane (usually 7 cassettes total)

[SOURCE: Placenta twin 2 discs Gross Protocol and Template 041624.docx]
REFERENCES:
Lester, Susan. Manual of Surgical Pathology; 2nd Ed. Churchill Livingstone, 2005.
Rosai, Juan. Rosai and Ackerman’s Surgical Pathology; 9th Ed. C.V. Mosby Company. 2004.
Robboy, Stanley.  Pathology of the Female Reproductive Tract; 2nd Ed. Churchill Livingstone, 2009.

[SOURCE: whipple and distal panc.docx]
Pancreas and segment of duodenum (Pancreaticoduodenectomy)
[Grossly determine from which structure the tumor arises: is it pancreatic, ampullary, or duodenal in origin.  To do this, examine the appearance of the tumor and its relationship (i.e. tumor epicenter) to these organs/structures.  If the lesion is cystic, grossly determine if it communicates with the main pancreatic duct.  Always identify and submit ALL the lymph nodes.]

The anterior surface of the pancreas is inked yellow, the uncinate process margin is inked green, and the posterior surface of the pancreas is inked black.

- Sections demonstrate myocardium with a normal myofibrillary organization, with moderate interstitial and replacement-type fibrosis, highlighted by trichrome stain. Myocytolysis and vacuolization is noted within the cytoplasm of scattered cells. Scattered foci of chronic inflammation are noted, with rare foci showing occasional giant cells. Occasional myocytes within these foci demonstrate damage; however, this inflammation is interpreted as nonspecific in this setting. No granulomata are appreciated, nor are eosinophils identified. This case was reviewed at the UCH Hematopathology Consensus Conference on 10/29/2025. The marrow is hypercellular with subtle dysplastic changes involving the erythroid and megakaryocytic lineages and scattered ring sideroblasts. While these findings raise the possibility of a myelodysplastic process, they do not fully meet the morphologic criteria for myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) at this time. The changes are best classified as subtle dyspoiesis, although the differential also includes autoimmune disorders, drug or toxin exposure, hormones or growth factors, vitamin or essential element deficiencies, and viral infections, as well as a subtle myeloid neoplasm. Further clinical correlation, including review of cytogenetic and molecular studies, is recommended for further assessment.

Taken together, the morphologic, immunophenotypic, and molecular findings are consistent with a fibrotic myeloproliferative neoplasm. The presence of the hypercellular bone marrow, clustered megakaryocytes with mild dysplasia, and reticulin fibrosis makes the distinction difficult between prefibrotic primary myelofibrosis, overt fibrotic primary myelofibrosis, and essential thrombocythemia; therefore, the findings are best classified as a fibrotic myeloproliferative disorder with abnormal megakaryocytic proliferation at this time.

Thank you for allowing us to review this case for the purpose of continuing patient care. We agree with the diagnosis rendered by the originating pathologists. Only slides from the bone marrow biopsy dated 06/16/2025 were submitted for consultation review, and no parrafin block was available.

We note the patient’s recent myeloid molecular panel (September 2025). Per report, NeoGenomics identified PHF6 C20Lfs*2 and TP53 R282W mutations; FISH demonstrated a gain of chromosome 5; and karyotyping showed a normal female karyotype. These findings may be seen in clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP) or clonal cytopenia of undetermined significance (CCUS). Of note, the submitted marrow material does not show definitive morphologic evidence of dysplasia, and review of the prior bone marrow biopsy report from September 2025 (25UB:IB-1367) similarly does not describe overt dysplastic changes. Nonetheless, an underlying myelodysplastic process cannot be entirely excluded, particularly in the context of the patient's clinical and molecular findings. Further clinical correlation and evaluation are recommended.

This placenta demonstrates small size, abnormal accelerated maturation of villi, numerous clots (both between villi as well as within decidual tissue), and multiple infarcts suggesting repeated events of restricted blood flow occurring at different time points. The thrombi and infarct encompass a significant proportion of parenchyma. While downstream effects for the fetus are variable, worse outcomes are typically associated with larger parenchymal lesions. Altogether, the findings suggest an underlying problem with maternal perfusion of the placenta. Common causes include maternal vascular disease, diabetes, chronic hypertension/preeclampsia, thrombophilia, and maternal drug use (especially cocaine, heroin, and methamphetamine).
-Mature singleton placenta (405 g, 10-25th percentile for gestational age 40-0/7 weeks)
- Features of fetal vascular malperfusion, low grade, global pattern (see comment): focal stem villous thrombosis, villous stromal-vascular karyorrhexis, and avascular villi

C: The foci of fetal vascular malperfusion are distributed across all parenchymal slides, but involve small clusters of villi. These changes suggest intermittent restriction in fetal blood flow to the placenta, often caused by umbilical cord pathology. This case demonstrates hypercoiling of the umbilical cord, which has been associated with fetal vascular malperfusion.

LBD/AD: The decedent had several neurodegenerative disease occurring at once. The predominant diseases were Lewy body disease and Alzheimer’s disease. Lewy body disease is defined by alpha synuclein deposition in the form of Lewy bodies throughout the brain. These proteins eventually spread to the neocortex, which is the highest stage and is known as neocortical type. Lewy body disease is known to correlate with cognitive decline and a Parkinson’s like phenotype. There was also a high amount of Alzheimer’s disease neuropathic change, which is defined by extracellular amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles. These proteins spread throughout the brain together and also correlate with cognitive decline. The decedent also had small vessels disease that is characterized by cerebral amyloid angiopathy, which is the deposition of amyloid in the vessel walls, and arteriosclerosis, which is characterized by vessel wall damage.
Multiple Sclerosis: Multifocal chronic demyelinative plaques are identified throughout the CNS. This report discusses the ones identified

The left axillary lymph node shows well preserved nodal architecture with scattered reactive lymphoid follicles. The paracortex is expanded with mostly mixed lymphocytes; there are several foci of patchy lymphohistiocytic proliferation in the paracortex, which contain reactive lymphocytes of variable sizes and frequent histiocytes with irregular or crescentic nuclei. Abundant apoptotic cells are noted. No neutrophils or plasma cells are noted.

The focal paracortical necrotizing lymphohistiocytic proliferation is non-specific, which can be noted in autoimmune processes such as Lupus, Kikuchi-Fujimoto disease, and other reactive conditions. The overall findings as described above are suggestive of Kikuchi-Fujimoto disease. However, further correlatation with clinical examinations and laboratory studies is highly recommended. This case was shown at the UCH Hematopathology Consensus Conference on 7/13/2023, and all pathologists present concurred with the interpretation.
Patchy Paracortical Proliferations          Rest of the Lymph Node

Overall findings indicate necrotizing lymphadenitis with follicular and paracortical hyperplasia, mild increase in immunoblasts and focal vasculitis. An increase in proliferation index with increased cytotoxic T-cell subset within the necrotic area is atypical; however there is no definite evidence of lymphoma in this lymph node. Based on the morphology of the necrotic area, differential diagnosis includes systemic lupus lymphadenitis and Kikuchi lymphadenopathy. Systemic lupus lymphadenopathy is favored, given the current clinical findings of systemic lupus erythematosus encephalitis, fevers, acute hypoxemic respiratory failure, fungal pneumonia and lymphadenopathy. Case reviewed intradepartmentally by Dr. Schowinsky who concurs. Dr. Davis communicated the findings with Dr. Krienke on 1/4/22.

Vascular anomaly, favor fibroadipose vascular anomaly (FAVA)

Overall, the findings are suggestive of a benign vascular anomaly. The differential diagnosis also includes an arteriovenous malformation, given the presence of irregular and variably muscularized vessels, as well as a fibroadipose vascular anomaly (FAVA), although the latter typically presents as a painful, intramuscular lesion. As FAVA is associated with activating mutations in the PIK3CA gene, consideration of molecular studies, including SOVA, may be helpful for further diagnostic characterization.

C: Plasma cell deciduitis is often associated with maternal autoimmune disease, and a failure to appropriately immunosuppress the maternal immune system against attack on fetal antigens during pregnancy.  The presence of plasma cells indicates possible maternal antibody secretion against fetal antigens, and has been associated with fetal growth restriction and premature delivery.  It may also occur in subsequent pregnancies.

C: During normal placental development, implantation site trophoblast convert muscular arterioles in the basal plate to low-resistance vessels.  Persistence of the muscular wall indicates inadequate conversion and may be associated with pre-eclampsia or maternal hypertension.

Comment: Intravillous hemorrhage results from an acute change in pressure across fetal vessels and may be due to an acute abruption or, less commonly, cord compression. Clinical correlation is required.
Comment: Nucleated fetal red blood cells should be extremely rare in placental circulation after 28 weeks gestational age and their presence indicates in utero stress of indeterminate duration.

C: Chronic histiocytic intervillositis is a rare placental lesion which has been associated with unfavorable obstetrical outcomes, including recurrent miscarriage, intrauterine growth restriction, and intrauterine demise. In addition, it has a high recurrence risk in subsequent pregnancies (up to 30% recurrence reported). The pathogenesis is unclear but is thought to be secondary to maternal immunological dysregulation.
